Member     A Clinical Research Project submitted to the Faculty of the Florida School of Professional Psychology at National Louis University in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Psychology in Clinical Psychology    Tampa, Florida December 5, 2022 The Doctorate Program in Clinical Psychology Florida School of Professional Psychology at National Louis University   CERTIFICATE OF APPROVAL ___________________________  Clinical Research Project ___________________________  This is to certify that the Clinical Research Project of   Brianna Barnes-Harrington   has been approved by the CRP Committee on December 5, 2022 as satisfactory for the CRP requirement for the Doctorate of Psychology degree with a major in Clinical Psychology     Examining Committee:   ________________________________________  Committee Chair Christina Brown, Psy.D.    ________________________________________  Member Gary Howell, Psy.D.      i  Abstract This project examined the gap in the literature on LGB college students and social anxiety. The dearth of information around the prevalence and impact of social anxiety on the college population and the LGB population is important because social anxiety is known to be prevalent and chronic, affecting all areas of an individual’s life, but especially impacting the creation of social support networks and therefore access to social supports. Social support is one of the primary protective factors and promoters of resilience among all people, especially in marginalized communities like the LGBTQ community. Knowing that such a prevalent disorder is common among these populations and affects one of the main factors contributing to those individuals’ ability to adjust successfully and to their well-being, comes with the responsibility of better understanding that disorder, its impact on that population, and how to intervene to reduce assuage its negative effects. This project reviewed prevalence rates of social anxiety disorder (SAD) among the college student population and the LGB population to estimate the prevalence of SAD within the LGB college student population. This project also explored the risk factors of SAD for college students and LGB people to investigate the risk factors of SAD for LGB college students. Finally, this project reviewed protective factors and prevention strategies for SAD among LGB people to consider the clinical application for LGB college students, including therapeutic, social, and community interventions. Clinical implications and recommendations for future research are included.    ii  INVESTIGATING THE PREVALENCE OF SOCIAL ANXIETY IN LGB COLLEGE STUDENTS                                    Copyright ©2022   Brianna Barnes-Harrington  All rights reserved   iii  DEDICATION This project is dedicated to my incredible, amazing wife and all that we have lost along this journey. .............................................................................................................................. 162  1  CHAPTER I: INTRODUCTION AND HISTORY The lesbian, gay, and bisexual (LGB) population, which refers to the community of individuals who identify as sexual minorities, often experiences barriers and difficulties in everyday life. These barriers and difficulties include experiences such as social stress, minority stress (e.g., discrimination/prejudice), overt stigmatization, internalized homonegativity/homophobia, stigma consciousness, and sexual orientation concealment (Alessi, 2014; Cox et al., 2010). In consideration of these challenges to the everyday lives of LGB individuals, this project examines the role and impact of social anxiety disorder (SAD) in the lives of LGB individuals, particularly exploring the prevalence of social anxiety in young adulthood among LGB college students and the potential risks and protective factors that may affect these students. Understanding Minority Stress Sexual minority individuals are exposed to and affected by stress primarily related to their sexual orientation while living in a world that is predominantly heterosexual, with organization and structure set up based upon heterosexual attraction and gender roles (Rotheram-Borus & Langabeer, 2001).  It is important to define some of these stressors, including minority stress, internalized homonegativity/homophobia, stigma consciousness, and sexual orientation concealment. The minority stress theory (Meyer, 2003) asserts that the chronic stress faced by minority individuals, including sexual minorities, as a result of stigma, prejudice, and discrimination related to their identity can lead to an increased risk of health problems. Minority stress is related to the otherness and oppression that nonheterosexual individuals continually experience from existing within the norms and structures meant for a heterosexual-centric society (Woodford et 2   al., 2015). LGB individuals are more likely to report lifetime and day-to-day experiences of discrimination and that these experiences of discrimination made their lives more difficult, including challenging their ability to lead a full and productive life, compared to heterosexual individuals (Mays & Cochran, 2001). Individuals reporting lifetime or day-to-day experiences of discrimination had significantly increased odds of having a psychiatric disorder, low ratings of current mental health, and high psychological distress (Mays & Cochran, 2001). LGB individuals also experience internalized stressors such as internalized homonegativity/homophobia, which occurs when the negative attitudes and stereotypes of sexual minority orientations from the broader heterosexual culture are internalized by the individual toward themselves and others in the LGB community (Cox et al., 2010). There also appears to be a relationship between internalized homonegativity and depression, self-esteem, and psychological distress (Alessi, 2014; Cox et al., 2010; DiPlacido, 1998; Meyer, 1995, 2001, 2003; Shidlo, 1994; Vanden Berghe et al., 2010). Stigma consciousness refers to “the extent to which people expect to be stereotyped by others” (Cox et al., 2010, p. 1201) due to the awareness of their own possession of a stigma or difference from others or society that is considered undesirable (Pinel, 1999). The more someone is aware of themselves as stigmatized, the more important it may be to anticipate being stereotyped, which can negatively affect an LGB individual’s health, psychological, and social functioning (Cox et al., 2010). Sexual orientation concealment and general self-concealment may increase LGB individuals’ risk for developing mental health concerns. Self-concealment can be defined as actively hiding personal information that could be emotionally distressing or embarrassing (Leleux-Labarge et al., 2015). Concealing sexual orientation can range from engaging in subtle 3   efforts of impression management that allow one’s orientation to be unnoticeable to overtly declaring a heterosexual identity (J. M. Cohen et al., 2016). It is operationally defined as the “lack of disclosure,” “lack of open behavior,” “lack of general openness,” and “lack of public knowledge” about one’s sexual orientation with others (Pachankis et al., 2020, p. 833). Sexual minorities are at an increased risk for overall psychological distress and psychopathology (Cochran & Mays, 2000; King et al., 2008; Kirsch et al., 2015; McAleavey et al., 2011). It has been found that LGB individuals are more likely to experience a mood or anxiety disorder than their heterosexual counterparts (Bostwick et al., 2010), and LGB college students experience greater psychological distress and decreased social well-being during the first year of undergraduate studies compared to heterosexual peers (Kirsch et al., 2015). Research has demonstrated that LGB individuals face many factors that can lead to increased stress and mental health difficulties (Alessi, 2014; Anderson et al., 2015; Bostwick et al., 2010; Cox et al., 2010; Kirsch et al., 2015; Leleux-Labarge et al., 2015; Mays & Cochran, 2001; Pachankis et al., 2020; Safren & Pantalone, 2006; Woodford et al., 2015). Growing up in a predominantly heterosexual society can begin to impact LGB individuals from early adolescence well into adulthood (Kirsch et al., 2015; Safren & Pantalone, 2006; Woodford et al., 2015). The transition to adulthood, specifically college life, is also stressful for most young adults, even when they have the needed support and resources (Kirsch et al., 2015). As LGB individuals may be at risk for developing SAD due to the nature of their experiences in the world around them (Bostwick et al., 2010; Kirsch et al., 2015) and the potential barrier that SAD could be for those individuals (Safren & Pantalone, 2006) in being able to adjust and build the supports needed to be successful in college, it would seem to emphasize that this is an important area to understand. 4   Social Anxiety Disorder SAD, a fear in social situations that often leads to social avoidance (American Psychiatric Association [APA], 2013), may be an added barrier for some LGB individuals. SAD is defined by the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (5th ed.; DSM-5; APA, 2013) as “marked fear or anxiety about one or more social situations in which the individual is exposed to possible scrutiny by others” (p. 202), as well as the fear that while in these situations their behavior or anxiety will lead to negative evaluation, potential embarrassment, or possible rejection by others. This causes these social situations to provoke a disproportionate amount of fear or anxiety within the individual, leading them to either avoid social situations or suffer from intense fear or anxiety for the duration of the situation. To diagnose this disorder, the individual must have experienced fear, anxiety, and avoidance over at least 6 months. The fear and anxiety must cause clinically significant distress or impairment in functioning (APA, 2013). According to the DSM-5, the United States 12-month prevalence rate of SAD is approximately 7% (APA, 2013). This corresponds to the National Comorbidity Survey Replication (NCS-R) findings, which identified a 6.8% 12-month-prevalence of social phobia in the general population (Kessler et al., 2005). The National Comorbidity Survey found lifetime prevalence rates of SAD to be 13.3% (Magee et al., 1996). While SAD is considered a prevalent disorder with a chronic course and an early onset (APA, 2013; Furmark, 2002), there is very limited research and information on its prevalence and impact on college students generally. In the general population, SAD rates are higher among women than men, ranging from 1.5 to 2.2 times more likely for women, with the difference being more prominent among adolescents and young adults (APA, 2013). In the United States, the median age of onset is 13 years, with 75% of individuals experiencing onset between age 8 5   and 15 (APA, 2013). The onset of SAD may emerge from a history of social inhibition or shyness in childhood, following a stressful or humiliating experience, or after significant life changes associated with new social roles (APA, 2013). How SAD manifests can vary based upon the age of the individual, with adolescents endorsing a broad range of fear and avoidance across many situations; young adults expressing higher levels of situation-specific anxiety; and older adults expressing lower levels of social anxiety across a wider variety of situations (APA, 2013). The course of SAD can vary and tends to be particularly persistent for individuals who present for treatment (APA, 2013). In the community, remission of symptoms occurs for about 30% of individuals with SAD in one year and for approximately 50% of individuals within a few years (APA, 2013). Without SAD-specific treatment, symptom remission can take several years or more for around 60% of individuals with SAD (APA, 2013). SAD is a heritable disorder, which increases the likelihood of first-degree relatives also having SAD (APA, 2013). Behavioral inhibition and fear of negative evaluation are two traits that can predispose individuals to SAD, both of which are strongly influenced by one’s genetics and influenced by the gene-environment interaction (APA, 2013). The importance of understanding the prevalence and impact of SAD on college students can be seen in the growing number of studies examining it in many countries around the world (Ahmad et al., 2017; Bella & Omigbodun, 2009; Desalegn et al., 2019; Kuder & Grover, 2014; Parade et al., 2010; Pshyk et al., 2019; Reta et al., 2020; Russell & Shaw, 2009; Seim & Spates, 2010; Strahan, 2003; Tillfors & Furmark, 2007). 6   Social Anxiety in the LGB Population Knowing that SAD can have a significant impact on functioning for the general college student emphasizes the potential for a compounding impact on LGB students as well. An important consequence of having SAD is that it could limit the individual’s willingness or ability to seek out social supports and engage in positive activities, which is important, as social support is likely a protective factor for LGB individuals (Safren & Pantalone, 2006). Social anxiety is significantly and negatively associated with social support (Potoczniak et al., 2007). Safren and Pantalone (2006) suggested that social anxiety itself may be a barrier for LGB individuals in creating and building social supports and partaking in social events because the fear and avoidance of social interactions associated with social anxiety and the pressures faced by LGB individuals to hide their sexual orientation and conform to heterosexual norms may limit their ability to form satisfying and supportive relationships with their peers. Link and Phelan (2001) indicated that connecting stereotypes of certain groups of people, such as individuals labeled with mental illness like SAD, to negative or undesirable characteristics, often leads to stigma and separation of that group from others “through loss of status, discrimination, and differences in social, economic, and political power” (Anderson et al., 2015, p. 131; Link & Phelan, 2001). LGB individuals may have increased chances of experiencing peer-related social anxiety as they may perceive themselves as different in a way that is typically rejected by peers (Safren & Pantalone, 2006). Statement of Problem Compared to their heterosexual peers, LGB college students are at an elevated risk for mental health issues, including social anxiety, due in part to their minority status and the corresponding stress (Bostwick et al., 2010; Kirsch et al., 2015). Social anxiety could be a barrier 7   to LGB students’ ability to adjust to college, connect with peer supports, and reach out for assistance (Safren & Pantalone, 2006). However, current research tells us little about SAD among college-age individuals and even less about college-age LGB individuals. This paper strives to investigate the prevalence of social anxiety in LGB college students. Understanding the prevalence of SAD among college-age LGB individuals, the barriers and risk factors for this population, and how they can be supported through this transitional time may allow for the reduction or prevention of the development of SAD and allow these individuals to manage the stressors of college successfully and reach their goals. This project primarily refers to the LGB community, versus the broader lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, questioning, and others (LGBTQ+) umbrella terminology, due to the acknowledgement that there are different experiences between sexual minorities and gender minorities. While individuals who identify as transgender or gender nonconforming are affected by some of the same stressors as sexual minorities, it is understood that additional intersectional layers add complexity to their challenges and deserve their own direct focus. At times, this paper may refer to specific groups within the larger LGBTQ community or use varying specifiers to identify the community, such as LGB, LGBT, LGBTQ, LGBTQ+, and LGBTQIA+. These differences in language will be solely based on the language used by researchers, as there is much variance across research in how they defined and referred to the broader community or the specific group they studied. Due to the comprehensive nature of this paper, some older research uses terms that are no longer used within the LGBTQIA+ community; these terms are only used in reference to those specific studies. 8   Purpose of the Study The purpose of this literature review is to examine the gap in the research on social anxiety among LGB college students and highlight the potential implications for this population. Research Questions and Hypotheses 1. What is the prevalence of social anxiety among LGB college students? As research tends to report a higher prevalence rate of social anxiety and other psychological disorders among LGB individuals, it is hypothesized that LGB college students will also report higher rates of social anxiety than their heterosexual peers. 2. What are contributing factors to social anxiety among LGB college students? It is hypothesized that factors that contribute to social anxiety among LGB college students will be an intersection of those factors that contribute to social anxiety for other LGB individuals and other college students, such as identity development, social support, minority stress, and significant life transitions. 3. What factors can facilitate resilience and prevent or protect LGB college students from developing social anxiety? The hypothesis is that the preventative or protective factors of social anxiety for LGB college students will be an intersection of factors that are preventative or protective for LGB individuals and college students overall, such as perceived social support, increased supports on college campuses, accessible resources targeted to this specific population, integrated programming in the orientation process, and reduced stigma surrounding LGB community and mental health overall. Research Procedure The variables to be researched include social anxiety, college-age students, and the LGB-identified population. The research questions were evaluated by examining current research on 9   social anxiety among LGB college students, social anxiety overall, social anxiety within the LGB community, and social anxiety among college-age students in general. The databases used to search for existing research literature included EBSCOhost, Google Scholar, PsycINFO, PsycNET, ResearchGate, and research also acquired from referenced articles in the results of these searches. The search terms utilized included social anxiety and LGB and college student, social anxiety and LGB, social anxiety among LGB, social anxiety and LGBT, social anxiety among LGBT, social phobia among LGBT, rates of social anxiety among LGB, prevalence of social phobia among LGBT, sexual minority and social anxiety, prevalence of SAD, risk factors for LGB individuals, barriers to resilience LGB, barriers to help seeking LGB, LGB* college students, LGB* university, SAD or social phobia and lesbian, SAD or social phobia and bisexual, SAD or social phobia and college students or university students, SAD or social phobia and prevalence, protective factors for social anxiety, determinants of social anxiety. Factors of inclusion for journal articles were papers that included social anxiety, LGB, LGBT, any one subgroup of the LGBT community, academic journals, full text, scholarly (peer-reviewed) journals, and availability in the English language. Factors of exclusion for journal articles were papers where the primary focus of the research was not related directly to the variables of interest.   10   CHAPTER II: THE PREVALENCE OF SOCIAL ANXIETY AMONG LGB COLLEGE STUDENTS The literature suggests a high prevalence of social anxiety among college students in general (Nordstrom et al., 2014) and among the LGB population in particular (Bostwick et al., 2010). However, there is a gap in our knowledge about the prevalence of social anxiety among LGB college students. The presence of social anxiety in LGB college students is important to consider when thinking about its impact on these students during the formative, transitional period of college. This chapter explores more about the prevalence of social anxiety in LGB college students. Due to the dearth of information and research on this specific intersection of the LGB and college populations, research on both populations separately was considered to inform the potential prevalence of LGB college students. As research tends to report a higher prevalence rate of social anxiety and other psychological disorders among LGB individuals, it was hypothesized that LGB college students experience higher rates of social anxiety than their heterosexual peers. It was also hypothesized that LGB college students experience social anxiety at a prevalence rate similar to the LGB population in general. SAD in College Students To begin the investigation into the prevalence of social anxiety among LGB college students, the prevalence of social anxiety among college students in general was examined first. Specific research into the prevalence of SAD in college students in the United States is limited, although there appears to be a consensus that it is common, with a prevalence of high or clinical levels of social anxiety between 19-33% of college students (Parade et al., 2010). Overall, most research on SAD among the college population has been completed in other countries around the 11   world, though two studies were completed in the United States that did report the prevalence of social anxiety in their participant sample (Kuder & Grover, 2014; Strahan, 2003). Strahan (2003) examined the effects of social anxiety and social skills on the academic performance of first-year university students in the United States. The purpose of this study was to examine what role, if any, high-trait social anxiety plays in an individual’s undergraduate academic career. The researchers randomly selected 1600 first-year students who were contacted with an invitation to participate in the study during the first two weeks of classes via campus and U.S. mail. Over 800 of the invited students registered to participate via the response portion of the invitation. Ultimately, only 16% of the invited sample participated in the study, with 253 students completing the assessments. The authors indicated the sample reflected the composition of the campus, with 200 European-American students, 22 Asian-American students, 15 African American students, 9 Hispanic American students, and 2 students who identified as other. The gender of the students was not provided (Strahan, 2003). This study used several measures to assess the variables of social anxiety, social competence, and academic persistence. The Social Phobia and Anxiety Inventory (SPAI; Turner et al., 1989) is a measure of social anxiety where participants endorse a response to statements describing anxiety in certain social situations on a seven-point scale ranging from “never” to “always.” The authors used the SPAI Social Phobia subscale to investigate the degree of social anxiety within the sample using cutoffs of 90 for women and 100 for men based on previous research. The authors used the Social Skills Inventory (SSI; Riggio, 1986), a social competence inventory containing 90 items, to measure the social competence of the sample. On the SSI, participants respond using a five-point scale ranging from ‘1 = Not at all like me” to “5 = 12   Exactly like me.” The authors assessed the sample’s academic persistence using a 13-item measure, the adapted College Affiliation Questionnaire (Cabrera et al., 1993). The participants completed the measures for the study during the first 4 to 6 weeks of classes in small group testing sessions with 4 to 15 students. As included in the initial informed consent for the study, the researchers completed a follow-up data collection to access student records for grade point average (GPA) and enrollment for two years after the study began, as these were the variables they were intending to predict. As part of the study, they examined the prevalence of clinical levels of social anxiety among the participants (Strahan, 2003). Based on the social phobia scale of the SPAI, results indicated a 22% prevalence rate of social anxiety among this sample of college students (Strahan, 2003). The authors noted that this prevalence rate could be somewhat larger than the actual prevalence due to the potential overrepresentation of women in the sample, as reports of social anxiety tend to be higher among women than men. However, they found this prevalence rate similar to the one in another study at a large university (Turner et al., 1989). The authors cited prevalence rates found in prior research, including one study by Beidel et al. (1989), which found 19% of the sample of undergraduate students met the criteria for social phobia and another study by Strahan and Conger (1998) in which social phobia symptoms were reported by 33% of a sample of undergraduate men. The primary purpose of this study was not to determine the prevalence of social anxiety in the student population, and the final sample size was small for that purpose. However, the study had the potential to be a large study on the first-year student population. It is important to keep the sample size and small numbers of minority groups in mind when considering the generalizability of the results found in this study, as well as the very low response rate of the 13   invited students, because all these factors limit the generalizability of the results from the study. With a 16% participation rate, the students who participated in the study may possess certain qualities that led them to participate compared to those who did not. The authors did explore differences between the students in their sample and nonparticipant students in the Registrar database in terms of gender and academic variables, finding that the group in the study may be “somewhat more academically talented . . . more female. . . [and] persist in somewhat greater numbers” (Strahan, 2003, p. 353) than the general first-year student population of this cohort. Acknowledging the limited generalizability for a small sample size, even with limited power, the study found a significant effect, which might be seen in larger studies if replicated (Strahan, 2003). Another study (Kuder & Grover, 2014) examined the performance of socially anxious college students from a mid-Atlantic Jesuit university while they were observed in a conversation with a friend. The perception of the student’s own social performance was used to examine perceived social competencies and observable behaviors of social anxiety. The study was conducted through convenience sampling of 54 undergraduate students through a university psychology department. The only requirements for participation were being aged 18 to 21 and currently enrolled in college. Participants volunteered through the psychology department research portal and received credit in introductory psychology courses in return for their participation. The participants were 70% women and 85% White, 7% Asian/Pacific Islander, 6% Hispanic, and 2% Black. Participants were between 18 and 21, with a mean age of 18.65 (Kuder & Grover, 2014). During the study, participants and a friend of their choice were directed to a room with two chairs and a video camera, where they were left alone. Each participant was instructed to 14   have a 10-minute conversation with their friend about something they would like to change about themselves. This conversation was videotaped. Their conversations were assessed using the Social Performance Rating Scale (SPRS; Fydrich et al., 1998), a system used to evaluate social skills through rated observed behaviors. Individuals are rated on five behavioral indicators of anxiety: gaze, discomfort, vocal quality, length of contribution, and flow of conversation. Ratings are completed on a 5-point Likert scale. In this study, gaze was not rated due to some visibility concerns with lighting on the videotapes. The raters were two trained undergraduate students (Kuder & Grover, 2014). Following the conversation, participants completed an online survey that included a demographic questionnaire and assessments to evaluate social anxiety and interpersonal competence. The study used the Social Anxiety Scale for Adolescents (SAS-A; La Greca & Lopez, 1998) to assess social anxiety. The SAS-A is a self-report measure where participants rate 22 statements on a five-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (not at all) to 5 (all the time). This assessment provides an overall social anxiety score along with three subscale scores for fear of negative evaluation, social anxiety and distress in new situations, and social anxiety and distress in general. The Interpersonal Competence Questionnaire (ICQ; Buhrmester et al., 1988) is a 40-item rating scale developed to assess college students’ competency in close friendships and romantic relationships. It evaluates five domains: initiating relationships, self-disclosure, providing emotional support, negative assertion, and conflict management. Items are rated on a scale from one (poor; uncomfortable) to five (extremely good; very comfortable). After each item, participants rate their perception of their own competencies and their comfort levels with a same-sex and a different-sex friend or romantic partner. The authors used Pearson correlations to 15   explore whether social anxiety was related to ratings of observed performance and perception of social competence (Kuder & Grover, 2014). The study found that 48.1% of participants had significant social anxiety, based upon analysis of SAS-A scores with total score cutoffs of 44. Additionally, they found general social anxiety was significantly negatively correlated with two of the observed social performance behaviors (comfort and length) and perceived general interpersonal competencies. Individuals with higher social anxiety reported lower social competencies, displayed less comfort, and provided very short or long additions to the conversation. In general, it appears that students who are socially anxious tended to have more negative perceptions of their social competencies than peers who were not anxious, and these young adults seemed to demonstrate deficits in performance in conversations (Kuder & Grover, 2014). The generalizability of this study appears to be fairly limited as it was a small study with only 54 participants. The participants were primarily White, female, undergraduate psychology students, and the use of convenience sampling may not have allowed for a representative sample of the student population at this university, let alone of the college student population at large. There are also limits on the generalizability, particularly for minority students, as the sample was homogenous and not representative of the general population, though it may be representative of that school or area. For example, the experience of one Black student (2% in the study) cannot be generalized to any broader group. Additionally, this study was part of a larger study examining the link between psychopathology in young adults and their social relationships, which seems to be even more of a convenience sampling. It is unclear whether they are examining data that initially had another purpose or if all the data were collected and included with this study in mind from the beginning. This could have made their sample even more limited than if subjects were 16   recruited specifically for this study. The demographics questionnaire was fairly limited, limiting the factors that can be examined in the study, though the sample size was likely too small for between comparisons regardless (Kuder & Grover, 2014). Conversely, the mean age of participants was 18.65, which is representative of first-year college students who would be in the middle of making the transition into college. It could be useful to look specifically at students transitioning into college, as they are likely the most at risk regarding the consequences of social anxiety impacting their success and experience. This could be a significant time when support and prevention for students could be most impactful. Additionally, the findings of “significant social anxiety” for participants were not based explicitly on the diagnostic criteria for SAD, which could mean that the study may not be measuring the same clinical construct, though this may be unlikely due to the support for the construct validity of the assessment in previous research. A potential challenge in this study, particularly with a socially anxious population, was the use of self-report measures, which may have been affected by social desirability, leading to underreporting of symptoms, minimization of problems, or increased competence levels. Nevertheless, the research study and its findings are still relevant in that they were working with the college student population and examining the experience and impact of social anxiety on students (Kuder & Grover, 2014). One study examined the prevalence of social phobia among students at a Swedish university (Tillfors & Furmark, 2007). In addition to prevalence among university students, the authors wanted to investigate the association between avoidant behavior in anticipation of public speaking and SAD, examine any demographic features that may be more prevalent with SAD, and compare prevalence rates of SAD among university students to that of the general Swedish population. A postal survey was sent to a sample of 753 university students in Sweden randomly 17   selected via a student-based registry from two universities. Students were chosen from three strata of the total student population—natural science/technique, social science/humanistic, and pedagogic programs. Selected students were in their fourth semester, which was chosen to minimize the influence of non-social-phobia-related factors, such as choosing the wrong program of study. Separate sampling by sex was used due to unequal distribution in the total population and each stratum. A diagnostic questionnaire, a separate identification sheet, and a letter explaining the objectives of the study were mailed to the selected participants. Two reminders were mailed to non-responders over five weeks. Ten students could not be reached by mail, 2 students were abroad and could not respond, and an additional 218 students did not respond. In total, 523 student responses (69.5%) were interpretable. The sample consisted of 178 men and 345 women ages 18-60 (Tillfors & Furmark, 2007). Measures used included the Social Phobia Screening Questionnaire (SPSQ; Furmark et al., 1999) to assess social phobia, and the Swedish versions of the Social Phobia Scale (SPS; Heimberg et al., 1992) and the Social Interaction Anxiety Scale (SIAS; Heimberg et al., 1992) were used to validate the clusters of clinically identified subgroups within social phobia. Additional information was gathered with questions about parental history, sociodemographic data, personal information, educational program, and location/county where participants grew up. Participants were also asked if fear of speaking in front of an audience led them to avoid an educational situation to assess for public speaking avoidance. The authors established a Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (4th ed; DSM-IV; APA, 1994) diagnosis of social phobia using the diagnostic section of the SPSQ. For this measure, participants were asked to rate the amount of distress on a scale from 0 (no distress) to 4 (severe distress) caused by 14 possibly phobic scenarios. Following that, six diagnostic questions were asked to 18   determine if the participant fit criteria A-D of DSM-IV social phobia in one or more of the scenarios. To assess E-criterion, the requirement that the avoidance, anxiety, or distress interferes with the person’s ability to function; the participant was asked three yes or no questions to determine if the social discomfort was significant enough to significantly interfere with or bother them in their work, school, leisure, or social activities (Tillfors & Furmark, 2007). The researchers were most interested in the prevalence results of the current study, which found 16.1% of participants met the criteria for social phobia. The authors reported that this rate did not differ from the Swedish general population prevalence rate of 15.6% for social phobia. Those prevalence rates are moderately higher than the estimated 7% 12-month prevalence rate of SAD in the United States (APA, 2013). The researchers also contacted 86 individuals who did not respond to the initial invitation, of which 86 responded and completed a short interview of the SPSQ. Of these 86 respondents, 33 (38.4%) met the impairment criteria, leading the researchers to conclude that the non-responders were more impaired than the individuals who participated in the full study. They indicated that this might mean the 16.1% prevalence of SAD among Swedish university students may be an underestimation (Tillfors & Furmark, 2007). Overall, the study was very thorough and addressed many of the challenges of previous research using random sampling and diagnostic criteria for assessment. While the total number of participants is high, the number with social phobia is lower. This is consistent with a prevalence rate of less than 20%, but it may make it more difficult to gain an understanding or make inferences or correlations about those who do meet the criteria as a group since there are very few of them compared to the overall number of participants. The generalizability of the study is limited because even though the students were randomly selected, the two universities were not randomly selected, and approximately 30% of the student sample did not respond, 19   which means that the results may not be generalizable to all university students in Sweden. Additionally, the authors suggested that their study may underestimate the prevalence of social anxiety, as the completed attrition analysis indicated that non-responders might be more impaired than those who participated in the study. The use of self-report measures may limit the accuracy of the diagnostic tools or data collected, as participants may demonstrate bias by either reporting in a socially desirable manner, inaccurately assessing themselves, misunderstanding or misinterpreting the questions, or having a tendency for neutral or extreme response ratings. For these reasons, the assessment of social anxiety may be considered indicative of social anxiety versus akin to a formal diagnosis. It is worth noting that in this paper the authors talked about subgroups of social phobia and referring to the DSM-III, when DSM-IV was introduced in 1994, approximately 13 years prior to the study. It is unclear why they are using the term social phobia instead of SAD, especially as they were utilizing the DSM-IV diagnostic criteria, which are much broader than the DSM-III disorder of social phobia. This raises the need for consideration in ensuring that the constructs being measured, instruments used for measurement, and the overall literature pertaining to social anxiety are indeed talking about the same construct (Tillfors & Furmark, 2007). A study at the University of Ibadan in Nigeria (Bella & Omigbodun, 2009) examined the prevalence of social phobia among university students, as well as sociodemographic correlates and comorbidity with depression and alcohol use disorders. This study was a cross-sectional survey of students at the university and included undergraduate students who were 18 or older, had been at the university for at least one year, and who were currently living in the residence halls. Exclusion criteria included students with severe mental disorders, such as schizophrenia, or physical impairments, such as motor or sensory. They used multistage sampling to recruit 20   students to the study based on proportion to the population. They chose a sample size of 500 subjects based on the 0.3% lifetime prevalence of social phobia in the general population of Nigeria. The authors utilized a stratified selection for men and women separately due to unequal sex distribution in the student population. There were 413 participants. Of the 500 selected, 53 refused to participate, and 34 questionnaires were not used due to missing data. Participants ranged in age from 18 to 49 years old, with a mean age of 22.9 years and only 2.4% aged 30 or older. The majority of the participants were men (66.5%) and single (98.8%; Bella & Omigbodun, 2009). The study was completed in two stages. In the first stage, selected students were given a sociodemographic questionnaire, an alcohol use assessment, a general health questionnaire, and a disability assessment. In face-to-face interviews, the screening section of a diagnostic interview was administered. The sociodemographic questionnaire gathered information on age, gender, marital status, religion, state of origin, level and course of study, and monthly allowance. Additionally, it included their parents’ highest level of education and present occupation to determine the social class of the students. A diagnostic interview was completed using the World Mental Health Initiative version of the Composite International Diagnostic Interview (WMH-CIDI; Kessler & Ustun, 2004), which screens for several disorders, including social phobia and depression. The authors used the social phobia and depression module questions for the interview, basing diagnoses on DSM-IV criteria. The Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT; Adewuya, 2005; Saunders et al., 1993) is a self-rated, 10-item questionnaire about alcohol consumption and alcohol-related problems. Each item is scored from zero to four, with total scores of five and above having been shown to be indicative of hazardous alcohol use. The General Health Questionnaire (GHQ-12; Goldberg, 1978) is a self-administered assessment 21   designed to detect psychological distress. Scores above one suggest psychological distress; however, this study used a cutoff of two and above for specificity. The World Health Organization Disability Assessment Schedule (WHO-DAS II; World Health Organization, 2000) is a 12-item self-administered questionnaire that assesses overall daily functioning. Items are rated on an ordinal scale from one (no difficulty) to five (extreme/cannot do). This study used the questions to assess for overall health and interference with daily living. The second stage of the study involved a follow-up to students who had provided a positive response to one or more screening questions for social phobia or depression. In the second stage, these students were administered the full diagnostic interview using the WMH-CIDI social phobia or depression module questions, with diagnoses based on the DSM-IV criteria (Bella & Omigbodun, 2009). Descriptive statistics were used to summarize continuous variables. Percentages were used to summarize categorical variables. The chi-squared test was used to compare two proportions and investigate the association between two qualitative variables at a 5% level of significance. Variables that were statistically significant in bivariate analysis were entered into a logistic regression analysis using a stepwise backward elimination method. Associations between social phobia and explanatory variables were computed using the logistic regression model (Bella & Omigbodun, 2009). Researchers found the 12-month social phobia prevalence was 8.5%, and the lifetime prevalence was 9.4% among university students sampled. They noted that social phobia was also strongly associated with depression, psychological distress, and poor overall health (Bella & Omigbodun, 2009). Only students who responded positively to one or more of the social phobia or depression screening questions were given a full interview, which means that there could be a possibility 22   that the lifetime prevalence could be underrepresented. Additional limitations to this study included that it was conducted in another country and could represent factors specific to the students in this study. However, it is helpful that they found similar prevalence rates to those found in other research. Overall, while the methods used would appear to support the validity of the research, one concern would be that the interviews with students were conducted at the residence hall, which could pose concerns for confidentiality and comfort (Bella & Omigbodun, 2009). A study in the United Kingdom (Russell & Shaw, 2009) used an opportunistic sampling method to investigate the prevalence of social anxiety among university undergraduate students at a large university and its partnership colleges across seven departments. The authors utilized an opportunistic sampling method to obtain participation from students from a variety of programs, as they noted a 2003 report indicated that vulnerability to mental health issues tends to vary by program. The sample consisted of 1,007 students from 7 faculties and 2 partner colleges. Postgraduate students were not included due to time constraints. Eight hundred fifty-six students, or 85.0% of the total population, completed the study questionnaire. Participants were of a broad age range, from under 21 to over 50, with the majority of students being under 30 years old. The sample was 61.3% women, 38.3% men, and 8 students who did not specify gender. Researchers assessed social anxiety using the Liebowitz Social Anxiety Scale (LSAS; Liebowitz, 1987), a self-report measure consisting of 24 items that describe a situation that an individual rates based upon how much anxiety that situation provokes for them (fear) and how often they avoid that situation (avoidance). Ratings are from zero (none or never) to three (severe or usually). The scale can be divided into four subscales of fear of performance, fear of social interaction, avoidance of performance, and avoidance of social interaction. It also provides a 23   total avoidance score and a total fear score, combined for a total LSAS score that measures the individual’s experience of clinical social anxiety. Scores below 55 are considered mild and clinically insignificant, while scores from 55 to 65 are moderate, 65 to 80 are marked, 80 to 95 are severe, and greater than 95 are very severe (Russell & Shaw, 2009). The researchers found that 9.9% of university and college students surveyed with the LSAS reported “marked” to “very severe” social anxiety (Russell & Shaw, 2009). It is unclear why they reported 9.9% versus the 16.4% of moderate to very severe scores, as scores above 55 are considered clinically significant. They also found a statistically significant difference between men and women, with women showing higher scores across total social anxiety and all subscales. Additional important findings included that a small proportion of the students reported a severe fear of speaking out in public, some reported a severe fear of interacting with strangers or people they did not know well, some reported they regularly avoided speaking out, and some reported they regularly avoided looking directly at people they were unfamiliar with (Russell & Shaw, 2009). These are important findings because each fear and behavior can significantly impact a student’s ability to engage effectively in their school and social settings. This study could generalizable to the broader population of college students, though the results have the potential to be related to the characteristics of the students who volunteered to participate in the study. The generalizability for this study is limited, as it only includes students from a UK university, and the demographic variables are minimal, so there is not a good understanding of the population sample that is included in this study and to whom these results can really apply. Additionally, the authors noted that the opportunistic sampling method used in this study resulted in disproportionate numbers of students particularly related to age and faculty (area of study), so it 24   is likely that the sample is not representative of the university population at this specific school or universities more broadly. Despite the concerns around generalizability, the prevalence rate they found was comparable to other studies examining the college population, which may suggest that this population has similar experiences across regions/countries/nationalities (Russell & Shaw, 2009). A study (Ahmad et al., 2017) was conducted at Garmian University to investigate the prevalence of social anxiety and associated factors among undergraduate students. The authors conducted a cross-sectional descriptive study, which entailed administering a demographic questionnaire and a social phobia inventory (SPIN) and then analyzing the data with descriptive and analytic statistics. With a total undergraduate college of education population of 1,918 students, the authors randomly selected 250 students and distributed questionnaires to them. Of these, 198 were fully completed, with a response rate of 79.2%. The participants ranged in age from 19 to 27, with a mean age of 20.53. Respondents were 107 female students (54%) and 91 male students. The sample consisted mostly of first-year students (35.9%), with 18.2% second-year students, 20.2% third-year students, and 25.8% fourth-year students (Ahmad et al., 2017). To assess social anxiety, researchers utilized a translated version of the Social Phobia Inventory (SPIN) developed by Connor et al. (2000), which consists of 17 items rated on a Likert scale from 0 (not at all) to 4 (extremely). The inventory consists of three subscales: fear, avoidance, and physiological conditions. A score over 20 indicates social anxiety, with scores from 21 to 30 categorized as mild, 31 to 40 as moderate, 41 to 50 severe, and 51+ as very severe (Ahmad et al., 2017). The researchers found that more than 80% of students in the study showed varying degrees of social phobia based on responses to the SPIN, with 20.2% mild, 41.9% moderate, and 25   28.3% severe. They reported that only 8.6% of students endorsed below-threshold scores, and no students indicated very severe scores. They found an association between gender and social phobia, with a higher prevalence among women and higher prevalence among first- and second-year students who experienced a higher degree of social phobia than junior and senior students (Ahmad et al., 2017). While their findings had much higher prevalence rates than other similar studies (Bani Mustafa et al., 2014; Momeni et al., 2015; Salina et al., 2008; Tillfors & Furmark, 2007), their results were similar in indicating support for the prevalence of SAD among college students. This study also noted a higher prevalence of SAD among female students compared to men and first- and second-year students compared to third- and fourth-year students. This study has limited generalizability, as the sample was from one university, one college within that university, and with limited demographic data provided. It is unclear if the sample is representative of the population of the university, the country, or university students overall. Additionally, education students could have unique characteristics that lead to a prevalence different from the general college student population. As the study was survey-based, results could also be limited by the characteristics that led these students to respond versus those who did not. The authors proposed that social anxiety could also be why many students did not participate in the survey, which would also impact the prevalence. The authors mentioned that they controlled for limitations of mental and emotional conditions that could impact how students responded but did not elaborate on how or what exactly that means. As with many of the studies reviewed, it may be difficult to generalize these results to university students in the United States or other countries, but the findings indicating that SAD is a concern among university students are consistent with the current body of research overall. The authors 26   discussed that this estimated prevalence may not be the most accurate due to higher levels of anxiety found in girls and first-year and second-year students (similar to other studies), which made up more than half of their participants. It seems that the authors identified gender (specifically woman identified) as a predisposing factor for developing SAD, as they mentioned previous research that also indicated this. However, while a significant gender difference is noted, it is difficult to conclude anything more than a correlation for gender as a risk factor based on the study design. Social anxiety was assessed using the SPIN, which does not directly equate to a SAD diagnosis, but it has been demonstrated to differentiate between socially phobic and non-phobic populations (Connor et al., 2000). One concern about the methodology of the study is that the SPIN was not originally translated into Kurdish, so a team of experts at the university translated it into Kurdish for the study, which initially raises concern about the validity and reliability of the instrument as it has not been tested and researched in this form. To ensure validity, the researchers presented the translated version of the questionnaire to five psychology experts at the university who approved it, and then tested the validity and reliability of the instrument with a sample group of 50 students prior to using the instrument in the study. Another challenge in this study, much like in others, is the interchangeable use of social anxiety and social phobia, which can be confusing as diagnostically these terms refer to a somewhat different set of criteria. Specifically, they refer to the SPIN as the social anxiety inventory while also referencing social phobia disorder and socially phobic individuals. It is unclear if this is an intentional change, perhaps in an effort to use more current terminology, or a translational issue, but being the name of an official measure, it seems problematic to refer to it by an alternative name (Ahmad et al., 2017). 27   A study from Gondar, Ethiopia, examined the prevalence of social phobia and its correlates among undergraduate university students studying health science (Desalegn et al., 2019). The study intended to inform the development of interventions for students that would ensure they receive optimal care. The study was an institution-based cross-sectional study conducted with students from the College of Medicine and Health Sciences at the University of Gondar. The only exclusion was students who were critically ill, though the authors did not define that term. The authors determined sample size using a single population proportion formula, which included a margin of error, estimated prevalence of social phobia from a previous study completed in Ethiopia, and an anticipated non-response rate. They recruited students through a simple random sampling technique using a lottery method. The final sample consisted of 503 participants, with a 100% response rate. The participants had a mean age of 22.17 years old, with 43.3% between ages 18 and 21. Participants were 72% men, 93.8% single, 57.5% from rural residences, and 36.8% third-year students. Of the participants in the sample, 2.6% reported a history of mental illness, 16.7% reported a chronic physical illness, and 3.2% reported a family history of mental illness. Regarding social support, 41.4% of participants reported poor social support, 43.3.% reported moderate social support, and 15.3% reported strong social support. In relation to substance use, 43.7% of participants reported drinking alcohol and 11.1% reported taking a stimulant called khat (Desalegn et al., 2019). Data were collected through a self-administered questionnaire which assessed sociodemographic factors, social support, clinical factors, and substance use. The authors assessed the level of social support using the Oslo 3-item Social Support Scale (OSSS-3; Dalgard & Brevik, 1996), which consists of three items that measure social functioning, including the number of people the participant feels close to, the amount of interest and concern others show 28   the participant, and the ease in which the participant can obtain practical help from others. Total scores range from 3 to 14 and are categorized as poor support (3 to 8), moderate support (9 to 11), and strong support (12 to 14). The SPIN, which was previously discussed, was used to assess social phobia/social anxiety in this study (Desalegn et al., 2019). The authors used a univariate analysis to test associations between the independent variables and the dependent variable. Then, independent variables with P-values less than 0.2 were entered into the multivariate logistic regression model to identify the effects of the independent variables on the dependent variable (Desalegn et al., 2019). The researchers found a prevalence of social phobia symptoms of 31.2% based on responses to the SPIN, with 16.7% mild, 9.3% moderate, 3.8% severe, and 1.39% very severe. Factors that were significantly associated with social phobia were being female, a first-year student, from rural areas, and having poor support. They found that women were 2.3 times more likely to have social phobia than their peers. First-year students were 5.5 times more likely to have social phobia than students in other years. Students who lived in rural areas were 1.6 times more likely to develop social phobia than students from urban areas. Compared to students with good social support, students with poor social support were 2.8 times more likely to have social phobia (Desalegn et al., 2019). Some limitations of this study are that it was cross-sectional and, therefore, could not determine conclusions about causality regarding social anxiety and the related factors they explored. Due to the study design, one cannot conclude that these correlated factors can explain the cause of social phobia, but they are significantly associated with it and may be important risk factors to consider for social phobia. Additionally, with most cross-sectional studies, there were concerns about the differences between participants who responded and those who did not, but in 29   this study, there was a 100% response rate which would ideally mean that the sample was representative of the population and there would be limited response bias. The authors indicated that the sample consisted of a small number of students, which could impact generalizability, especially as the sample was from one college at the university and primarily men. Therefore, the results may not be as generalizable to the broader university population, young adult population of Ethiopia, or college and university overall. Despite generalizability concerns, the researchers did find a similar prevalence rate to other studies with college students in different countries. The authors indicated that their result was consistent with the estimated prevalence found in studies in other countries. The SPIN has not been validated in Ethiopia but has been widely used and validated in other countries with adolescents and adults. There could be a question of whether the SPIN was measuring the intended construct for this population, though its use in many countries may indicate that it is a reliable measure across cultures. It is unclear how the authors chose the cutoff scores for their population without previous validation studies. While there are general cutoff scores per the SPIN manual and instructions, at times, the best cutoff score to determine potential social anxiety varies by population and could be important to assess (per SPIN manual; Connor et al., 2000; Davidson, 2021). Like other assessments, the SPIN does not directly equate to a diagnosis of social phobia or SAD, so discretion should be used in interpreting findings. Relating to concerns about the constructs being measured, it should be considered whether using social phobia criteria and SPIN is measuring SAD in terms of current criteria established in the DSM-IV, as these could be reflecting information on different constructs related to social anxiety. A small note is that the authors did not cite the measures or abbreviate them correctly, which may be stylistic or possibly related to translation if that occurred especially being from another 30   country, but this may be an issue when it comes to standardization of research. For example, if someone is looking for studies using the SPIN, this study may be missed as it referenced the SPI. One study examined the prevalence and severity of social anxiety among medical students in Ukraine (Pshyk et al., 2019). They investigated the prevalence of social anxiety among university students with the purpose of developing and implementing a group format program to treat social anxiety. The sample consisted of 120 medical students in years 3 through 6 of medical school at National Pirogov Memorial Medical University. The participants had an average age of 20.4 years old, with 70 men and 50 women (Pshyk et al., 2019). The authors utilized the SPIN and the LSAS, which were previously discussed, and the  Social Performance Rating Scale (SPRS; Wells, 1997). As described by Nordahl and Wells (2018), the SPRS (social phobia) consists of five rating scales that assess distress, avoidance, self-consciousness, safety behavior use, and negative beliefs. Each scale appears to have a differing number of items and rating scale; it is unclear if there are standard ranges for rating the items, as their description demonstrated a wide variation in range based on the scale. As this study did not report any data or how they used this scale, it did not seem relevant to explore this measure further since how it was used or any results from it could not be determined (Pshyk et al., 2019). The authors relayed that they used the SPIN to screen the participants and reported a 31.7% prevalence of participants (38 students) in their sample with varying degrees of social anxiety. They indicated participants fell into the following categories of 12.5% (15 students) mild, 10% (12 students) moderate, and 9.2% (11 students) severe social anxiety, with seemingly no “very severe” endorsements (Pshyk et al., 2019). 31   The major focus of the study was describing and reviewing the group treatment they were testing. Students who screened with symptoms of social anxiety were given a consult that identified features of social anxiety such as isolation, comorbidities, and impact on quality of life. Then, students were offered placement in a group format to work on social anxiety. The treatment was a closed psychotherapeutic group with 17 members from the sample who were primarily diagnosed with moderate to severe social anxiety. The article is not explicit in how these 17 were chosen from the 38 participants who endorsed symptoms of social anxiety after the initial screening. It is reported that they used the SPIN and LSAS for more detail on each participant in the group; however, this is not elaborated on. After the treatment group was completed, the SPIN was administered again to participants in the group treatment to compare pre- and post-treatment social anxiety levels. The authors did not report statistical analyses of these results but indicated that there was a decrease in general social anxiety scores for all members of the group (Pshyk et al., 2019). It was very difficult to assess the quality of this research and the results of this study due to so little information being included in the final article to allow readers to follow along with the process and make conclusions. This primary factor may lead one to conclude that it was not the best quality, though it could be possible that this format was standard for the researchers’ region. The results of this study may have limited generalizability, particularly to the United States or other Western university students, as this study was completed in Ukraine. There was significantly limited demographic data on the study participants, so the generalizability to non-medical students, broader university students in Ukraine, and college students worldwide was difficult to ascertain. There was also no discussion on how the participants were recruited to gain further information about internal and external validity. Therefore, results should be considered 32   with caution. While the prevalence found was within the range found in other studies, it is unknown how representative this sample was of the population of the medical school, the broader university, or the local population, which creates a challenge in understanding the meaning of that percentage (Pshyk et al., 2019). As the study mentioned two other measures to assess social anxiety in addition to the SPIN, it would have been helpful to know how those measures were used and how all the measures compared when examining the results of their participants. The authors indicated that these measures were used to estimate levels of social anxiety, but they did not describe the measures or how they used them in this study, so it is unclear what role they all played. Without a detailed description of the methods used in this study, it is challenging to evaluate some strengths or limitations regarding the prevalence findings and the testing of a treatment intervention. Additionally, results from each of these measures were not clearly reported, though they indicated using a four-point evaluation system to estimate fears and anxiety of participants in, as well as avoidance of, specific social situations and then statistical processing was completed using Microsoft Excel (Pshyk et al., 2019). It seems that the primary focus of the study was the group intervention, but even then, they reported very little about what they did, how they did it, or explicit outcome data. They did not describe any specific statistics that were conducted or demonstrate how they would determine the effectiveness of the program. While they reported SPIN scores from before and after the intervention, they were only shown in graphical form, which visibly showed a change in scores from time one to time two, but it was not clear if these changes were statistically significant. Statistics could have been conducted to demonstrate whether these changes were clinically significant. Without this information, it is unclear if these changes would matter 33   clinically, nor is there a comparison/control group to determine if the changes were any more than anyone might have over a 10-week period. Indicating that this program has shown its effectiveness and can be used in other work or in other universities seems like an overassessment. Regarding the practice of group therapy, the type of group and setting of the group plays a role in how the group is set up. The optimum number of participants for group therapy is 8 to 12 members (Ezhumalai et al., 2018). A group with 17 participants is large, which may impact the group intervention effectiveness. Additionally, the authors discussed training assertiveness skills and developing confident behavior without indicating how those two concepts might be connected. Overall, the steps taken and the direction chosen in the study and intervention were not clearly connected to let the reader understand the theoretical underpinnings of the research, which made it challenging to understand and validate. The authors did choose to elaborate more on some areas than others, such as describing components of theory and steps in the intervention with participants directly, which it appears could allow for some replication of their work but not enough to fully replicate it (Pshyk et al., 2019). Another study examined the prevalence of social anxiety in undergraduate university students at Hawassa University in Ethiopia (Reta et al., 2020). This cross-sectional study was conducted with undergraduate students in the College of Medicine and Health Sciences during April and May 2018. The authors determined the sample size for their study with a single population proportion formula. The authors recruited 304 students, of which 293 completed the questionnaire and were used in the study, a 93.6% response rate. Participants were selected using stratified random sampling, where each department was the stratum and data were independently collected from each department. Samples were proportioned based on the total number of 34   students in each department. For this study, data were collected by trained data collectors and facilitated by supervisors. The authors utilized a nine-item questionnaire to assess student characteristics related to socio-demographics, academics, and clinical information. The final sample of 293 participants had a mean age of 22.13 years, was 58.7% male, 95.6% single, 48.1% Amhara by ethnicity, 63.1% Ethiopian orthodox, 72% below the fourth year of study, and 56.7% medical students. In the total sample, 8.5% of participants reported a previous history of mental illness, and 7.5% reported a family history of mental illness (Reta et al., 2020). To assess social phobia, the researchers used the SPIN, which has been discussed. The authors reported that the SPIN had been previously validated in Nigeria, with 82.2% sensitivity and 77.6% specificity. The researchers assessed social support using the Oslo Social Support Scale (OSSS-3), which was discussed previously. The authors reported that previous research found acceptable validity and reliability of the OSSS-3 with the African population, indicating that it was appropriate for use with their population (Reta et al., 2020). In this study, the authors performed a binary logistic regression to examine any association between each independent variable and the dependent variable. Any variables that had statistical significance when the p-value was less than or equal to 0.25 were further examined in multiple logistic regressions to identify any independent effects. They performed multiple logistic regression analysis to determine if any factors were associated with social anxiety (Reta et al., 2020). The results indicated a 32.8% prevalence rate for SAD among the participants. They also reported social support among participants categorized as 24.2% excellent, 31.4% very good, 29.4% good, and 15% poor social support. They found factors that were significantly associated with SAD to be a family history of mental illness and being a third- or fourth-year student. Those 35   with a family history of mental illness were 4.7 times more likely to develop SAD than those without a family history. Being a third- or fourth-year student significantly predicted social phobia (Reta et al., 2020). The authors shared some cultural background information that in Ethiopia shyness is emphasized as a dominant cultural norm due to being seen as a measure of politeness (Reta et al., 2020). While shyness is not equivalent to SAD, it would be interesting if the social-cultural norms of emphasizing shyness/politeness led to an increased prevalence or experience of what is considered anxiety in other cultures. It would seem important to then differentiate between a cultural concept and a diagnostic disorder. In this study, the researchers found that being a third- or fourth-year student significantly predicted social phobia but reported that compared to fifth-year students these students were less likely to develop SAD. This is confusing because they did not find a significant correlation between being a fifth-year student and social anxiety. Additionally, they acknowledged that this was the opposite of what three other studies have found, including one that was also in Ethiopia and found a similar prevalence rate to theirs. This might bring some question about the statistics that were performed and their interpretations. They collected demographic information, but they did not include much explanation around many of the demographics they collected or the results of them. The demographic data may have been collected to examine the representativeness of their sample and not as specific study points or for comparison. They examined “previous resident area” and it could be important to compare urban and rural students, as this could be a significant factor to consider particularly for undergraduate students who are adjusting to university (Reta et al., 2020). 36   Some limitations of this study include the cross-sectional design, which does not allow causation to be inferred from the correlations found. It seems that the authors attempted to acknowledge this limitation; however, they may have unintentionally written that the design type “does not allow the correlation to be inferred” (Reta et al., 2020, p. 575) when they indeed did find correlations. While noting this, some of the phrasing that they used implies causation in stating that the factors with significant associations played a role in the “development” of SAD when causation cannot possibly be known due to the study design. This is problematic when considering that some of their findings were not wholly similar to previous findings, aside from the prevalence rate. Additionally, they noted that the SPIN was not validated in Ethiopia, which could lead to some error, though they reported validation in other African countries. The assumption of validity in other African countries applying to the country of the current study could make sense as it has been demonstrated to work with people from cultures that are more similar to theirs than if that validity had not already been demonstrated. The authors shared that as a nondiagnostic self-rating screening tool, the SPIN might overestimate the prevalence of SAD, though they noted it has high validity and reliability in many countries (Reta et al., 2020). Some research that was explored was completed on specific phobias, which was appropriate to include as it is anxiety related and social anxiety adjacent. Some of the experiences that may be captured in specific phobias are directly related to experiences of SAD. Seim and Spates (2010) completed a study examining specific phobias in college students. The purpose of this study was to assess the prevalence of phobias and fears among college students, determine which phobias and fears are more likely to co-occur, and establish how many of these students would be interested in treatment. They completed an epidemiological study that surveyed 813 college students from a large Midwest university. They reported that less than 1% 37   of students refused to participate fully in the study. The sample of students were between 18 and 47 years old, with a mean age of 19. The sample consisted of 58% female, 42% male, 87% non-Hispanic Caucasian, 6% African American, 3% Asian or Pacific Islander, 3% Latino, and 0.1% Native American (Seim & Spates, 2010). Classes were surveyed during the first 10 minutes, where the survey was introduced, informed consent was provided, and then a questionnaire was administered. The questionnaire consisted of 12 different fears found to be common in community samples. Participants rated how much they experienced each fear on a five-point Likert scale from zero (no fear) to four (severe fear), and then they responded to a question asking if they were interested in receiving treatment for these fears, and, if so, how many sessions they would attend in treatment. They were also asked if they would only attend treatment for extra class credit, which was used as a validity measure for students who were not interested in personal benefits. There was also space at the end of the questionnaire for students to write about other fears or phobias they experienced and would be interested in treatment for (Seim & Spates, 2010). This study found that 31% of the participants feared public speaking, with 11% reporting a severe fear, and 5% of the participants feared meeting new people, with 1% reporting a severe fear, both of which can be aspects of social anxiety. Particularly interesting is the comorbidities found in which 12% of participants who reported significant or severe fear of public speaking reported a fear of meeting new people, and 70% of participants who reported a significant or severe fear of meeting new people reported a fear of public speaking. Of those who reported significant and severe fear of public speaking and meeting new people, 20% and 28%, respectively, indicated an interest in receiving treatment (Seim & Spates, 2010). 38   While this study was not directly investigating social anxiety, the results showed that many students were impacted by fears that could impair their college experience. Some of these fears overlapped with the experience of social anxiety, which highlights the importance of looking more closely at social anxiety and the impact it can have on the college experience. Some limitations of this study include that a small number of fears and phobias were assessed, which left out many common fears such as thunderstorms, flying, and crossing bridges. However, this was intentional, as they were only examining fears that would be most likely to interfere with a student’s college experience and fears that could be easily treated in the university setting. The authors did acknowledge that a formal assessment of a wider range of fears relevant to this population would be useful, such as sexual assault and failing school. The inclusion of more common fears and social fears may have been helpful in capturing a broader picture of the student experience, particularly around things that are present in their daily lives and could impact or impair daily functioning, including academic success. For example, some of the write-ins are very common phobias one could expect to be assessed, like clowns. Additionally, this study did not fully assess the criteria for formal diagnosis, so the use of self-identified fear and severity only approximated the prevalence of fears or phobias on campus. While they did assess the prevalence of these fears, they were not clinically assessed, and the degree to which these were clinical fears in that they interfere with the functioning of these students is unknown as it was self-reported. The generalizability of this study may be limited, as there may have been bias in the sample. It was not stated if or how the sample was chosen and whether the researchers utilized random selection, such as which classes were assessed and how they chose those classes, nor how representative the sample was of the population at the university or geographic area. While there were limited demographics of the sample, participants 39   were primarily White, which may be representative of a Midwest university, but this may miss or misrepresent fears or phobias that different groups of students may experience. It seems that more research with broader, more representative samples across different universities and geographic areas would be needed to conclude that specific fears are “quite prevalent on college campuses” (Seim & Spates, 2010, p. 54), though this is likely a good place to start in exploring that research. In examining the previously explored studies on social anxiety and social phobia among college students, one can see that social anxiety and the impact it has on students’ success in college is of concern and becoming notably important.
