With that said, there is significant variety in the results being found and the quality of the research being completed. For example, just in reviewing these studies, it can be inferred that the prevalence of social anxiety among college students is between 8.5% (Bella & Omigbodun, 2009) and 80% (Ahmad et al., 2017). This is a dramatically wide range of possibility, even accounting for differences between geographic locations, schools, countries, majors, and assessment measures used. This range indicates that there are likely significant inconsistencies in the study of social anxiety, despite the significant impact it is believed to have on individuals. The prevalence rates found in research thus far include 8.5% for 12 months and 9.4% lifetime (Bella & Omigbodun, 2009), 9.9% “marked” to “very severe” and 16.4% if moderate scores are included (Russell & Shaw, 2009), 16.1% (Tillfors & Furmark, 2007), 22% (Strahan, 2003), 19% and 33% (as cited by Strahan, 2003) in additional research, 31.2% (Desalegn et al., 2019), 31.7% (Pshyk et al., 2019), 32.8% (Reta et al., 2020), 48.1% (Kuder & Grover, 2014), and 80% (Ahmad et al., 2017). There are many reasons why the prevalence rates may vary, though the majority of studies falling between 16.4% and 32.8% may point us toward a narrower range of prevalence for university students. 40   Overall, the research appears to be of moderate quality, and though there are some common concerns among most studies, there are only three studies that are of questionable quality and should be considered with caution, Desalegn et al. (2019), Pshyk et al. (2019), and Reta et al. (2020). Overall, the main challenge across these studies is generalizability to a larger population, which is a general concern across all research as the sample population available will always have limits and varying methods for completing the research studies. Regarding generalizability, some studies seemed to take care and consideration for selecting their populations, while in others, it seems they did their best to randomly select participants and many used convenience sampling, as is common in university research. Some studies are rather small, particularly those examining prevalence, or are very limited in population representation, for example, when they only include certain majors, making generalizability to a larger university population very difficult. Randomization of sampling should be more commonplace, especially for the broader university population, though maybe it is not always realistic. This is especially a concern when examining smaller subsets of the population, such as minority students and those with intersectional and marginalized identities, as their experiences may differ in significant ways. In some studies, opportunistic samples lead to disproportionate numbers of certain sub-populations/demographics and ultimately unrepresentative samples. Many of the samples were homogenous, which often may have been representative of the population at the university, especially in international studies, but which can certainly create a challenge when attempting to compare populations across research since there may be cultural factors at play that create a difference. For example, as was mentioned in one study, in Ethiopia, shyness is emphasized as a dominant cultural norm due to being seen as a measure of politeness (Reta et al., 2020). While one cannot equate shyness with SAD fully, it would be useful to determine whether 41   social norms increased that anxious experience for people or contributed to differences found across populations. Additionally, there is always a chance for response bias and the students who did participate in the research having certain unique qualities and characteristics, which could be assuaged with more broad and inclusive random sampling. This relates again to studies examining specific populations and convenience samples, which are at least a good place to start but something future research may benefit from controlling for more. Underestimates of prevalence are possible when the impairment or experience of non-respondents who declined to participate in studies is unknown, which some authors posited could be a result of social anxiety itself, among other factors. At times, the demographics collected are limited, which limits the factors that can be compared or examined but also makes it difficult to know the population being discussed and how the sample compares to the broader population. For example, across these studies, there is some variation in mean age and year that the students were in, which could impact the results, especially as some studies have indicated that the prevalence of social anxiety varied by year and, in some cases, there were opposing results on what those trends look like. Overall, it would seem helpful that once general research is established, subsequent research could look more specifically at the breakdowns and differences in prevalence and the impact of social anxiety on different years in school.  In some instances, the primary purpose of the study was not to determine prevalence, and as there are studies dedicated to doing that, it may be important to assess whether these studies are sufficiently assessing prevalence and if the results from these studies are an accurate view of the prevalence. Additionally, at times some studies used a dataset that was part of a larger study, and it was unclear if their studies were a part of the original plans for research or if 42   they were able to ask these questions after the fact simply due to the data collected, which could pose some concerns around the population and sample used if it limited the data that were used or there were inherently some different characteristics of that sample due to the larger sample they were taken from. There was also variation in the type of study conducted and the limits of different types of studies regarding utility. For example, many studies utilized cross-sectional approaches where correlations could be found, but they were unable to speak to the causality of related factors. This may not be as pertinent for prevalence rates, but prevalence was often not the main focus of many studies. Some studies attempted to posit that correlated factors might be able to explain social anxiety, but the research is not sufficient to support that. Differing methods may also relate to the variation among response rates reported in different studies. There is some concern for two-part studies, where only students who screened for social anxiety were included in the second portion. This may limit some of the data collected, especially when timelines vary. For example, if some studies assess for symptoms or information in the last year and others in the last five years or last six months, the rates may vary significantly, especially if researchers are only asking those who screened positive in that set time range for historical or lifetime occurrence, as others with lifetime occurrence may have already been excluded. Across these various studies, there was variation in the methods used to collect data, including surveys sent to homes, interviews conducted in dorms, surveys completed in classrooms, and assessments and observations in labs. This variation could impact the results found, especially those completed in spaces that may not be the most confidential. What may be even more challenging than the variation of methods used is that, at times, there is little description or elaboration on the methods. In some studies, it is unclear how some key aspects of the research were completed, such as how the sample was recruited, the specific 43   steps taken in the study, how data were analyzed, or whether all the data that were collected or analyzed were not reported in the article. This could lead to significant challenges in replicating studies in the future, but also in being able to interpret and determine how viable and clinically useful the findings are. This becomes even more of a concern when there is sometimes uncertainty about the statistics or analyses performed and the interpretations made from them, especially if it seemed there was a misunderstanding in the article itself. Having all the methods and data available would allow consumers to see what the authors were seeing and how they came to their conclusions. Furthermore, when there are opposing findings, which do not seem abnormal, it can allow for a better understanding of where those differences arise and what they mean. Often self-reporting surveys were used, which is very common in research, and many of the measures have established reliability and validity. However, one concern that this may raise, particularly with a socially anxious population, is whether results may be affected by social desirability and whether this could have led to underreporting of symptoms, minimization of problems, or increased competence levels. An additional challenge with self-report measures is that they may limit the accuracy of the diagnostic tools or data collected, as participants may demonstrate bias by inaccurately assessing themselves, misunderstanding or misinterpreting the questions, or having a tendency for neutral or extreme response ratings. Another concern is that translations or altering of measures within the study could impact the measure’s validity and reliability, especially in studies where the researchers do not indicate the steps they took, if any, to test the instruments or alterations before using them in their study. Additionally, at times some measures were not yet validated in the country where the study took place, which could pose some concerns for the accuracy of the assessment, even if the population 44   and culture may be similar to others who have used the measure. A benefit of this is that it seems some measures are demonstrating reliability across cultures, which could be very useful in future research as it could address some concerns around the construct being studied and the validity of results from different studies. The most notable and significant concern observed across these studies is how social anxiety or social phobia was measured. Few of the studies base the assessment of social anxiety or social phobia on diagnostic criteria, so there could be some question about whether they were assessing clinical social anxiety or sub-clinical experiences of social anxiety. Another question to consider is whether each of these studies, and the body of research at large, is examining, talking about, or researching the same construct of social anxiety. This is particularly significant because, across studies, there is variation in what instruments are used to assess social anxiety. There is the possibility that some of these instruments may be measuring different constructs or different aspects of the construct that may not equate to the same thing. This could be a contributing factor to the vast range of prevalence rates observed. In turn, this leaves the question: How can the prevalence rates of each of the studies be compared if they use different methods to assess SAD and, therefore, could be assessing different constructs? An additional challenge related to the variation in instruments is the varying use of language. All the studies reviewed are from 2003 or later, which is nine years after the release of the DSM-IV and the change from social phobia to SAD; however, over half of the studies referred to social phobia, interchanged social anxiety and social phobia, or used measures that assess social phobia. It is unclear why they used the term social phobia instead of SAD. Recurrent use of social phobia terminology versus social anxiety raises the concern of whether they were examining the same thing and whether these measures are still representative of what 45   they are trying to assess, especially if the measures were made to assess or are using social phobia criteria, which was a narrower definition and more limited criteria than SAD in DSM-IV and, subsequently, DSM-5. This gives cause for concern or at least consideration in ensuring that the constructs being measured, instruments used for measurement, and the overall literature pertaining to social anxiety are indeed talking about the same concept. SAD in the LGB Population Continuing the investigation into the prevalence of social anxiety among LGB college students, the prevalence of social anxiety among the LGB population in general has also been examined. Research into the prevalence of SAD among the LGB population has improved over time, with an increased interest in examining LGB mental health overall in the last two decades, as it became apparent that this population may be at an increased risk for mental health disorders compared to their heterosexual counterparts. Some factors may contribute to this increased risk for the development of mental health concerns, including minority stress, social stress, prejudice and discrimination, and difficulties with identity and development. These factors and their potential impact on the individual highlight the importance of understanding the role of social anxiety and its impact on LGB individuals’ development and social functioning. Understanding that LGB adolescents and adults have an increased risk for psychosocial concerns in general (Kirsch et al., 2015), it is important to understand the role that SAD also plays in the experiences of LGB individuals, especially considering how important community and social support is for LGB individuals who may face challenges when it comes to acceptance from their peers and family. For example, nonheterosexual individuals reported fewer social supports, less satisfaction with social supports, and fewer positive events than their heterosexual peers (Safren & Pantalone, 2006), and it has been found that they may have more negative 46   thoughts surrounding social situations than their heterosexual peers (as cited in Wadsworth & Hayes-Skelton, 2015). Several studies have suggested that social anxiety is higher among the LGBTQ population (both youth and adults) than among their heterosexual peers (Bostwick et al., 2010; Pachankis & Goldfried, 2006; Safren & Pantalone, 2006; Sandfort et al., 2001). Sandfort et al. (2001) completed a study examining the differences in the prevalence of mental health disorders between heterosexual and sexual minority individuals. They compared the prevalence of mood, anxiety, and substance use disorders among heterosexual and sexual minority individuals in the Netherlands to assess the relationship between sexual orientation and mental health. Their data came from the Netherlands Mental Health Survey and Incidence Study (NEMESIS; Bijl et al., 1998), which used a representative sample of the Dutch population aged 18 to 64 to assess for psychiatric disorders. The survey used a multistage, stratified, random sampling procedure to recruit households in the Netherlands in which one respondent per household was randomly selected for participation in the study. In total, 7,076 people were interviewed, with a 69.7% response rate of the eligible respondents. Face-to-face interviews using the CIDI (Andrews & Peters, 1998) were used to determine DSM-III-R diagnoses by trained, non-clinician interviewers. The authors reported that the CIDI has acceptable reliability and validity for nearly all diagnoses except acute psychosis. The diagnoses of participants were determined through data processing. Respondents were assessed for psychiatric disorders prior to assessment of their sexual behavior to minimize chances of contamination. Sexual behavior was verbally assessed by asking respondents if they had sexual contact in the preceding year. They were also asked the gender of their partners and respondents were categorized as “homosexual” if they had sex with someone of the same gender, whether it was exclusively same sex or not. The interviewers did not assess sexual orientation (Sandfort et al., 2001). 47   Of the total sample, 30 respondents did not report their sexual behavior, 1,043 participants were not sexually active, and 5 additional respondents lacked the data to categorize them as heterosexual or “homosexual.” This left 5,998 respondents for the current study, 84.8% of the initial sample that could be classified. Participants classified as “homosexual” included 2.8% (82) men and 1.4% (43) women who had sex with same-sex partners. Six of these men and six of these women categorized as “homosexual” also had sex with opposite-sex individuals (Sandfort et al., 2001). The researchers found a higher 12-month and lifetime prevalence of mood and anxiety disorders among sexual minority men compared to heterosexual men and a higher 12-month and lifetime prevalence of substance use disorders among sexual minority women compared to heterosexual women. They also found a higher lifetime prevalence of general mood disorders and major depression among sexual minority women compared to heterosexual women. The 12-month prevalence of social phobia was 3% for heterosexual men, 7.3% for sexual minority men, 5.8% for heterosexual women, and 7.0% for sexual minority women. The lifetime prevalence of social phobia was 5.5% for heterosexual men, 14.6% for sexual minority men, 9.5% for heterosexual women, and 18.6% for sexual minority women (Sandfort et al., 2001). Strengths of this study include that they used a large representative sample, that participants were selected without reference to sexual orientation, they did not use a convenience sample, the large number of participants allowed for separate analyses for men and women, and they utilized a reliable and standardized diagnostic instrument. However, some challenges related to these factors included that selecting participants without reference to sexual orientation may have led to a smaller number of sexual minority participants; they indicated that a limited number of sexual minority participants could have contributed to underestimated differences 48   between groups. Additionally, they seem to have conflated gender and sex at times, assessing the participants’ gender (man or woman), but defining sexuality in terms of sex (male or female), which also excludes other nonheterosexual or nonbinary identities (Sandfort et al., 2001). While the researchers utilized the CIDI, which has reportedly good validity and reliability, the diagnoses were based on DSM-III-R, published in 1987. The DSM-IV was published in 1994, and WHO published its psychiatric assessment instruments book in 1995, detailing that the CIDI version 2.0 assesses diagnoses using the ICD-10 and DSM-IV criteria. The authors did not address using the older version, though perhaps the new version was not as accessible yet in 1996. They may have used this version of the diagnostic criteria because the assessment was well-validated. Using outdated diagnostic materials may lead to inaccurate assessment due to changes in norms and disorder criteria. Further limitations of this study include the generalizability of the results outside of the Netherlands or to minority populations within the Netherlands. The authors indicated that they may have found lower mental health rates than other Western countries potentially would find due to a more tolerant climate toward “homosexuality” in the Netherlands. They hypothesized that some differences could be because “homosexual men might have been less reluctant to admit specific complaints” (Sandfort et al., 2001, p. 89), though this seems in opposition to the idea that differences may have been underestimated due to the limited number of sexual minority participants. Despite the authors controlling for some demographic variables, there is the possibility that other confounding variables, which were not controlled for, contributed to the observed differences found. The original study used a cross-sectional design, which does not allow for assessment of cause of the observed differences. 49   A significant critique of this study is that they used sexual behavior to define sexuality, which does not necessarily equate to someone’s sexual orientation or identity. The researchers perceived the use of recent sexual behavior as a strength of their study and indicated that they believed it was a better indicator of “homosexual self-labeling” (Sandfort et al., 2001, p. 89) than lifetime sexual behavior despite the results of numerous studies (Bajos et al., 1998; Doll et al., 1992; Laumann et al., 1994) that they cited, which indicate that there are discrepancies between “homosexual behavior” and sexual orientation or labels. While the researchers cited many resources for statements made throughout the paper, they simply stated although there were discrepancies, they thought it was a better indicator without any research to support this. Additionally, they believed this in part contributed to being able to more precisely look examine relationship between same-sex attraction and mental health, but some could argue that they were not wholly examining sexual minority orientation, more so just a part of it. There has been research (Savin-Williams & Cohen, 2015) examining the importance of identity in relation to mental health and development, yet those who sleep with members of the same sex or gender do not all identify as a sexual minority. Therefore, they may have been including people in the sample who did not hold a sexual minority identity and did not have the same experiences as people who do. Additionally, it is not clear if the researchers asked about the circumstances in which the sexual behaviors occurred. It is possible that some people had same-sex sexual encounters with multiple partners, which may certainly not reflect on their identity. Furthermore, by excluding lifetime partners or sexual behaviors and only examining partners and behaviors within the last year, it is likely that the researchers may have excluded many people who could have added to each group or that they miscategorized people who did hold a sexual minority identity that was 50   not depicted by recent sexual behaviors. For example, bisexual individuals who have only engaged with opposite-sex partners over the last year would be incorrectly categorized as heterosexual despite past behavior, relationships, or self-labeled identity. There are many people with sexual minority identities who have not or will not ever engage in same-sex sex sexual activity. The researchers could also be excluding people who had not been able to explore their sexuality through sexual behavior, which could be limited by lack of partnership or even mental health. The authors noted the role of current distress and relationship status on overall mental health, as well as potential challenges facing sexual minority individuals regarding making intimate connections, which could be all the more reason to utilize self-identified orientation labels. This could lead to missing a significant portion of an already small population and adds to erasure of bisexuality as a sexual minority identity, especially as people who engaged in sexual behaviors with members of same and opposite-sex were categorized as “homosexual only.” An irony of that categorization is that the authors claimed in other studies people were grouped together based on lifetime experiences to make up for small numbers and it was a positive thing that they did not do that. However, they did decide to aggregate people, disregarding their life experiences and not asking about how they identified and effectively erasing any identity outside of homosexual or heterosexual. It also seems incongruent not to assess sexual behavior beyond a year when mental health was assessed for 12-month and lifetime prevalence (Sandfort et al., 2001). One study by Gilman et al. (2001) examined the risk of psychiatric disorders among individuals engaging in same-sex sexual behavior. This study used data from the National Comorbidity Study (NCS; Kessler et al., 1994), which collects survey information from a nationally representative household sample of people between the ages of 15 and 54 years old in 51   the United States. The NCS interviews took place in two parts from 1990 through 1992, with a response rate of 82.4%. In the first part of the study, participants were assessed for DSM-III-R psychiatric disorders using a modified version of the CIDI structured interview, which has been previously discussed. Participants moved on to part two of the study if they screened positively for a lifetime psychiatric disorder. In addition, a random sample of other respondents were also given the second part of the interview. In part two, the questions assessing sexual activity were also included. All participants were asked the number of women that they had sexual intercourse with in the preceding five years and in a separate question they were asked the number of men that they had sexual intercourse with in the preceding five years. Based on responses to these two questions, participants were identified as homosexually active, exclusively heterosexually active, or not sexually active. Those who were not sexually active were not included in the analyses. Of the remaining sample, 125 participants (1.8%) reported having any same-sex sexual partners, of which 74 were men and 51 were women. Within the same-sex subsample, 77 participants (41 men and 36 women) reported having both same-sex and opposite-sex partners, and 48 participants (33 men and 15 women) reported having exclusively same-sex partners. The exclusively opposite-sex sexual partners subsample consisted of 4,785 participants (2,310 men and 2,475 women) and the subsample of participants who reported no sexual partners included 967 participants (439 men and 528 women; Gilman et al., 2001). The authors utilized simple cross-tabulations to assess the differences in the 12-month prevalence of DSM-III-R disorders between the same-sex partnered and opposite-sex partnered subsamples. They used discrete time-survival analysis based on retrospective age-at-onset reports to estimate the relationships of lifetime risk and age of onset variables with those who had same-sex partners versus those who had opposite-sex partners. Then, the authors used 52   logistic regression to estimate the association between 12-month persistence of disorders for those who had same-sex partners versus those who has opposite-sex partners. In all of the analyses, the authors reported that they controlled for sociodemographic variables and made separate estimates for men and women (Gilman et al., 2001). The 12-month prevalence of social phobia was 8.8% for same-sex partnered men, 6.3% for opposite-sex partnered men, 10.4% for same-sex partnered women, and 9.1% for opposite-sex partnered women. The researchers did not find any statistically significant differences between the subsamples regarding age, education, income, or race/ethnicity. There were some differences in prevalence of psychiatric disorders between the subsamples, but most were not statistically significant. For example, same-sex partnered women had a higher prevalence of 11 of the 12 disorders assessed than opposite-sex partnered women, but only major depression, simple phobia, and PTSD were statistically different. The difference in social anxiety was not statistically significant. Additionally, while same-sex partnered men appeared more likely to have any anxiety, mood, or substance use disorder than opposite-sex partnered men, there was no higher prevalence of any specific psychiatric disorders for same-sex partnered men. Also, same-sex partnered women had a higher prevalence of suicidal thoughts and plans, while same-sex partnered men had a higher prevalence of suicidal plans and attempts than their opposite-sex counterparts, although this finding was not statistically significant (Gilman et al., 2001). Some limitations of this study included potential limits on generalizability or representativeness due to the data being collected from 1990 to 1992, almost 10 years old by the time of the study and may not have been as representative of the population at that time, especially with the strides and setbacks in the progress of LGBTQ rights within society. Additionally, they excluded people who were not sexually active within five years before the 53   study, which could potentially exclude participants with certain characteristics, such as self-identified sexual orientation regardless of sexual behaviors or potentially people not engaging in sexual behaviors for reasons such as mental health concerns. The decision to collect the sexual activity data in the second part of the study may have been a limitation of this study. It seems that it could have been helpful to collect that demographic information in the initial phase, which could have allowed that sample to be larger. It also could have allowed for matching between those who screened positive for a lifetime disorder and those who did not, particularly with the potential for comparison between more individuals who engaged in same-sex behaviors. The same-sex partners subsample was a relatively small population and number of respondents compared to the overall sample size; while this was representative of the general population, it is likely that there was lower power because of the small number in the subsample. The smaller number of same-sex partnered participants also may have limited the opportunity for analysis of multiple subgroups within that sample, which may be why there was no distinguishment between participants with only same-sex partners and those with both same- and opposite-sex partners. This combining of individuals who only engaged in sexual behaviors with same-sex partners and individuals who engaged in sexual behaviors with both same-sex and opposite-sex partners likely conflates or misses characteristics unique to the differences and experiences of each of those populations, which could have an impact on the results found. Much like the previous study (Sandfort et al., 2001), this one used behaviorally defined versus identity defined sexual orientation. The authors noted that with using this definition they could not assess whether sexual identity played a role as a risk or protective factor, which they considered an important limitation because in relation to mental health sexual identity might be just as or more important than sexual behavior. 54   Additionally, some people who identify as homosexual or bisexual do not engage in sexual behaviors with people of the same-sex, while some people who do engage in sexual behaviors with people of the same-sex do not identify as homosexual or bisexual. This demonstrates that how sexual orientation is defined in a study impacts the demographics of and participants who are included in each subgroup of that study. The authors also indicated that there is variation in the acts used to define same-sex sexual behavior across studies, which also leads to measurement errors. The researchers chose to use the term intercourse. They acknowledged that with use of this word some participants with same-sex partners who did not engage in this behavior may have been excluded, relating to how the behavior is defined, as well as the uncertainty of how female same-sex respondents may have interpreted the item. Language must be considered when working with sexual minority individuals, especially when the language could have differing connotations than intended, be othering, or interpreted as heterocentric or heteronormative. These concerns around language have arisen around common assessments used for social anxiety as well (Weiss et al., 2013). Marital status, or heterosexual marriage rate, was assessed and was low among people who had same-sex partners compared to those with opposite-sex partners, while the cohabitation rate was higher among people who had same-sex partners. It is unclear what the purpose of including this variable was, particularly because same-sex marriage was not legal yet and domestic partnership or any comparable rights for same-sex couples was significantly limited at this time. So, it would make logical sense that the marriage rates would be lower among some of this subsample and that cohabitation rates would be higher (Gilman et al., 2001). A study by Wang et al. (2007) assessed the prevalence of SAD among gay men. This study, the Geneva Gay Men’s Health Survey, examined the 12-month prevalence of common 55   psychiatric disorders among gay men in Switzerland. They used a sampling method developed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention called time-space sampling in this cross-sectional venue-based probably survey. The authors used randomly selected venues or meeting points frequented by gay men in Geneva, then used randomly selected time slots, and randomly selected participants at each venue. Ultimately, recruitment occurred at 35 different meeting points including gay organization events, bars, cafes, discos, parties, sex clubs, saunas, parks, toilets, and internet chat rooms. This study recruited 1,153 eligible men who either identified as gay or as men who have sex with men. They advertised the study as a general health survey of gay men and participants were given a unique code to complete the first part of the questionnaire. If they were at a physical venue, they were asked to complete it on a laptop onsite, and if online they were asked to complete it at their leisure. The survey consisted of 550 questions assessing sociodemographic variables, mental and physical health, substance use, and stressors (Wang et al., 2007). The authors assessed the 12-month prevalence of major depression, specific phobia, social phobia, alcohol dependence, and drug dependence using the CIDI Short-Form (CIDI-SF; Kessler et al., 1998). They used questions from the Swiss Health Survey to assess self-reported history of depression and anxiety. They also used a general question from the Canadian Community Health Survey about mental health consultation with any health professional. Additionally, they used questions and recommended assessment instruments from the European Health Interview Survey (Buratta et al., 2003; de Bruin et al., 1996) to measure current subjective health and temporary mental disability through limitations in daily activities. They assessed quality of life with the Mental Health Inventory-5 (Buratta et al., 2003) to examine psychological distress and World Health Organization Quality of Life-Brief Version (Buratta et 56   al., 2003) to evaluate global quality of life, physical health, psychological health, social relationships, and environment. To assess nominal and ordinal variables, they used contingency tables and chi-square tests. They used the t-test for continuous variables with normal distribution and they used analysis of variance with the Tukey test to analyze the continuous variable with a dependent variable (Wang et al., 2007). The study had 571 participants (50% response rate). The majority of the sample (83%) was under 44 years old, with 65.8% between the ages of 25 and 44 years old. Overall, the sample consisted of 63.6% of participants with a university education or other professional training, 78.9% with paid employment, 51.3% who lived in a large urban city, 57.4% who lived alone, and 59.9% who were not in a relationship (Wang et al., 2007). The 12-month prevalence rate for social phobia was 13.5% in this study. The researchers found that gay men reported higher prevalence and earlier onset of social phobia and the other psychiatric disordered assessed, as well as higher rates of comorbidity with another disorder, than rates found in heterosexual counterparts in previous studies of the general population. Many of these observations tended to relate with poor prognosis, greater treatment difficulty, and chronicity. Most sociodemographic variables were not significantly associated with a psychiatric disorder in the past 12 months, though there was increased risk for men who lived alone and men who were not in a relationship (Wang et al., 2007). Some limitations of this study included the cross-sectional nature, sampling from targeted locations for the specific population, and limited generalizability. Due to general difficulties sampling small, marginalized groups like the LGBTQ+ population through standard methods, this study used common meeting points where members of the gay male population tended to meet for leisure, socialization, or sex to recruit participants. While they used a sampling 57   procedure that has demonstrated robust coverage of this population in urban areas and should have allowed for fair representativity of this population, it may not be generalizable to gay men who did not engage in sex or go to any of these places. Additionally, this study was limited to participants who identified as gay men or men who had sex with men, and therefore did not generalize to the broader LGB population. The authors allowing the participants to identify themselves as gay and/or men who had sex with men reduced some concerns noted in other studies, though in analysis it does not seem that there was any differentiation between those two identities, which could lead to some of the same concerns around who was in the sample and who the sample was representing when considering sexual orientation identity versus sexual behaviors. The age range in the sample was also limited, though it appeared fairly similar to other prevalence studies that did not have many, if any, participants over age 54. Another challenge with the generalizability of the results is that the differences between the 50% of the recruited sample who agreed to participate compared to the half who did not participate are unknown. There could be particular characteristics of the participants that contributed to the results, leading to higher or lower prevalence rates. The reasons people chose not to participate could be related to factors such as mental health status that may be important barriers to know or address in the larger population (Wang et al., 2007). Meyer et al. (2008) completed a study examining the lifetime prevalence of psychiatric disorders in LGB individuals. They wanted to examine variability among the LGB population, particularly in the subgroups related to gender, race/ethnicity, age, and sexual orientation identity, because general population studies typically only have a few members of these populations and cannot provide information on variability. Participants were directly recruited at 274 venues including bookstores, cafes, social groups, parks, and snowball referrals. The authors 58   reported a response rate of 0.6 and a cooperation rate of 0.8. The authors collected data on sociodemographic data relating to age, sexual orientation, sex, race/ethnicity, education, and socioeconomic status. The final sample consisted of 388 participants who were residents of New York City. Participants ranged in age from 18 to 59 years old, with 44% between 18 and 29 years old, 44% between 20 and 44 years old, and 12% between 45 and 59 years old. Participants self-identified as lesbian, gay (a combined 82%), or bisexual (18%); male (49.7%) or female (50.3%); and White (34%), Black (33%), or Latino (33%; Meyer et al., 2008). To assess DSM-IV psychiatric diagnoses, the authors used the computer-assisted version of the World Health Organization World Mental Health Survey Initiative of the CIDI version 19 (Kessler et al., 2005), which is the updated version of the previously discussed CIDI. The authors calculated unadjusted prevalence and standard error rates, then used logistic regression to find odds ratios and confidence intervals after adjusting for sociodemographic variables. In this study, 22.2% of the total sample reported a lifetime prevalence of social phobia. Of the sample, this included 23.8% of men, 20.5% of women, 21.1% of lesbian or gay individuals, and 27.1% of bisexual individuals (Meyer et al., 2008). While it appears that the authors were able to assess prevalence and variance between the subgroups of the LGB population, there were some limitations to this study and its generalizability. This study used a nonrandom sample and did not report using any methods to assist in randomizing the venues or participants selected for use in the study. The authors reported that they attempted to reduce bias by sampling diverse venues and avoiding venues that would overrepresent individuals with mental health disorders such as clinics and 12-step programs. As they found similar prevalence rates to other studies that did use random sampling, they indicated that this suggests the sample was not significantly unrepresentative of the general 59   LGB population. It is challenging to assess the significance or power of their findings because while they reported some of the demographics and prevalence rates, they did not report all of them, specifically not those divided into smaller subgroups. For example, one of their findings was that “Black lesbians, gay men, and bisexual individuals had lower prevalence of all disorders than Latino and White individuals” (Meyer et al., 2008, p. 1004), but they did not present data for specific subgroups such as Black lesbians, so the data this information come from cannot be examined and assessed or the meaning or significance determined. Additionally, while the main purpose of this study was to examine variability among the LGB population and its subgroups, some of the data they provided were combined. It is limiting that the researchers grouped gay, lesbian, and other individuals with similar identities such as queer, only separating out bisexual individuals, at least in the presented data. Previous studies have demonstrated some differences in the experiences of men and women, and therefore of gay men and lesbian women, so it would seem important that those groups were also considered separately. Related to the previous concern mentioned, it would seem that the authors did indeed consider these groups separately, otherwise mentioning specific groups like Black lesbians would be impossible, but for some reason they did not provide that separated data in the article, which again does not allow readers to assess the data for themselves (Meyer et al., 2008). A study by Bostwick et al. (2010) examined the lifetime prevalence of anxiety and mood disorders among adult men and women in the United States to explore if there were any differences in prevalence across three major dimensions of sexual orientation. The authors analyzed data from the second wave of the 2004-2005 National Epidemiologic Survey on Alcohol and Related Conditions (NESARC; Grant et al., 2004). This was a longitudinal study intending to assess the prevalence of alcohol, drug, and mental health disorders in the 60   noninstitutionalized general population of the United States. In the current study, they analyzed this cross-sectional data to assess lifetime and past-year prevalence of mood and anxiety disorders and the associations with three dimensions of sexual orientation and sex. Reportedly, the data came from a nationally representative sample of civilian adults in the United States who were 20 years of age or older. The original study utilized stratified sampling and clustering of the target population, as well as oversampling Black, Hispanic, and 18- to 24-year-old individuals. They also used sampling weights and adjustment of wave two data based on the 2000 Decennial census to offset inequalities and ensure the sample was representative of the U.S. population. The survey was conducted through face-to-face interviews that were completed in the participants’ homes (Bostwick et al., 2010). A total of 34,653 interviews were conducted with a response rate of 86.7% (Bostwick et al., 2010). Demographics that were assessed and included in the current analyses were sex, age, race, educational level, job status, income, health insurance coverage in the past year, and relationship status. The overall demographics of the sample were 70.9% White, 11% Black, 11.6% Hispanic, 4.3% Asian or Pacific Islander, and 2.2% American Indian; 52.1% female and 47.9% male; 73.1% between the ages of 25 and 64 years old, 58.5% education above high school, 87.7% with some form of health insurance coverage in the past year, 53% working full-time; and 63.8% married or cohabitating (Bostwick et al., 2010). Sexual orientation was assessed through questions asking about sexual identity, sexual behavior, and sexual attraction. Participants were asked to indicate which responses on a preprinted card best described them (sexual identity), their feelings (sexual attraction), and who they have had sex with in their life (sexual behavior). The sexual identities of the sample were 98.1% heterosexual, 0.8% lesbian or gay, 0.6% bisexual, and 0.5% unsure (a total of 1.4% 61   reporting nonheterosexual identity). The reported lifetime sexual behavior of participants was 94.6% only with the opposite-sex partners, 2% with no one, 1.9% with partners of both sexes, and 1.5% with only same-sex partners (a total of 3.4% reporting some same-sex sexual behavior). The sample’s reported sexual attraction was 94.2% only opposite-sex, 3% mostly opposite-sex, 1.4% only same-sex, 1% equally both sexes, and 0.4% mostly same-sex (a total of 5.8% reporting nonheterosexual attraction; Bostwick et al., 2010). The study assessed mood and anxiety disorders with the Alcohol Use Disorder and Associated Disabilities Interview Schedule-IV (AUDADIS-IV; Grant et al., 2004), a structured interview to be used by lay interviewers. The authors reported that reliability and validity had been assessed in previous research. The AUDADIS-IV assesses major depression, dysthymia, mania, hypomania, panic disorder with and without agoraphobia, social phobia, specific phobia, and generalized anxiety. All disorders were assessed for lifetime and past-year occurrence (Bostwick et al., 2010). The authors conducted analyses with a statistical software specifically for use with correlated data in complex sample surveys called SUDAAN. They employed bivariate analysis to find associations for women and men separately, as well as for lifetime and past-year time frames. They then assessed the relationship between the three dimensions of sexual orientation and DSM-IV mood and anxiety disorders using multiple logistic regression analyses to test for associations for women and men separately (Bostwick et al., 2010). Lifetime prevalence of social phobia for women by sexual identity was 9.6% for lesbians, 18.2% for bisexuals, and 13.6% for those unsure. By sexual attraction (in women), lifetime prevalence of social phobia was 6.5% for only female attraction, 12.4% for mostly female attraction, 13.4% for equal attraction, and 11% for mostly male attraction. By sexual behavior (in 62   women), lifetime prevalence of social phobia was 4% with women only, 15.5% with both women and men, and 11.1% with no one. Lifetime prevalence of social phobia for men by sexual identity was 12.4% for gays, 14.2% for bisexuals, and 15.6% for those unsure. By sexual attraction (in men), lifetime prevalence of social phobia was 9.2% for male only attraction, 7% for mostly male attraction, 7.9% for equal attraction, and 9.8% for mostly female attraction. By sexual behavior (in men), lifetime prevalence of social phobia was 6.1% with men only, 13.8% with both women and men, and 11.8% with no one. Past-year prevalence was found to be similar to lifetime prevalence rates. Ultimately, the study supported that the prevalence of mental health disorders varied by dimension of sexual orientation, while adding and emphasizing that risk patterns differed among women and men, and for specific sexual minority groups. For example, higher lifetime prevalence of disorder was generally associated with any sexual minority status for men, whereas for women, higher prevalence was associated with any sexual minority identity, but not for sexual attraction or behavior (Bostwick et al., 2010). The study had many strengths, including the sample size, methods, and language. The authors intentionally took steps to improve the design over preceding research. The authors reported that the data collected formed the largest national sample of sexual minority populations when the study was completed, which is very significant because it is exceedingly difficult to conduct research with minority populations, especially when they face societal stigma. Ideally, this would provide more power to find significant associations. Additionally, the national study appears very carefully considered and calculated to be representative of the U.S. population, which should allow the results to be more generalizable to the broader LGB population than they might otherwise be. With that said, the sample of sexual minority individuals is still a relatively small sample and was likely not representative of the 2010 U.S. population, especially if it was 63   adjusted to the 2000 census. By using multiple measures of sexual orientation, this study allowed comparison across those dimensions, which helps reduce concerns around how the subgroups are defined, whether there is under- or overrepresentation due to combining subgroups or worries about the mislabeling of participants or their identities and the actual construct they are trying to understand. In this study, the diagnoses were based on DSM-IV criteria and the measures were well-validated, allowing some certainty of the construct being measured and the applicability to current psychiatric diagnosis at the time. While this study used validated measures, they were still different than the measures used in other similar studies, which could ultimately still make it difficult to compare. The authors did control for a variety of demographic factors, which reduced the chance of confounding variables contributing to the associations found. Some limitations to this study included the use of cross-sectional data, limiting the kinds of knowledge that could be ascertained from the results. Additionally, the current study only used data from the second wave of the original survey because sexual orientation was not assessed in the first wave, so the authors noted that they could not examine temporal order or whether development of a minority sexual orientation identity preceded the mental health condition or vice versa. There is also the possibility that participants underreported information about themselves, especially when discussing sensitive information such as sexual behavior, identity, or attraction in a face-to-face interview format that left little anonymity when they could be concerned about judgment or discrimination. This study used lifetime sexual behavior, compared to the past year or the past five years as seen in other studies, making it more difficult to directly compare their results to the results of other studies. Much like measures establishing diagnosis, it may be important to standardize 64   sexual orientation measures, definitions, and wording or language in future research. The authors also noted that a number of variables were not taken into account, including participants’ level of disclosure or any experiences of discrimination related to their sexual identity, or past experiences of trauma or abuse, which are factors associated with mental health status among sexual minority groups. An additional question for this study is why they only used categories of sex, male and female, for the participants and their sexual partners were only same- or opposite-sex, when they included other options like “unsure” for sexual orientation. It would seem likely that some individuals may have had relations with people who did not identify within the binary and who may have neither been the same or opposite gender, which may have been challenging to classify without those options for participants. While factoring in gender may have been another layer that made the variables less clear, it could be an important variable that is not being considered in these results since it can often have significant meaning in how one defines their sexual orientation, attraction, and behaviors (Bostwick et al., 2010). In 2014, Sandfort et al. completed another study investigating the prevalence of psychiatric disorders in relation to sexual orientation and differences over time. This study was a replication and expansion of the first study. Their data came from the second Netherlands Mental Health Survey and Incidence Study (NEMESIS-2; de Graaf et al., 2012) which used a representative sample of the Dutch population aged 18 to 64 years of age to assess for psychiatric disorders. The survey used a multistage, stratified, random sampling procedure to recruit households in the Netherlands. One respondent per household was randomly selected for participation in the study. The authors used post-stratification weighting of demographic factors to ensure the sample had a distribution close to the general population. In total, 6,646 people were interviewed, with a 65.1% response rate of the eligible respondents. The study collected 65   sociodemographic information including sex, age, educational level, partnership status, and urbanicity. The sample demographics were a mean age of 44.3 years old and 55.2% women. Most participants had higher professional or university education, 67.8% were married or cohabitating with 20.8% living alone, 74.6% were employed, and 5.7% were of non-Western origin (Sandfort et al., 2014). The CIDI 3.0 (Kessler & Ustun, 2004) was used to determine DSM-IV diagnoses. The authors reported that the CIDI 3.0 has generally good validity for anxiety, mood, and substance use disorders. NEMESIS-2 assessed major depression, dysthymia, bipolar disorder, panic disorder, agoraphobia (without panic disorder), social phobia, specific phobia, generalized anxiety disorder, alcohol and drug abuse and dependence, attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder, conduct disorder, and oppositional defiant disorder. Questions from the International Personality Disorder Examination (Huang et al., 2009) were also administered to assess anti-social personality disorder. These assessments were administered in face-to-face interviews with a laptop computer (Sandfort et al., 2014). Sexual orientation was assessed by means of asking participants about their sexual behavior and sexual attraction. They were asked about sexual contact over the preceding year and the sex of their partners and then categorized as either “homosexually active” (had sex with someone of the same sex) or heterosexually active. Next, they were asked to identify their sexual attraction from response options on a card that included “to women only,” “predominantly to women,” “to women and men equally,” “predominantly to men,” and “to men only.” Participants who expressed equal attraction or predominant or exclusive attraction to the same sex were categorized as same sex attracted. All others were categorized as heterosexually attracted. The 66   authors indicated that the bisexual behavior and bisexual attraction subgroups were too small to analyze on their own (Sandfort et al., 2014). The authors used bivariate analysis for men and women separately to assess for any confounding demographic variables and sexual orientation. They then used logistic regression analyses while controlling for age, education, residence, and relationship status to assess for differences in prevalence between “homosexually active” or same-sex attracted participants and heterosexual participants. These variables were controlled to allow for comparison with their first study. They then tested interaction effects of time and sexual behavior interactions to determine if there were any variations in disparities of prevalence between 1996 (NEMESIS-1) and 2007 to 2009 (NEMESIS-2; Sandfort et al., 2014).  Of the total sample, 2.2% of sexually active men and 2.0% of sexually active women engaged in same-sex sexual behavior, with 10% of those men and 19.3% of those women also engaging in opposite-sex sexual behavior. Additionally, same-sex attraction was reported by 2.5% of the men and 2.5% of the women. Bisexual or same-sex attraction was also described by 2.9% of sexually inactive men and 3.7% of sexually inactive women. The researchers found a higher 12-month prevalence of any anxiety disorder for men who engaged in same-sex behavior compared to men with only opposite-sex behavior. In particular, men who engaged in same-sex behavior were more likely to have experienced social phobia than men who engaged in opposite-sex behavior. Regarding lifetime prevalence, men who engaged in same-sex behavior were more likely to experience panic, drug abuse, and comorbid disorders than men who engaged in opposite-sex behavior. Same-sex attraction yielded similar results, with men who experience same-sex attraction having a higher likelihood of 12-month prevalence of major depressive disorder and lifetime experience of any mood disorder, major depression, social phobia, and 67   general anxiety disorders than men who experience opposite-sex attraction. Women who engaged in same-sex behavior were more likely to have experienced bipolar, alcohol dependence, and drug dependence in the previous 12 months and alcohol and drug dependence during their life than women who engaged opposite-sex behavior. Mood and anxiety disorders were more likely in the previous 12 months for women who reported same-sex attraction compared to women who reported opposite-sex attraction, including social phobia specifically. Lifetime prevalence of any mood, anxiety, or substance use disorder was more likely for women with same-sex attraction than women with opposite-sex attraction, including alcohol and drug dependence, dysthymia, and social phobia. In this study they found the 12-month and lifetime prevalence of social phobia for men by behavior-based orientation (bisexually and homosexually active) was 12.3% and 17.8%, respectively, and by attraction-based orientation (same-sex attracted) were 12.1% and 20.1%, respectively. The 12-month and lifetime prevalence of social phobia for women by behavior-based orientation (bisexually and homosexually active) were 12.2% and 20.2%, respectively, and by attraction-based orientation (same-sex attracted) were 15.3% and 25.3%, respectively (Sandfort et al., 2014). This study appears thorough. The authors made adjustments based on newer research since the first iteration of this study, which improved many of the concerns noted before. For example, they broadened the definition of sexual orientation, albeit by adding just one more dimension, but it still demonstrated some significant differences and emphasized the importance of using more than one, rigid definition of sexual orientation. They also included and analyzed data for participants who did not have sexual partners over the past year, which demonstrated higher prevalence rates overall for both homosexual and heterosexual groups. Some limitations of the study included small sample sizes of some subgroups that did not allow for analysis to 68   better understand how the interaction of or differences between sexual behavior and attraction contribute to the variations found. Additionally, while previous research has shown the importance of splitting groups based upon exclusively homosexual orientation and bisexual orientation, they were unable to do so in this study, and therefore, some disparities between the homosexual group and the heterosexual group may not be as significant or accurate as what was found. Another challenge with a small sample size is the lowered power to identify significant differences (Sandfort et al., 2014). In examining the preceding studies on prevalence of mental health disorders, with pointed interest in social anxiety and social phobia among LGB individuals, it is notable that social anxiety can substantially affect the everyday life of many LGB individuals. While there was nuance and moderate variation in the research findings, it is evident that there tended to be higher prevalence of social anxiety among LGB individuals overall. At a quick glance, it can be estimated that the 12-month prevalence of social anxiety among LGB individuals was somewhere between 7% (Sandfort et al., 2001) and 15.3% (Sandfort et al., 2014), while the lifetime prevalence was between 4% (Bostwick et al., 2010) and 27.1% (Meyer et al., 2008). This range seems to indicate that there may be meaningful differences in the distribution and experience of social anxiety, particularly between unique subgroups. The prevalence rates found in research thus far include 12-month prevalence of 7.3% for homosexual men and 7.0% for homosexual women (Sandfort et al., 2001); 8.8% for same-sex partnered men and 10.4% for same-sex partnered women (Gilman et al., 2001); 12.1% (attraction-based) to 12.3% (behavior-based) for men and 12.2% (behavior-based) to 15.3% (attraction-based) for women (Sandfort et al., 2014); and 13.5% (Wang et al., 2007). Lifetime prevalence of social phobia was between 4% and 18.2% for nonheterosexual women (defined by behavior, identity, or attraction) and between 69   6.1% and 15.6% for nonheterosexual men (defined by behavior, identity, or attraction; Bostwick et al., 2010); 14.6% for homosexual men and 18.6% for homosexual women (Sandfort et al., 2001); 17.8% (behavior-based) to 20.1% (attraction-based) for men and 20.2% (behavior-based) to 25.3% (attraction-based) for women (Sandfort et al., 2014); and 22.2% total including 23.8% of men, 20.5% of women, 21.1% of lesbian or gay individuals, and 27.1% of bisexual individuals (Meyer et al., 2008). Overall, the research studies reviewed appeared to be of quality and the concerns that arose were fairly similar to those addressed in discussing the previous research. While generalization to the broader population is often a concern, in this section half of the studies were from the United States and the other half were from Western Europe, indicating significantly less variation in the populations studied, which could mean that the results may be more representative and comparable for those populations. However, it does provide a narrow view of SAD in the LGB community and will make it more challenging to compare these sections on prevalence. Over time, the authors in a number of these studies seemed to take intentional steps to improve the study design over preceding research, versus completing a number of similar or flawed studies, whether it was improvements to sample size, methods, or language. The use of cross-sectional designs has limitations and does not allow for exploration of causation, but this might not be as important since it is not the main focus of prevalence studies. The primary goal of most of these studies was solely to look at and compare prevalence rates, which is a significant distinction from the studies in the previous section. Many of these studies used large, representative samples that were carefully randomized and selected. These larger and more representative samples likely made these results more generalizable than some of the other research that has been explored thus far, particularly to the 70   broader LGB population. Larger numbers of participants also allowed more exploration between groups than in some smaller studies. In one study, it was noted that they had the largest national sample of sexual minority populations to date, which is significant because it is remarkably difficult to conduct research with minority populations, especially when they face societal stigma. Ideally, this would provide more power to find significant associations. A challenge to large, representative samples of the general population was that there were still a relatively small number of LGB individuals, which at times still led to them being grouped together instead of considered separately and certainly may have masked or inflated results for the broader LGB population when variation was possibly more accurately attributable to a specific subgroup. For example, combining individuals who only engaged in sexual behaviors with same-sex partners and individuals who engaged in sexual behaviors with both same-sex and opposite-sex partners likely conflated or missed characteristics unique to the differences and experiences of each of those populations, which could have an impact on the results found. Another odd choice in one study was combining gay, lesbian, and other similar identities such as queer into one subgroup, only separating out bisexual individuals. Previous research has demonstrated some differences in the experiences of men and women, and therefore of gay men and lesbian women, so it would seem important that those groups were also considered separately. A significant critique for a number of these studies is how they defined and measured sexual orientation, especially if they primarily used one dimension such as sexual behaviors that were engaged in over attraction or self-identification. This did improve in more recent studies, which is a positive progression, though the insistence of some researchers to use behavioral based categorization despite the demonstrated importance of identity was questionable. Differing methods may also relate to the variation among response rates reported in different studies. For 71   example, how sexual orientation is operationalized in a study does change the results of the study, which indicates a similar concern that was noted before around the measurement of the construct and the challenge of comparing between studies when they may not have the whole or same picture. Additionally, there was variation in the acts or timeframes used to define same-sex sexual behavior across studies, which also led to measurement errors. For example, if some studies assessed for sexual behavior in the last year, others in the last five years, and others lifetime, the samples and ultimately the findings could vary significantly. By excluding partners or sexual behaviors beyond a year or five years and only examining partners and behaviors within a shortened timeframe, it seems likely that many people may be excluded that could have added to each group or that people who do hold a sexual minority identity that is not depicted by recent sexual behaviors may have been miscategorized. In one study, it seemed helpful that the authors allowed the participants to identify themselves as gay and/or men who had sex with men, as this reduced some concerns noted in other studies around accuracy of categorization for sample participants and subgroups. In another study, the participants were able to identify their sexual identity as part of their orientation, which was important because research has begun to look at the importance of identity in relation to mental health and development. Identity and how one relates to their sexual identity is a pertinent piece of the puzzle that strictly behaviorally defined orientation misses because there are people who sleep with members of the same sex or gender and do not identify as homosexual at all. So, including these people in a sample where they do not hold a sexual minority identity may impact or skew the results, as they likely do not have the same experiences as people who do hold that identity. Additionally, in all the studies that used behavioral definitions of sexual orientation, it is either unclear if they asked the circumstances in which the sexual behaviors occurred or unlikely when a question of that nature 72   was not described while assessment of orientation was. It could be possible that some people had same-sex sexual encounters with multiple partners at once and that situation may not be reflective of their identity. By using multiple measures of sexual orientation, some studies allowed comparison across those dimensions, which helped reduce concerns around how the subgroups were defined, whether there was under- or overrepresentation due to combining subgroups or worries about the mislabeling of participants or their identities and the actual construct they were trying to understand. An additional factor noted throughout these studies was the general exclusion of gender and instead the use of sex. Participants were usually categorized as male or female and their sexual partners were either same- or opposite-sex, even in studies where they included other options such as “unsure” for sexual orientation. It is possible that some individuals may have engaged in sexual behavior with or attraction to people who did not identify within the binary and who may have neither been the same or opposite gender, which may have been challenging to classify without those options for participants. It is possible that factoring in gender may have added another layer that made the variables less clear, but it could be an important or confounding variable that is not being considered in the results since it can often have significant relevance in how one defines their sexual orientation, attraction, and behaviors. Another difference in methods includes varying demographics being collected, reported, considered, and analyzed across studies. Some studies collected a series of demographics and report them, regardless of whether they analyze them, and others collected seemingly few demographics or did not directly report them or fully describe their sample. When the demographics collected or reported were limited, it limited the factors that could be compared or examined and it created challenges in knowing the population that was being discussed and how 73   the sample compared to the broader population. In some studies, the authors reported controlling for a variety of demographic factors to reduce the chance of confounding variables contributing to the associations found, which could alleviate the concern arising in other studies when there was uncertainty about what factors were being analyzed or if any were even controlled for. One study noted something important that may have not even been considered in the other studies, which was acknowledging that several factors associated with mental health status among sexual minority groups were not considered, such as the participants’ level of disclosure, any experiences of discrimination related to their sexual identity, or past experiences of trauma or abuse. Another sociodemographic-background-related challenge that may limit the generalizability of most of these studies was that there was a fair amount of recruited people who did not respond or participate in all the studies. The differences between the recruited sample who agreed to participate compared to the rest who did not participate are not known. There could be unique characteristics of those who did participate and those who did not participate that contributed to the results, leading to either higher or lower prevalence rates. The reasons people chose to respond or not could be related to important factors such as mental health status, stigma, or lack of information and resources, which may be important barriers to consider or address in the larger population. These studies tended to use reliable, validated, and standardized diagnostic instruments that were based on clinical diagnostic criteria. The majority of the studies used varying versions of the CIDI, which actually provide some consistency and comparability that is lacking in a great deal of other research. However, while the quality of the instruments may be good and similar across these studies, they are still different than ones used in other studies on SAD, the LGB population, and college students, which could ultimately make it difficult to compare all the 74   findings. In some instances, it seemed that the data collected, or the instruments used, were outdated when something newer could have been used. It seems that this may just be a part of the nature of these large, national prevalence studies due to the time it takes to plan, organize, gather data, and use validated instruments. It may be unfortunate that this is the case simply because publishing data that are 5 or 10 years old, particularly relating to trends and changes in the population, are likely no longer an accurate representation of the population. Almost all these studies primarily used a face-to-face interview format to administer the measures to their participants. Therefore, there is a possibility that participants underreported information about themselves, especially when discussing sensitive information such as sexual behavior, identity, attraction, and mental health with little anonymity and potential concerns about judgment or discrimination from others. Finally, there was considerable variance in the use of language across studies, which relates to challenges with definitions and categorization of groups and people, though some of the fluctuating terminology may be related to social progress as the appropriate verbiage within the LGB community or research world changes over time. For this reason, it seems important that language is intentionally considered and deliberately chosen when working with sexual minority individuals, especially when the language could have differing connotations, be othering, or is heterocentric or heteronormative. For instance, one study made the choice to use the term intercourse. They acknowledged that some participants with same-sex partners who did not engage in this behavior may have been excluded, which relates to how sexual behavior is defined, as well as the uncertainty of how female same-sex respondents may have interpreted the item. These concerns around language have also arose around common assessments used for social anxiety (Weiss et al., 2013) where the questions may ask about people of the opposite-sex 75   or gender and therefore would likely not be a sufficient assessment of an LGB person’s social anxiety. Much like measures establishing diagnosis, it may be important to attempt to standardize sexual orientation measures, sexual orientation definitions, and general and categorical language in future research to allow for inclusion, consistency, and accuracy. SAD in LGB College Students Thus far, this paper has explored the challenges faced by college students and LGB individuals overall regarding SAD and the impact that it can have on their experiences. While understanding how SAD impacts these two groups in general, it is important to understand the intersection of the impact of SAD specifically on LGB college students, as these students may have varying experiences when these two identities meet to create potentially unique stressors and challenges. College campuses can be unwelcoming and uncomfortable for sexual minority students (Woodford et al., 2015). LGB students experience greater psychological distress and decreased social well-being during the first year of undergraduate studies compared to heterosexual peers (Kirsch et al., 2015). LGB students reported greater levels of psychological distress across the first year in addition to the elevated levels of distress that they began college with (Kirsch et al., 2015). Additionally, studies of LGBTQ college/university students have found higher prevalence of depression, suicidal behavior, and addictive behavior compared to heterosexual peers, which appears to support the minority stress theory suggesting that sexual orientation relationship stress is related to worse mental health (Peltzer & Pengpid, 2016). There has been limited research examining social anxiety among LGB college students in particular and no studies were found that investigated the prevalence of social anxiety in this specific population. While some studies were found that did investigate LGB college student mental health or social 76   anxiety specifically, they did not measure or attain prevalence. These studies did demonstrate an increase of social anxiety for gay and bisexual men over time (Pachankis et al., 2018) and that gay men reported more anxiety than heterosexual men across many domains (Pachankis & Goldfried, 2006). Additionally, some studies have found that there may also be variation of these trends among the LGB subgroups themselves. For example, one study found that bisexual and other sexual identities (not gay and lesbian) endorsed higher levels of social anxiety than lesbian/gay and heterosexual peers, while lesbian/gay individuals rated similar levels of social anxiety as heterosexual peers (Wadsworth & Hayes-Skelton, 2015). As demonstrated by examining all the previous studies, attempting to measure the prevalence of SAD for a population with minimal research requires exercise of caution not only in comparing the research related to each of these populations to extrapolate probabilities related to the population of interest, but also in considering the overall prevalence of SAD in general. Overall, the research appears to be of quality and well designed. However, as demonstrated by Furmark (2002), and noticed above, there is variation in the methods used across studies to categorize and measure social anxiety. Even small changes in how SAD was defined or categorized can significantly skew the prevalence estimates that are found, which is a challenge in attempting to compare the results of the studies, but additionally adds a challenge to determine which results are most accurate as well. In addition to how SAD is categorized and defined, there is variation in how sexual orientation is defined and measured across studies, which can skew the sample and impact the results as well. Gilman et al. (2001) even mentioned that the variation in the acts used to define same-sex sexual behavior across studies could also lead to measurement errors. With that said, the previously reviewed research indicated that the prevalence of SAD among college students is likely between 8.5% (Bella & Omigbodun, 2009) and 80% (Ahmad et 77   al., 2017), with the majority of studies falling between 16.4% and 32.8%. It was also demonstrated that the prevalence of SAD among LGB individuals is likely between 7% (Sandfort et al., 2001) and 15.3% (Sandfort et al., 2014) for 12-month prevalence and between 4% (Bostwick et al., 2010) and 27.1% (Meyer et al., 2008) for lifetime prevalence, with the majority of lifetime prevalence falling between 14.6% and 27.1%. It would appear that both of these populations demonstrate some common overlap for the majority of the studies indicating prevalence between 14.6% and 32.8% in the middle range. It would seem likely that the prevalence of SAD for LGB college students would be comparable to this range, with a note that the actual prevalence may be somewhat higher, especially for students with any sexual orientation that includes people with same and different sex/gender from their own.   78   Chapter III: RISK FACTORS FOR SAD As noted in the previous chapter, there is a high prevalence of social anxiety among college students and within the LGB population, which is presumed to indicate that it is likely there is a significant prevalence of social anxiety in the LGB college student population as well. With awareness about the importance of social support for LGB individuals and the challenges that transitioning into young adulthood and college life can pose, it is paramount to understand how LGB students experience social anxiety and the impact it may have on their development and success. This leads to the second question in this project, which is examining the potential risks and contributing factors to social anxiety among LGB college students.
