The hypothesis was that the factors that contribute social anxiety among LGB college students are an intersection of those factors that contribute to social anxiety for other LGB individuals and other college students, such as identity development, social support, minority stress, and significant life transitions. This chapter examines factors that contribute to social anxiety and the LGB experience to explore the potential risks and challenges for this population, including general etiological factors, developmental issues, gender role nonconformity, abusive and negative family experiences, stigmatizing attitudes, self-concealment, and sexual orientation victimization. General Risk Factors for SAD The general risk factors for SAD among LGB individuals include etiological factors that are common to all individuals (Higa-McMillan & Ebesutani, 2011). Examining SAD through a developmental framework, research has proposed that factors influencing psychopathology include predisposing factors, precipitating factors, and maintaining factors, though SAD can be developed through a variety of developmental pathways, regardless of having predisposing 79   factors or experiencing precipitating factors (Higa-McMillan & Ebesutani, 2011). Predisposing factors may include genetic vulnerabilities, neurobiological vulnerabilities, inhibited temperament, poor attachment, and negative parenting styles (Higa-McMillan & Ebesutani, 2011). Precipitating factors may include negative life events, such as childhood stressors like abuse, illness, or family conflict, or direct or indirect exposure to conditioning experiences such as socially traumatic events (Higa-McMillan & Ebesutani, 2011). Maintaining factors would include any factor that leads to the persistence of SAD, which can include any predisposing factors or precipitating factors, as well as issues such as social skills deficits and cognitive biases (Higa-McMillan & Ebesutani, 2011). Research with population data indicates that young people who experience abuse as children or adolescents are more likely to have impaired psychosocial functioning, such as social problems and SAD (Silverman et al., 1996). For example, in a study on early negative life events, Binelli et al. (2012) found that university students in Spain who indicated high levels of social anxiety reported higher prevalence of negative events early in life. They specifically found a positive correlation between family violence in childhood and social anxiety, concluding that family violence could be a risk factor for social anxiety among the college population (Binelli et al., 2012). Higher levels of social anxiety (Craig, 1998; Walters & Inderbitzen, 1998) and lower levels of social acceptance (Callaghan & Joseph, 1995) are displayed more in children who experience higher levels of peer victimization than children who experience lower levels of victimization. For example, there was a statistically significant and positive correlation found between college students who reported a history of childhood teasing and scores on measures of anxiety sensitivity and social anxiety (Roth et al., 2002). Anxiety sensitivity, which may be a 80   significant factor in the development and continuation of social anxiety (Gore et al., 2002), relates to a predisposition to fear the potential negative consequences of experiencing anxious sensations that may arise from distressing thoughts or beliefs about those experiences (Hazen et al., 1994; Scott et al., 2000). It is possible that the world begins to be perceived as a dangerous place by children who are victimized and they may learn that they need to be hypervigilant and alert, which could lead to difficulties with anxiety, particularly in social situations (Sailer & Hazlett-Stevens, 2011). The idea that social situations are dangerous and will end in failure is reinforced when negative situations like those involving victimization are directly experienced (Clark & Wells, 1995; Rapee & Heimberg, 1997). In one study examining correlates of social anxiety among Chinse university students, Cheng et al. (2017) explored lifestyle, social, personality, and mental health factors of incoming university students reporting experiences of social anxiety symptoms. The study found that factors associated with high levels of social anxiety symptoms included being an undergraduate student, being a nonsmoker, having poor social support, experiencing internet addiction, poor sleep, engaging in less altruistic behavior, and experiencing suicidal ideation (Cheng et al., 2017). Higher levels of social anxiety symptoms were also noted among undergraduate students than graduate students in this study (Cheng et al., 2017). As explored above, some general risk factors for SAD that likely impact LGB individuals include genetic vulnerabilities, neurobiological vulnerabilities, inhibited temperament, poor attachment, negative parenting styles, negative life events, childhood stressors such as illness, abuse, family conflict, direct or indirect exposure to socially traumatic events, family violence, and peer victimization (Binelli et al., 2012; Callaghan & Joseph, 1995; Craig, 1998; Higa-McMillan & Ebesutani, 2011; Roth et al., 2002; Sailer & Hazlett-Stevens, 2011; Silverman et al., 81   1996; Walters & Inderbitzen, 1998). Additionally, many factors such as being an undergraduate student, not smoking, poor social support, internet addiction, poor sleep, reduced altruistic behavior, and suicidal ideation are associated with high levels of social anxiety symptoms (Cheng et al., 2017). These factors can be taken into consideration when working with LGB college students and understanding their experiences or implementing interventions and programs to target specific student groups. General Mental Health and SAD-Specific Risk Factors for LGB Individuals While general etiological factors for SAD that are experienced by the broader population likely play a role in the development of SAD among LGB individuals, there are also factors of concern that relate specifically to the LGB population that may play a role in the development of SAD as well. This section discusses some general mental health risk factors among LGB individuals that are important to consider regarding broader LGB mental health and factors that impact overall mental health and well-being. Then, this section goes on to explore some LGB-specific risk factors that may relate to the development of SAD among the LGB community. Research indicates that minority stress plays a role in the well-being of LGB people and impacts their mental health, as a positive correlation between minority stress and negative mental health outcomes has been found among LGB adolescents and adults (Dürrbaum & Sattler, 2020; Eaton, 2014; Feinstein et al., 2012; Kuyper & Fokkema, 2011; Newcomb & Mustanski, 2010; Pachankis et al., 2014; Roberts et al., 2010; Sattler et al., 2017; Szymanski & Sung, 2010). In one small study conducting interviews with LGB youth who were experiencing depression and suicidal ideation, the most frequent causes of psychological distress identified by the youth were rejection from their family because of their sexual orientation, sexual orientation victimization 82   from individuals outside of their family, and negative family events that were not related to their sexual orientation (Diamond et al., 2011). Additionally, while Fish and Pasley (2015) found similar levels of depressive symptoms and suicidality among individuals who first reported same-sex attraction and a sexual minority identity in adulthood and those who reported in adolescence, they did note that worsening mental health in adulthood was associated with later changes in attraction, behavior, and identity. Specifically, they noted greater risk for development of depressive symptoms and excessive alcohol use in individuals who become aware of or acknowledged their sexual minority attraction or did not incorporate their attraction into their identity until later stages of their development. Ueno (2010) also found that when individuals take on a stigmatized identity, there is an increased risk of poor mental health. Further, barriers to societal integration, which include not living with a partner or children, unemployment, and lack of societal trust, were found to be higher among LGB individuals compared to heterosexual individuals and these barriers partially explained the higher risk and prevalence of suicide among LGB individuals (Bränström et al., 2020). Additionally, lack of support socially and culturally from institutions that shape the lives of LGBTQ youth, such as schools, families, and faith institutions, limits the rights and protections of LGBTQ individuals and can make them vulnerable to negative experiences (Russell & Fish, 2016). For example, research has demonstrated that LGBTQ youth in schools with specific policies related to nondiscrimination and antibullying for gender and sexual minority individuals report less victimization and harassment than students in schools without those policies (Kosciw et al., 2014), and LGBTQ youth in areas with fewer protective policies for gender and sexuality minority individuals are more likely to report suicide attempts within 83   the last year compared to youth in areas where protective policies are common (Hatzenbuehler & Keyes, 2013). Other social environment characteristics at the county level associated with a lower risk of suicide among LGB youth were the proportion of same-sex couples and registered Democrats (Hatzenbuehler, 2011; Hatzenbuehler & Keyes, 2013). This impact also stretches to the laws and policies that are in place at the broader societal level, and while there are only a few studies that specifically examine the relationship between laws, policies, and mental health, it is generally accepted that these constructs form the conditions that affect minority stress and mental health (Russell & Fish, 2016). For example, Rostosky et al. (2009) found that after an election cycle in states where the ballot contained measures to ban same-sex marriage there were higher reports of psychological distress among the LGB individuals who lived there and Hatzenbuehler et al. (2010) found that LGB adults who lived in states where same-sex marriage was banned had higher rates of psychiatric disorders. In addition to the etiological factors that can impact any young adult and potentially lead to onset of SAD, other factors that have been investigated in the literature as potential variables that might contribute to increased social anxiety in the LGB community include developmental issues, gender role nonconformity, abusive and negative family experiences, self-concealment, and sexual orientation victimization (Bailey & Zucker, 1995; Corliss et al., 2002; Garofalo et al., 1998; Poteat et al., 2009; Roberts et al., 2011). Developmental Issues Higher levels of social anxiety found among LGBTQ youth may be partially explained by the lifelong challenges of feeling different from others and knowing that the way in which one is different is considered unacceptable by broader society (Bostwick et al., 2010; Pachankis & Goldfried, 2006; Safren & Pantalone, 2006), and social anxiety, among other mental health 84   concerns, may be an outcome, if not a key determinant, for sexual minority individuals who expect rejection from others, and from heterosexuals in particular (Hart & Heimberg, 2001; Meyer, 2003). D’Augelli (2002) noted that awareness of the social conflict with one’s sexual orientation or gender identity may begin around 10 to 11 years old, with many youths reporting even earlier that they feel different from others, though they often do not disclose their identity until many years later. It is posed that social anxiety may play a role in this delay (D’Augelli, 2002; D’Augelli et al., 2006; D’Augelli & Hershberger, 1993; Roberts et al., 2011) and D’Augelli (2002) noted that development for LGBTQ individuals has the added obstacles of negative evaluation from society that likely have an impact (Rotheram-Borus & Langabeer, 2001). Young people’s experiences with romantic relationships are a normal and significant fundamental piece of their development, and these relationships can offer support, which may act as a protective factor for LGB youth (Collins et al., 2009; Russell & Fish, 2016). However, there can be many barriers to dating same-sex partners, such as limited opportunities for romantic partners, minority stress related to pursuing romantic relationships, and constraints on same-sex relationships in academic settings, which might result in LGB youth seeking out other social settings such as bars and clubs, potentially increasing risky behaviors (Mustanski et al., 2014; Russell & Fish, 2016). Diamond and Lucas (2004) also found that when it comes to finding compatible partners and general dating, LGB youth report less initiative and more fear. These added challenges to dating have the potential to impact development from adolescence through later life stages (Frost, 2011; Mustanski et al., 2014; Russell, Watson & Muraco, 2012). 85   Gender Role Nonconformity Regardless of their sexual orientation, gender diverse people are more likely to face discrimination, stigma, and victimization from a young age (Corliss et al., 2002; Fagot, 1977; Feinstein et al., 2012; Horn, 2007; Jacobson et al., 2016; Smith & Leaper, 2006; Toomey et al., 2012; Zucker et al., 1995), with gender diverse youth reporting more experiences of victimization, mental health problems, and traumatic stress (D’Augelli et al., 2006) and gender nonconformity in childhood being significantly associated with rejection sensitivity, depression, social anxiety, and experiences of discrimination (Feinstein et al., 2012). Many sexual minority youth believe that others can easily identify them as LGBTQ, which may be partially due to their own awareness that they may not present according to traditional gender expectations (Roberts et al., 2011). D’Augelli and Hershberger (1993) found that indivdiuals who percevied themselves as more representative of characteristics of the opposite gender than their peers, for example young men who perceived themselves as more feminine than other men, felt that they were more identifiable as a sexual minority than other LGBTQ people. D’Augelli et al. (2006) found that sexual minority men perceived their parents’ reactions to gender atypical behaviors more negatively than sexual minority women, which appears consistent with findings from Kane (2006) indicating that parents seemed more accepting of these behaviors among young girls compared to young boys. Further research has indicated that as early as preschool and continuing through adolescence, boys who are gender nonconforming are subjected to more criticism, ridicule, and rejection by peers, teachers, and family than gender-conforming boys (Fagot, 1977; Horn, 2007; Jacobson et al., 2016; Landolt et al., 2004; Roberts et al., 2013; Zucker et al., 1995). Some research has shown a relationship between early gender nonconformity and later development of anxiety, notably for gay men 86   (Lippa, 2008; Weinrich et al., 1995), as well as an association between self-reported levels of gender nonconformity and higher levels of trait anxiety among gay men, but not lesbians (Skidmore et al., 2006). According to research, gay men are more likely to engage in gender nonconforming behaviors such as speaking, walking, or dressing in ways that are considered effeminate (Lippa, 2000, 2005, 2008; Rieger et al., 2008) and engagement in these behaviors can increase the chances of an individual being identified as gay and possibly targeted for victimization (Skidmore et al., 2006). Indeed, findings from a large-scale study of Latino gay and bisexual men showed that those who described themselves as more effeminate were more likely to have been physically and sexually abused, with the link between gender atypicality and mental distress, including reports of anxiety, being mediated by homophobic experiences (Sandfort et al., 2007). Jacobson et al. (2016) completed a study examining effects of gender nonconforming behavior and sexual orientation on interaction anxiety among Israeli men. They thought that gay men might be more likely to experience anxiety in social interactions partially due to worries about rejection or negative evaluation because of their sexual orientation. However, they found that self-reported perceptions of gender atypicality and heterosexual orientation predicted higher levels of social interaction anxiety, but no significant interactions were found between sexual orientation and gender behavior. With an inverse relationship, individuals reported being more anxious the less masculine they thought others perceived them to be. This led Jacobson et al. (2016) to conclude that perhaps gender atypicality may play more of a role in increasing risk for anxiety than sexual orientation, as other researchers have suggested that the correlations between same-sex attraction and anxiety that have been found throughout the research body may be 87   mediated by gender nonconformity, specifically negative reactions to gender nonconformity (Rieger & Savin-Williams, 2012). In a study conducted by Van Beusekom et al. (2016) researchers examined the relationship between homophobic peer victimization, gender nonconformity, and mental health among adolescent boys. In their sample, there was a significant positive correlation between same-sex attraction and gender nonconformity and experiences of homophobic name-calling, social anxiety, and psychological distress. They found significant positive correlations between gender nonconformity and social anxiety, psychological distress, and homophobic name-calling. They also observed a significant positive relationship between homophobic name-calling and social anxiety and psychological distress. In exploring the effects of homophobic name-calling, they learned that it partially mediated the relationships between gender nonconformity and both social anxiety and psychological distress, though gender nonconformity was still significantly related to both without considering homophobic name-calling (van Beusekom et al., 2016). In considering other moderating factors, van Beusekom et al. (2016) found a significant interaction between gender nonconformity and sexual attraction whereby the positive relationship between gender nonconformity and homophobic name-calling increased as same-sex attraction increased. These findings were only significant for individuals with mean and high levels of same-sex attraction, but not for individuals with low same-sex attraction, interestingly. The researchers noted that this difference in levels of same-sex attraction may indicate that feelings of same-sex attraction play a role in possible experience of victimization, as individuals were not targeted by others exclusively due to their gender expression, though this may relate to other factors relating to their sample, such as level of outness or openness about gender identity and sexual orientation or their ages as young adolescents (van Beusekom et al., 2016). This study 88   adds to the body of research with results indicating that sexual minority youth report experiencing more psychological distress, including social anxiety, which in part is impacted by their sexual orientation, gender nonconformity, and experiences of sexual orientation victimization to varying degrees. Abusive and Negative Family Experiences The challenges faced by LGBTQ youth in the community also occur within their families, which creates an additional layer of stress because of how important parental and familial relationships are for the well-being of young people (Steinberg & Duncan, 2002). Many youth are afraid to come out to others, especially to their parents (Potoczniak et al., 2009), due to fears of being rejected, disappointing others, hurting others, rupturing their relationships, and even verbal or physical abuse (D’Augelli et al., 1998; Roberts et al., 2011; Ryan et al., 2009). Therefore, many LGBTQ youth may experience distress and symptoms of social anxiety in their home environment (Hart & Heimberg, 2001). In a study completed by D’Augelli et al. (2008), it was estimated that 30% to 40% of parents have a negative response to their children’s disclosure of their sexual orientation, though the likelihood of a negative response was often overestimated by LGB youth. In another study, Pachankis et al. (2008) noted that over a quarter of their sample was not out to at least one parent and, compared to individuals who had disclosed their sexual orientation to their parents, there was significantly higher internalized homophobia among those who had not disclosed. More fear of rejection and internalized homophobia was reported by the individuals who had not shared their orientation with their parents, while youth who worried less about rejection reported positive reactions from their parents (D’Augelli et al., 2008). This fear is understandable, as rejection can have significant consequences such as increased verbal or physical harassment (D’Augelli et al., 1998) and homelessness (Durso & Gates, 2012). 89   Individuals who experience family rejection have higher risks of depression, anxiety, suicidal ideation, and suicide attempts (D’Augelli, 2002; Rosario et al., 2009; C. Ryan et al., 2009). In one study on family rejection of gay and lesbian individuals, Carastathis et al. (2017) found common themes around the impact of familial rejection including development of a negative identity, poor mental health, and self-destructive behaviors. Some of the participants acknowledged an early dissatisfaction with their sexuality due to societal perceptions that being a sexual minority was wrong or abnormal and a general lack of acceptance for sexual minority individuals, which were reinforced by family rejection (Carastathis et al., 2017). For many participants, this led to internalization of negative family attitudes and negative attitudes about themselves such as feeling wrong, abnormal, worthless, and self-hatred (Carastathis et al., 2017). Some questioned their identity and felt a confusion or a pressure to conform to heterosexuality (Carastathis et al., 2017). Other consequences of familial rejection included poor mental health and self-destructive behaviors such as intense distress, depression, and coping through self-harm, drug, and alcohol use (Carastathis et al., 2017). Some reported use of self-harm as a maladaptive coping strategy to reduce and manage intense emotions, while others also used self-harm as self-punishment in relation to experienced self-hatred (Carastathis et al., 2017). It was common among participants to cope with distress through the use of drugs and alcohol, whether for escape or as an act of rebellion (Carastathis et al., 2017). In some participants the levels of distress were so intense that they experienced suicidal ideation with some also reporting suicide attempts (Carastathis et al., 2017). Carastathis et al. (2017) concluded that rejection by family members can impede an individual’s ability to cope and create significant adversity for sexual minority individuals. 90   Pachankis et al. (2018) examined a construct called parental unfinished business, which they described as “persistent, unresolved negative thoughts and feelings towards one’s parents,” (p. 1068) in relation to experiences of parental rejection among sexual minority men. They found that parental unfinished business was a separate construct from parental rejection and had unique relationships with mental health outcomes, including a significant association with depressive and social anxiety symptoms. These results further emphasize the impact and challenges that can arise among sexual minority individuals from a lack of support, acceptance, or added conflict in their family relationships. There is a high prevalence of reported childhood verbal, physical, and sexual abuse among LGBTQ adults (Corliss et al., 2002; Grossman & D’Augelli, 2007; Kenagy, 2005; Pilkington & D’Augelli, 1995; Tomeo et al., 2001), often perpetrated by family members, particularly parents (Corliss et al., 2002; Rivers & D’Augelli, 2001) and at higher rates than heterosexual youth (Corliss et al., 2002; Saewyc et al., 2006). Waldo et al. (1998) reported that instances of childhood abuse or victimization were positively correlated with self-reported gender atypicality. Stigmatizing Attitudes Stigmatizing attitudes such as negative attitudes toward LGBTQ individuals, HIV/AIDS stigma disproportionate toward LGBTQ individuals, and internalized homophobia are widespread, even throughout primary/middle schools up to postsecondary education, despite research indicating that with increases in age and education homophobia decreases (Lambert et al., 2006; Marsiglio, 1993; Poteat et al., 2009; Pettijohn & Walzer, 2008; Roberts et al., 2011; Sharpe, 2002). Research has demonstrated that stigma and negative attitudes toward LGBTQ people are relatively common, including some studies in schools where students endorsed beliefs 91   that homosexuality is always wrong or usually wrong (Sharpe, 2002), or where students indicated that they could never stay friends with someone who identified as gay or lesbian and would prefer to attend a school where there were no sexual minority students (Poteat et al., 2009). These kinds of negative attitudes toward sexual minority individuals can have a significant impact on sexual minority individuals. Rosario et al. (2002) found that anxious symptoms at a six-month follow-up were predicted when an individual experienced an event of perceived stigmatization such as losing a friend due to their sexual orientation. In an eight-year longitudinal study examining stigma and mental health among gay and bisexual men, Pachankis et al. (2018) found significant associations between three types of stigma (i.e., enacted, anticipated, and internalized) and social anxiety symptoms. Interestingly, over time these men experienced a significant increase in social anxiety, despite significant decreases in many forms of stigma (Pachankis et al., 2018). Fanucce and Taub (2010) explored the effect of homonegativity on the climate of campus residence halls. They found that homonegativity impacts all the students in the residence halls, LGBTQ and heterosexual alike, leading to reduced satisfaction with the residence hall climate. The impact of increasing levels of homonegativity was increased perception of the residence halls as more negative. When LGBTQ students perceive their residence halls as negative toward them, they can feel separate, left out of the community, like they do not belong, and that they are not socially supported (Fanucce & Taub, 2010). It would seem that these feelings and experiences could have a significant impact on LGB college students experience and level of support while in school. 92   Stigma has been wrongly placed on the LGBTQ community, particularly with the concern of the HIV/AIDS epidemic, which has disproportionately affected the LGBTQ community, as the general public was often misinformed about how the virus spread and often associated the illness with sexual minority individuals (Herek & Capitanio, 1999; Swendeman et al., 2006). This led to LGBTQ people experiencing more stigmatization and discrimination for HIV/AIDS, such as the finding by Swendeman et al. (2006) in which HIV positive sexual minority youth were twice as likely as HIV positive heterosexual youth to experience stigma related to their positive status including avoidance of physical contact, verbal abuse, or loss of a friend. Unfortunately, many of these attitudes and stigma can become internalized for LGBTQ individuals, leading them to have negative feelings about sexual minority orientation in general and for themselves, which is known as internalized homophobia (Kubicek et al., 2007; Roberts et al., 2011; Rosario et al., 2008). Some research has begun to examine the relationship between internalized homophobia and anxiety; in one study with LGB adults internalized homophobia predicted anxiety symptoms (Igartua et al., 2003) and in another study with young gay and bisexual men the relationship between internalized homophobia and substance abuse was mediated by anxiety symptoms (Rosario et al., 2006). Feinstein et al. (2012) found a significant association between internalized homonegativity and rejection sensitivity, depression, and social anxiety. Bostwick et al. (2010) explored the idea that the prevalence of mental health concerns differs across the varying dimensions of sexual orientation and that the patterns of risk are different for men and women and specific groups within the sexual minority umbrella. They found that the impact of sexual orientation on health outcomes seems to function differently for 93   men and women, as a higher prevalence for mental health concerns was more consistently associated with any definition of sexual minority status for men (Bostwick et al., 2010). They surmised that a significant factor contributing to this difference is a more extreme stigma toward sexual minority men in the United States, and that with this stigma comes more severe sanctions for violating “traditional” sex norms, such as serious victimization like threats of harm and physical violence, which are associated with poor mental health outcomes (Bostwick et al., 2010). However, among women, the prevalence rates varied based on the definition of sexual minority status used, with exclusive same-sex attraction and behavior both being related to lower rates of most lifetime and past-year disorders (Bostwick et al., 2010). Alternatively, poorer health outcomes were found for individuals who identified as bisexual or were unsure about their identity (Bostwick et al., 2010). The authors found increased risk of mood and anxiety disorders for men and women who endorsed bisexual identity and behaviors (Bostwick et al., 2010). They related this to the unique “double” stigma faced by bisexual individuals, which is different from that experienced by lesbian and gay individuals, as stereotypes and negative attitudes are pervasive among heterosexual, lesbian, and gay populations (Bostwick et al., 2010). These finding indicate that there is important variation among health outcomes within the LGB community and that the individual experience and potential risk likely differ based in part on how someone’s sexual identity, attraction, and behaviors area viewed and treated by society. Self-concealment Many individuals who identify as LGB or a gender and sexual minority learn to conceal their identity at an early age as a coping strategy since there is generally a lack of acceptance and the potential for victimization (D’Augelli, 1992; Martin, 1982; Pachankis & Goldfried, 2006; Roesler & Deisher, 1972). Individuals who are members of minority groups are likely to 94   experience hypervigilance when they are involved in social situations and engaging with individuals who are a part of the dominant group (Goffman, 1963; Pachankis & Goldfried, 2006), which may lead to social settings becoming a source of distress for those with a “concealable stigma” (Pachankis & Goldfried, 2006, p. 998; Smart & Wegner, 1999) as they would likely be thinking about their hidden identity throughout this interaction and focusing on keeping it hidden. Jourard (1959) noted that the mere presence of another person might be anxiety-provoking if becoming acquainted with that person is seen as a possible threat or risk, highlighting that perceiving individuals as dangerous can thwart the one’s ability to form close relationships. This heightened awareness and need to self-monitor may be a prominent factor in these individuals’ experience of social anxiety, as the individual may become preoccupied with concealment (J. M. Cohen et al., 2016; Pachankis & Goldfried, 2006). Cohen et al. (2016) also proposed that a common factor of both social phobia and sexual orientation concealment may be behavioral inhibition, in which people who are socially anxious could be less likely to share personal information, including holding a sexual minority identity. In one study, self-concealment was significantly and positively associated with anxiety (Leleux-Labarge et al., 2015). However, Pachankis and Bernstein (2012) completed a study examining sexual orientation covering, self-consciousness, and anxiety. They found that the relationship between self-consciousness in public and daily experiences of anxiety was mediated by the individual’s engagement in daily sexual orientation covering (Pachankis & Bernstein, 2012). In another study examining anxiety and depression symptoms in sexual minority young adults (J. M. Cohen et al., 2016), researchers found that symptoms of social phobia were significantly predicted by concealment of sexual orientation and greater concealment was 95   significantly associated with greater symptom severity of social phobia. The authors indicated that this may suggest that concealment intensifies socially anxious symptoms. LGB individuals with decreased levels of social anxiety tended to experience increased levels of social support, whereas greater social anxiety was related to less social support, which was related to more self-concealment (Potoczniak et al., 2007). Self-concealment has a significant negative relationship with ego identity commitment, which may imply that LGB individuals may have difficulty committing to an identity if they feel they need to conceal information about themselves (Potoczniak et al., 2007). Some barriers to openness about sexual orientation include fears of job loss, losing friends, verbal abuse at school or home, and physical abuse or harm at school or home (D’Augelli & Hershberger, 1993). Sexual Orientation Victimization Compared to heterosexual peers, sexual minority individuals are at a greater risk of experiencing discrimination, violence, and rejection (Faulkner & Cranston, 1998; Garofalo et al., 1998), including verbal harassment, physical harassment, and discriminatory policies at school (Kosciw et al., 2014). Research has found that negative attitudes toward LGBTQ individuals are commonly heard, in academic settings especially, with nearly 60% of the youth in one study indicating that they had experienced verbal abuse in their high school, as well as other abuses such as objects being thrown, physical altercations and assault, and sexual assault (D’Augelli et al., 2002; Poteat & Espelage, 2007; Roberts et al., 2011; Russell, Franz & Driscoll, 2001). Garofalo et al. (1998) found that compared to heterosexual peers, LGB youth were more likely to miss school out of fear and to report being recently threatened with a weapon at school. Even broader than the school environment, Duncan and Hatzenbuehler (2014) found that community context matters too. In their study, there was a positive association between reports of suicidal 96   ideation and attempts among LGBTQ youth who lived in neighborhoods with more LGBTQ-related hate crimes compared to LGBTQ youth who lived in neighborhoods with fewer of these crimes (Duncan & Hatzenbuehler, 2014). It has also been demonstrated that suicide attempts were less likely among LGBTQ youth living in areas that generally support LGBTQ rights (Hatzenbuehler, 2011). Mays and Cochran (2001) found higher rates of daily and lifetime discrimination among gay men and lesbians compared to heterosexual peers and indicated that these experiences of discrimination were associated with more psychological distress. Toomey et al. (2011) found that psychological distress and overall well-being for young adults was related to past experiences of bias-based victimization, indicating that these experiences likely continue to impact individuals in later developmental stages. Feinstein et al. (2012) found a significant relationship between experiences of discrimination, internalized homonegativity, rejection sensitivity, depression, and social anxiety. Adding to this trajectory, Robinson et al. (2013) found that the bullying rates of gay and bisexual men reduce less throughout the adolescent years compared to the rates of heterosexual men, which could indicate longer periods of risk for LGBTQ youth (Russell & Fish, 2016). A challenge in understanding and mitigating the negative effects of bias-based victimization is that compared to general harassment it has a distinct and amplifying effect on negative outcomes (Poteat & Russell, 2013; Russell & Fish, 2016). For example, higher levels of depression, substance use, missing school, suicidal ideation, and attempts have been reported among youth who have experienced sexual-orientation-based victimization compared to youth who experienced non-bias-based victimization (Poteat et al., 2011; Russell, Sinclair, et al., 2012). Additionally, these effects have not only been seen among LGBTQ youth, but also among heterosexual youth with research showing that homophobic victimization has led to poor mental 97   health among these individuals (Poteat et al., 2011; Robinson & Espelage, 2012). Research has begun to investigate the specific effects of sexual orientation victimization, including the relationship between discrimination and anxiety. In one study, Herek et al. (1999) found that higher levels of anxiety were reported by gay men who experienced a hate crime in the last five years compared to gay men that had not experienced crime related to their identity or not experienced crime at all. Research has found that sexual orientation victimization continues to be common in postsecondary education, with studies at colleges and universities finding that within the past year approximately one-third of undergraduate students reported offensive comments, harassment, threats, and assaults, and to avoid harassment a majority of students indicated that they hide their gender or sexual minority identity (D’Augelli et al., 2002; Ellis, 2009; Evans, 2001; Evans & D’Augelli, 1996; Love, 1998; Waldo et al., 1998). Students reported that these instances happened in many areas on campus, including public spaces, classrooms, and on-campus residences primarily at the hands of other students (D’Augelli et al., 2002; Ellis, 2009). D’Augelli et al. (2002) reported that experiences of sexual orientation victimization are associated with increased distress among youth who hold sexual minority identities. Waldo et al. (1998) found that instances of sexual orientation victimization occur and have similar correlates for LGB individuals in urban and rural communities. Mustanski et al. (2011) found that victimization showed a strong relationship with psychological distress among LGB individuals. Overall, in their sample of LGB youth they found high rates of victimization, with 94% of participants reporting some type of victimization, from verbal insults to physical violence, that they believed was related to their sexual orientation. However, they found only one-third of these participants reported clinical levels of psychological 98   distress, suggesting that some of the participants had resources in their lives that added to their resilience against negative experiences. In their study, they found that levels of victimization varied by race/ethnicity, with the highest levels being reported by Black participants, then those identified as “other,” White, and Latino. The highest levels of psychological distress were reported by White and “Other” identified participants. In the model they tested, they found that peer and family support demonstrated significant compensatory effects, but ultimately the negative effects of victimization remained significant and had negative consequences on those youth, even with social support present. The authors suggested that in addition to providing social support, programs and efforts to directly address victimization should be implemented. One example they provided was the safe school coalitions (Perrotti & Westheimer, 2001). Research has demonstrated that there is a link between social anxiety and rejection from the majority group (Feinstein et al., 2012; Hart & Heimberg, 2005; Meyer, 2003; Szymanski et al., 2008), with higher levels of social anxiety being connected to increased expectations of rejection and frequent experiences of discrimination (Hatzenbuehler et al., 2008; Pachankis et al., 2008), which highlights the importance of understanding how these factors impact LGB individuals and their experience of social anxiety throughout their development. In further exploring mechanisms through which discrimination can lead to increased psychopathology, Burns et al. (2012) examined the relationship between attributions of discriminatory events and social anxiety in gay men. They found that experiences of perceived discrimination were associated with increased social anxiety, but only when high levels of global attributions and importance were endorsed, indicating that attributional styles could be a risk or protective factor regarding discrimination. 99   Additionally, LGBTQ youth experience greater psychological and social problems related to being LGBTQ such as alcohol and drug use, engagement in risky sexual behaviors, decreased social support, and suicidality (Eisenberg & Resnick, 2006; Hart & Heimberg, 2005; Marshal et al., 2008; Safren & Pantalone, 2006). Grant et al. (2014) found that LGBQ students were more likely than their heterosexual peers to be overweight, depressed, have higher levels of stress, and have higher rates of compulsive sexual behavior and compulsive buying. They suggested that the increased levels of these factors could reflect coping utilized by these students as a reaction to stress, depression, or social isolation that may occur in school environments that prevent them from fully engaging in the college experience due to a culture that fosters sexual minority stigma on campus. Another interpretation Grant et al. (2014) offered was that these observations may be the result of maladaptive coping behaviors formed prior to college due to shame and internalized homonegativity, which are leading to increased stress, depression, and anxiety. Both of these ideas align with the notion that some LGB youth may struggle to cope with these experiences of minority stress due to lack of skills or resources and may develop maladaptive strategies to cope (Hatzenbuehler, 2009; Hatzenbuehler et al., 2008; Meyer, 2003), such as rumination and suppression of emotions (Hatzenbuehler et al., 2009). Impact of Social Anxiety on College Students SAD is important to study within the college population because it impacts students’ social and emotional adjustment to college (Nordstrom et al., 2014). In particular, college students are in a peculiar position between the ages of typical onset and emerging symptoms becoming stabilized and solidified from adolescence to young adulthood (Nordstrom et al., 2014). College academic, social, personal, and emotional adjustment can be predicted by most students’ level of satisfaction with their social support, including positive relationships with 100   professors, but because social anxiety can have an impact on perceived or actual social support, students who experience social anxiety may not be able to build and engage in such social supports during the challenging transition into college (Kuder & Grover, 2014; Nordstrom et al., 2014). In a study where college students were asked to have a conversation with a friend (Kuder & Grover, 2014), socially anxious students often held negative perceptions of their own social competencies and were observed to have performance deficits in interpersonal skills, appear less comfortable, demonstrate verbosity or brevity in speaking, and were less effective at maintaining the conversational flow. Kuder and Grover (2014) noted that this could interfere with socially anxious students’ ability to create intimate and supportive relationships as it could impede effective communication with friends and limit those relationships, in turn potentially limiting overall social support in college. Social anxiety can be related to higher levels of homesickness, lower levels of social support, and academic problems such as lower grades, more absences from class, fear of public speaking, lower self-esteem, and lower GPA (di Maria & di Nuovo, 1990; Strahan, 2003; Urani et al., 2003). Nordstrom et al. (2014) found that compared to students with low social anxiety, those with high levels of social anxiety demonstrated significantly lower global, academic, and social self-esteem; greater mental health symptoms such as somatization, obsessive-compulsive processes, and anxious, depressive, and phobic symptoms; and more difficulty in all domains related to college adjustment. In particular, the researchers noted that higher levels of social anxiety among incoming first-year students was comorbid with continued depressive, anxious, and physical symptoms during the first semester. One finding of Nordstrom et al. (2014) was a significant increase in social self-esteem across the first semester for students high in school anxiety, which they suggested could indicate that as these students are repeatedly exposed to and 101   must navigate the social situations and challenges that arise in college, they may gain an increased sense of mastery leading to decreases in anxiety. However, overall, they suggested that students’ academic, social, and institutional adjustment is compromised by the impact of social anxiety reducing multiple aspects of self-esteem (Nordstrom et al., 2014). An indirect impact that social anxiety can have on an individual could be reduced support and closeness from peers due to the stigma associated with SAD. In a study examining the stigma of SAD through describing stereotypes of social anxiety and comparing them to stereotypes of depression or generic mental illness, Anderson et al. (2015) found similarities between the stigmatization of a person with general mental illness and a person with social anxiety. Specifically, they found that more social distance was desired if the person/social anxiety was perceived as dangerous, having an embarrassing problem, being more avoidable, being more common among women, or causing problems at work, but less desire for social distance was associated if social anxiety was perceived as unavoidable (Anderson et al., 2015). Another study by Purdon et al. (2001) found that in social situations most participants occasionally experienced symptoms of anxiety and in their study all symptoms of anxiety were experienced by some participants at some point in time. The majority of their participants indicated that their perception of an individual's intelligence, ambition, reliability, or mental health would not be influenced by noticing that the person was anxious. However, participants did indicate that they thought less of an anxious appearing person’s leadership abilities and strength of character. Interestingly, while individuals higher in social anxiety believed those who are anxious would have higher compassion, it seems they may have been somewhat less compassionate in their judgments about others who were anxious as they were likely to view anxious others as less attractive and as having less strength of character. This could be a 102   contributing factor to interpersonal challenges of connecting with others and building social support. It could also be a factor that would make experiencing sensations of anxiety particularly threatening or impactful for socially anxious individuals in front of others, as they may anticipate the same judgment (Sailer & Hazlett-Stevens, 2011). The authors suggested that correcting the potentially exaggerated beliefs held by people with social phobia regarding the social consequences of exhibiting anxiety in front of other people may be a course of action for treatment. Socially anxious students may experience more cognitive and affective difficulties, as well as more general cognitive distortions (Kashdan & Roberts, 2004; Sailer & Hazlett-Stevens, 2011). In a study by Davison and Zighelboim (1987) socially anxious students provided more irrational thoughts than control (non-anxious) students. Johnson et al. (1992) found that socially anxious students endorsed more distressed responses, more distorted responses, and elevated levels of depressed thinking about other areas of life than students who were less socially anxious. Johnson et al. (1992) indicated that social isolation and depressogenic cognitions can lead to an increased risk for depression among socially anxious students and concluded that social anxiety could be a risk factor for development of depression in these students. Social anxiety has a significant impact on college students as it can affect their ability to adjust and function as they transition into young adulthood. As explored above, it has been demonstrated that social anxiety impacts students’ social and emotional adjustment to college, their ability to build and engage in such social supports, and can lead to deficits in interpersonal and communication skills that can impede ability to make and maintain relationships (Kuder & Grover, 2014; Nordstrom et al., 2014). College students with social anxiety may have higher levels of home sickness, lower esteem, lower social support, lower grades and GPA, be absent 103   more frequently, have fear of public speaking, experience greater mental health issues, and display cognitive difficulties (Davison & Zighelboim, 1987; di Maria & di Nuovo, 1990; Johnson et al., 1992; Kashdan & Roberts, 2004; Nordstrom et al., 2014; Sailer & Hazlett-Stevens, 2011; Strahan, 2003; Urani et al., 2003). Impact of Social Anxiety on LGB Rapee and Heimberg (1997) proposed a model to explore how social anxiety may have a considerable impact on LGB individuals. Their model suggests that a negative feedback loop is responsible for perpetuating and exacerbating social anxiety. In this negative feedback loop, an individual anticipates that a social encounter will go badly, then they experience anxiety and negative thoughts during the encounter, which leads them to negatively interpret and judge their performance in the situation. This continues across social situations, which in turn provides evidence to the individual that they should fear or avoid social situations all together (Rapee & Heimberg, 1997). If this model is used to understand the process and experience of social anxiety among a group of individuals who experiences social oppression, one might consider that experiences of oppression could add evidence to an individual’s negative interpretation. Additional evidence to support a negative interpretation may increase an individual’s anxiety and further reinforce the negative feedback loop, therefore leading to an increase in their symptoms of social anxiety (Rapee & Heimberg, 1997; Wadsworth & Hayes-Skelton, 2015). It also is suggested that sexual minority individuals might experience more negative thoughts about social situations than heterosexual individuals, as they are more likely to experience a great deal of stigma-related thoughts during these interactions (Smart & Wegner, 1999). Experience of social support is likely a significant factor in the experience of social anxiety, where less social support is correlated with higher experience of social anxiety, as well 104   as development of a healthy ego identity. This may emphasize the importance of a supporting and accepting environment for LGB individuals (Potoczniak et al., 2007), as apparent social anxiety and related symptoms can potentially be related to an individual’s identity. This may impact many areas of their life versus a generalized social anxiety that could persist (or exist) outside of identity development, though an individual’s identity should also not be assumed to be related to their problems and difficulties (Walsh & Hope, 2010). Safren and Pantalone (2006) found that compared to heterosexual youth, LGB youth reported more social anxiety, with higher social anxiety being associated with less satisfaction with social support. However, regardless of social anxiety, they found a trend of less satisfaction with social support among LGB youth compared to heterosexual youth overall. Additionally, fewer positive events were experienced among those LGB youth with higher social anxiety. These results suggest that social anxiety may have an impact on LGB youths’ social development, though it appears to be in conjunction with other unique developmental factors that these youth face during adolescence, such as exploration of their sexual orientation and learning to cope with challenges of this developmental time period. Safren and Pantalone (2006) hypothesized that social anxiety could be a barrier for LGB youth from receiving social support and participating in positive events, as it could create challenges for them in seeking out and maintaining relationships, even when like peers are around and available. They suggested that LGB youth may have fewer opportunities to engage in positive experiences with peers, which would allow them to build competence in social relationships, form satisfying supportive relationships, and create community, if they are fearful and avoidant of these very necessary social interactions due to social anxiety and perceiving that they may be different from peers in a way that may be rejected by others. This negative impact of social anxiety on LGBTQ individuals’ social supports could lead to difficulties with self-105   acceptance and self-concealment (Potoczniak et al., 2007; Roberts et al., 2011). Safren and Pantalone (2006) also discussed the social pressures that LGB youth may experience related to development, particularly around socialization and dating, which could create a pressure to conceal their sexual minority identity and conform to heterosexual behaviors. LGB individuals may also experience sexual risk behaviors related to social anxiety. Hart and Heimberg (2005) examined the relationship between unprotected sex and observation anxiety and social interaction anxiety among young sexual minority men. They found that social anxiety predicted an increased likelihood of engagement in unprotected sex in the past six months. Social anxiety can have many potential consequences for college students in addition to impaired social and occupational functioning (Sailer & Hazlett-Stevens, 2011). Substance use, depression, and suicidality are areas that research has indicated more risk for LGBTQ youth but has not specifically been directly tied to social anxiety empirically, though researchers have suggested possible relationships with these factors. There is the potential risk of increased alcohol and drug use for socially anxious LGB youth as there is already a relationship of high comorbidity between SAD and substance use in the general population (Buckner et al., 2008; Schneier et al., 2010), as well as higher prevalence of alcohol and substance use among LGBTQ youth in general compared to heterosexual youth (Marshal et al., 2008; Noell & Ochs, 2001; Rosario et al., 1997; Rotheram-Borus et al., 1994). Increased substance use may be related to marginalization, depression, loneliness, interpersonal stress, stigmatization, victimization, discrimination, homophobia, and shame (Bontempo & D’Augelli, 2002; Cochran & Mays, 2000; Herbert et al., 1994; Hughes & Eliason, 2002; Jordan, 2000; Mays & Cochran, 2001; McDermott et al., 2008; Roberts et al., 2011; Rosario et al., 106   1997). Individuals who are socially anxious appear to fear others noticing their anxiety and the potential social consequences of such (Sailer & Hazlett-Stevens, 2011). Lewis and Vogeltanz-Holm (2002) suggested that, in accordance with the tension reduction hypothesis, people frequently abuse or consume alcohol with the expectation that doing so will lessen uncomfortable feelings and thoughts, acting as a form of self-medication for those anxious feelings. These “ineffective coping strategies such as drinking and social isolation may be especially problematic in the college setting” (Sailer & Hazlett-Stevens, 2011, p. 2), as previous research has shown individuals who are socially anxious are more likely than those who are not anxious to report problems related to alcohol (Kessler et al., 1997; Kushner et al., 1990) as SAD is often a prominent motivation for heavy drinking among college students (Burke & Stephens, 1999). There is a higher risk of depression and suicidality among LGBTQ youth compared to their heterosexual counterparts, including higher frequency of reports of past suicide attempts (Almeida et al., 2009; D’Augelli, 2002; Eisenberg & Resnick, 2006; Garofalo et al., 1998; Hershberger & D’Augelli, 1995; Remafedi et al., 1998; Remafedi, 2002; Safren & Heimberg, 1999). While the relationship between depression and suicidality with social anxiety has not been thoroughly examined in the literature regarding risk factors for LGBTQ youth, it is likely an important variable to consider as it potentially connects with other related factors. For example, in two studies examining past suicide attempts by sexual and minority youth, Hershberger et al. (1997) found that predictors of past suicide attempts included disclosing one’s identity, losing friends due to disclosing, and victimization. Remafedi (1999) found variables associated with past attempts to include gender nonconformity, violence, lack of support, dropping out of school, 107   and family problems. Additionally, Bränström et al. (2020) found that barriers to social integration may contribute to higher risk of suicidality among LGB individuals. Based on the reviewed research, there are many significant contributing factors to the risk and impact of social anxiety among LGB college students. This research includes mixed results at times, with some studies demonstrating contradicting findings that could be due to many factors whether related to unique characteristics of the sample or variations in age, sex, gender, sexual orientation, or time period of the study. However, based on the research, potential risk factors for SAD for LGB college students may be general etiological factors for SAD that are common to all, such as genetic vulnerabilities, neurobiological vulnerabilities, inhibited temperament, poor attachment, negative parenting styles, negative life events (e.g., childhood stressors like abuse, illness, or family conflict) direct or indirect exposure to conditioning experiences such as socially traumatic events, social skills deficits, or cognitive biases (Higa-McMillan & Ebesutani, 2011). Risk factors for SAD for LGB students may also include social factors such as peer victimization (Craig, 1998; Walters & Inderbitzen, 1998) or sexual-minority-related factors including minority stress (Dürrbaum & Sattler, 2020; Eaton, 2014; Feinstein et al., 2012; Kuyper & Fokkema, 2011; Newcomb & Mustanski, 2010; Pachankis et al., 2014; Roberts et al., 2010; Sattler et al., 2017; Szymanski & Sung, 2010), lack of support socially and culturally from significant societal institutions (Russell & Fish, 2016), developmental issues, gender role nonconformity, abusive and negative family experiences, self-concealment, and sexual orientation victimization (SOV; Bailey & Zucker, 1995; Corliss et al., 2002; Garofalo et al., 1998; Poteat et al., 2009; Roberts et al., 2011). The impact of social anxiety on LGB college students may include difficulty building social support networks that assist with the transition to college (Kuder & Grover, 2014; 108   Nordstrom et al., 2014), reduced social support and closeness (Anderson et al., 2015; Purdon et al., 2001; Safren & Pantalone, 2006; Sailer & Hazlett-Stevens, 2011), higher levels of homesickness, academic problems such as lower grades, more absences from class, fear of public speaking, lower self-esteem, lower GPA (di Maria & di Nuovo, 1990; Nordstrom et al., 2014; Strahan, 2003; Urani et al., 2003), greater mental health symptoms such as somatization, obsessive-compulsive processes, and anxious, depressive, and phobic symptoms (Nordstrom et al., 2014), cognitive and affective difficulties (Kashdan & Roberts, 2004; Sailer & Hazlett-Stevens, 2011), sexual risk behavior (Hart & Heimberg, 2005), substance abuse (Buckner et al., 2008; Marshal et al., 2008; Noell & Ochs, 2001; Rosario et al., 1997; Rotheram-Borus et al., 1994; Schneier et al., 2010), and depression and suicidality (Almeida et al., 2009; D’Augelli, 2002; Eisenberg & Resnick, 2006; Garofalo et al., 1998; Hershberger & D’Augelli, 1995; Remafedi et al., 1998; Remafedi, 2002; Safren & Heimberg, 1999). This vast body of research is still limited in many ways when attempting to understand the causes, correlations, and impact of social anxiety among LGB individuals, college students, and LGB college students, specifically due to the extensive variety of factors that could be playing a role in these individuals’ experiences of social anxiety. The experience of LGB college students is a complex picture that requires consideration of intersectional factors when examining development, risk, and impact of mental health. An additional consideration when exploring the socially anxious experiences of LGB youth is that ultimately when contemplating some of these potential risks, it could be unclear whether an individual’s minority status comes with some of these risks leading to social anxiety, or if social anxiety could lead to some of these negative outcomes, or both. In reviewing this research, there is little information about the directional relationship or causes of social anxiety as it relates to LGB college students. Also, it 109   is important to consider the clinical implications, utility, and appropriateness of even diagnosing social anxiety if it were to be caused by minority status, since identity would be the mediating factor and the social context for having that anxiety would make sense. This is particularly true in relation to the need for hypervigilance, concern of protecting oneself, and being safe in the world as an individual who holds a minority identity that carries risk in and of itself. In this context, there is the chance that the anxiety could be appropriate at times and not considered to be “excessive” or “abnormal.”   110   Chapter IV: PROTECTIVE FACTORS AND PREVENTION FOR SAD In considering the expected high prevalence of SAD among LGB college students and the myriad of factors that could potentiate risk related to social anxiety, their transition to college, and their overall development and success, it is important to then explore the possible protective factors that can improve their outcomes and prevent a poor prognosis. This leads to the final question of this project, which is exploring which factors facilitate resilience and prevent or protect LGB college students from developing or further progressing social anxiety, as well as investigating effective approaches to treatment. The hypothesis is that the preventative or protective factors of social anxiety for LGB college students are an intersection of factors that are preventative or protective for LGB individuals and college students overall, such as perceived social support, increased supports on college campuses, accessible resources targeted to this specific population, integrated programming in the orientation process, and reduced stigma surrounding LGB community and mental health overall. However, due to lack of literature on preventative factors for college students broadly or specifically in relation to social anxiety, this project was unable to examine and review those factors in consideration of the intersection of the college student population and the LGB population. Therefore, factors related to the LGB population were primarily explored in this section. Not all members of the LGB community develop social anxiety or experience social anxiety in college. Therefore, it is important to identify the protective factors that increase resilience and buffer them from the development and effects of SAD. In considering factors that can facilitate or promote resilience, it is important to define resilience. One definition of resilience is a “process encompassing positive adaptation within the context of significant adversity” (Luthar et al., 2000, p. 543). Within resilience, there are risk factors and promotive 111   factors; the latter being resources that assist individuals in avoiding negative outcomes or consequences (Fergus & Zimmerman, 2004; Garmezy et al., 1984; Luthar et al., 2000; Rutter, 1985). Promotive factors work through compensatory processes, in which the factor directly impacts a result independently of risk factor effects, and/or protective processes, whereby the factor reduces the impact of a risk factor on a negative outcome or consequence (Fergus & Zimmerman, 2004; Garmezy et al., 1984; Luthar et al., 2000; Rutter, 1985). Resilience has also been defined as “a process resulting from the interplay of personal and contextual factors which allow LGB individuals to engage in positive adaptation to adversity, especially due to homophobic discrimination” (de Lira & de Morais, 2018, p. 278; Meyer, 2003, 2010). Based on this idea, de Lira and de Morais (2018) indicated that some researchers suggested resilience should be assessed through the interaction of risk and protective factors, with positive adaptation being the outcome of this interaction. Individual, family, and community-based resilience have been identified as the three main concepts of resilience (de Lira & de Morais, 2018). This chapter explores internal protective factors for LGB individuals such as social support, emotional openness, hope, optimism, health-promoting habits, psychological hardiness, outness, and religious faith. It discusses external protective factors for LGB individuals such as family support, social support, and broader community support. Then, it reviews ideas for intervention and prevention of SAD with LGB college students. Internal Factors A literature review was completed by De Lira and de Morais (2018), and they explored general resilience among the sexual minority population and examined internal factors that contributed to an individual’s resilience. They found these factors to include social support, 112   emotional openness, hope, optimism, health-promoting habits, psychological hardiness, outness, and religious faith. Kwon (2013) proposed a model of LGB resilience and explored resilience factors within the framework of that model. Working from a general model and concepts of resilience and acknowledging the impact of social relationships on health and well-being through connectedness and buffering of stress, they proposed that social support, emotional openness, hope, and optimism (in relation to a future orientation) were key factors to psychological health. While social support demonstrates a direct relationship to psychological well-being, it also helps through a mechanism of stress buffering. In addition to social support, emotional openness, hope, and optimism also work to reduce an individual’s reactivity to prejudice through stress buffering, which in turn impacts the individual’s psychological health and well-being (Kwon, 2013). Through conducting qualitative interviews with young gay and bisexual men who were diagnosed with HIV, Harper et al. (2014) derived primary themes regarding resilience processes for young gay and bisexual men. They found that resilience was demonstrated across the intrapersonal and interpersonal levels, in relation to cognitions, behaviors, seeking support from others, and providing support to others. The primary areas related to resilience included utilizing cognitive processes that promote health, engaging in behavioral habits or practices that are healthy, connecting with others to obtain social support, and providing support to and empowering other young gay or bisexual men (Harper et al., 2014). Figueroa and Zoccola (2015) explored the role of psychological hardiness in the association between stigma consciousness, which is related to poor mental and physical health outcomes and self-reported health. Psychological hardiness is defined as “a personality composite consisting of control (having a sense of control over life events), commitment (being 113   engaged and having a genuine interest in life), and challenge (seeing stressors as opportunities for growth)” (Figueroa & Zoccola, 2015, p. 330). They hypothesized that among sexual minority individuals, hardiness would buffer the relationship between stigma consciousness and self-reported health, based on past research demonstrating a buffering effect of hardiness and associations between hardiness and self-reports of better mental and physical health. They found a strong negative correlation between psychological hardiness and all physical and mental health variables, as well as a negative correlation with stigma consciousness. The results of this study suggested that sexual minority individuals with higher psychological hardiness had better mental and physical health. Additionally, they found a buffering effect on psychological hardiness on the relationship between stigma consciousness and discomfort from physical symptoms, indicating that higher psychological hardiness was associated with fewer physical symptoms. Despite the risks associated with coming out for sexual minority youth, research with LGB adults demonstrated that those who disclose their identities reported positive psychosocial adjustment and more support from family (D’Augelli, 2002; Luhtanen, 2002; Morris et al., 2001), as well as reduced depression and improved well-being in young adulthood for individuals who were out in high school (Russell et al., 2014). Additionally, students who reported concealing their sexual minority identity at school more still experienced victimization and concealment in school and had a negative association with adjustment in young adulthood (Russell et al., 2014), indicating that despite the risk, there are positive benefits related to LGB youth coming out in high school (Russell & Fish, 2016). Kosciw et al. (2015) investigated resiliency among LGBTQ students, particularly the role of openness about sexual orientation and the relationship between openness and student well-being. Coming out is often an important developmental milestone for LGB individuals, though it 114   is associated with both positive effects on psychological well-being and an increased risk of victimization, which can negatively impact psychological well-being. The authors examined not only the relationship between being out and well-being in relation to risk and resilience but also the impact of the community context of being in rural or suburban areas. They found that being out was related to higher levels of victimization while also being related to higher self-esteem and decreased depression. Additionally, they noted more victimization for out individuals in rural areas compared to suburban areas, as well as reduced well-being and academic success. However, this did not result in rural youth being less likely to disclose their sexual orientation. Ultimately, it appears that the positive effects on well-being related to outness often significantly reduce the negative effects of victimization and may be associated with improved well-being throughout life in general. However, it is always important to note the context of the individual and complete an analysis of the risks and rewards of being out versus assuming that being out is best for everyone (Kosciw et al., 2015). Walker and Longmire-Avital (2013) explored the relationship between religiosity, internalized homonegativity, and resiliency among young adult Black LGB individuals. They discussed how historically, religion has been used as a common tool for coping among the Black community and how Black LGB individuals may seek out religious support, as religion has been a path to resilience through navigating oppression. They found that for some Black LGB people, a lack of religious belief can substantially impact their ability to cope when experiencing considerable internalized homonegativity. Their findings suggest that religious faith can act as a resource and support for young Black LGB adults exploring their identity, as some religious institutions are successfully inclusive. However, there is also concern for individuals who seek support from institutions that are not tolerant of sexual minorities due to the potential impact on 115   those individuals if they experience conflict or rejection from their community. Ultimately, Walker and Longmire-Avital (2013) suggested that these two pieces of one’s identity, sexuality and religious faith, are not inherently mutually exclusive, and it is important for clinicians to acknowledge that the relationship between homonegativity and religious faith is a complex one, but the impact it may have on resiliency can be very important to explore. While this study specifically discussed the role of religiosity and homonegativity for Black LGB young adults, it is likely that this complex relationship with religion extends to other LGB young adults with varying racial or ethnic backgrounds and would be just as important to explore with those clients too. In a study examining sexual identity development and adjustment, Rosario et al. (2011) found that among LGB youth, consistently high identity integration or previously high integration was associated with better psychological adjustment. Specifically, they found that LGB youth with high identity integration reported significantly less anxiety, depression, and conduct problems, and higher self-esteem than youth with low integration. Youth with high identity integration also reported the highest self-esteem compared to middle or low integrated youth. Youth who were consistently high in integration or who were high and decreased to middle integration reported lower psychological distress than other youth. Additionally, supportive relationships were associated with better psychological adjustment, such that youth who had higher levels of family and friend support reported less depression, with friend support also associated with fewer conduct problems and family support also associated with higher self-esteem. Higher levels of support from family and friends were associated with a higher likelihood to be consistently high in integration or to move from high to middle integration. Overall, the researchers’ findings demonstrated the benefits of identity integration. The authors 116   suggested that LGB youth low in identity integration would benefit from being identified and supported through targeted interventions. This research highlighted the importance of addressing issues related to identity integration and how addressing challenges to identity integration may facilitate change that can lead to improved psychological adjustment. External Factors There has been some investigation into external protective factors in relation to individual resilience; these factors include family support, social support, and broader community support. Most research has examined the role of family and social support in relation to building resilience, particularly regarding the LGB community. Research has shown that support from parents and peers is positively related to LGBTQ youth well-being, self-acceptance, and mental health, especially sexual-orientation- and gender-identity-related support, which can buffer negative effects of minority stress (D’Augelli, 2003; Doty et al., 2010; Rosario et al., 2009; Ryan et al., 2010; Sheets & Mohr, 2009; Shilo & Savaya, 2011; Snapp et al., 2015; Ueno, 2005). Family Support Research has been conducted to examine the impact of family support on the well-being of LGB youth from both the perspectives of when LGB individuals have support from their families and when they lack support from their families. While lack of family support, and even more so rejection or victimization, can certainly pose a risk to health of LGB individuals, it is less clear the role family support plays as a protective factor or the degree to which it might buffer the effects of minority stress. Eisenberg and Resnick (2006) examined family connectedness as a protective factor for suicidal ideation and attempts among LGB youth. They found that family connectedness was significantly lower among LGB youth than heterosexual peers, but it was significantly protective 117   against suicidal ideation and attempts. In this study, the odds of suicidal ideation among youth in high family connectedness were about half that compared to youth with lower reported family connectedness. Additionally, in all of the models they tested, a greater amount of variance in suicidal behaviors was accounted for by family connectedness compared to other protective factors examined or sexual orientation. In a study examining the relationship between sexual orientation, victimization, and the effect these have on adolescent social-emotional health, Konishi and Saewyc (2014) found that the likelihood of experiencing social, emotional, or educational difficulties was significantly reduced for sexual minority students who had and had not experienced victimization through having the support of a caring parent (or even teacher) in their life. Ryan et al. (2010) examined the potential positive outcomes and protective factors of familial acceptance on the health of LGBTQ young adults. They found that family acceptance of LGBTQ youths’ identity is associated with positive mental health and physical health in young adulthood. Specifically, the findings indicated that support and acceptance of an LGBTQ individual’s sexual orientation and gender expression from their family is associated with higher self-esteem, social support, and general health. They also found protective effects of family support and acceptance including reduced experiences of depression, substance abuse, and suicidal ideation or attempts (Ryan et al., 2010). Relatedly, Reisner et al. (2014) completed a study exploring a compensatory model of risk and resiliency and the relationship to self-injury and suicide attempts among sexual minority youth, in which they found that decreased odds of self-injury and suicidality were independently associated with family support. These findings indicate that family support and acceptance is a significant protective factor for self-injury and suicidality (Reisner et al., 2014). In addition to support, parental reactions also have an impact on 118   LGB youth. According to a study by D’Augelli et al. (2008), youth who reported more positive reactions from their parents when they disclosed their identity revealed that they worried less about rejection, which may lead to reduced stress and anxiety for those individuals, especially around disclosing to others. Social Support A feeling of being different from others has been noted in LGB research, with a significant developmental task for LGB youth being to resolve these feelings, indicating that social support may be especially important for LGB individuals (Mustanski et al., 2011). There is a great deal of research demonstrating that supportive relationships can buffer the negative effects of stressful life events (Cohen & Wills, 1985), which can make supportive relationships a good factor to consider when exploring resilience (Mustanski et al., 2011). In a study testing two models of resilience, Mustanski et al.
