(2011) compared a compensatory model and a protective model, to explore factors that promoted healthy development among LGB youth in context of exposure to victimization. They found that peer support had the strongest correlation with psychological distress and had an independent promotive effect that did not vary significantly across age. Peer support included factors such as “lack of social loneliness, peer acceptance of homosexuality, and a sense of having friends as a resource” (Mustanski et al., 2011, p. 8) consistent with the idea that peer relationships play a critical role in adolescent development. For LGB youth, peer social support has been demonstrated to be protective of mental health, as social support was found to moderate the relationships between negative family attitudes and anxiety as well as family victimization and depression among LGB youth who lacked family support (Parra et al., 2018). More broadly, Parra et al. (2018) suggested that these 119   findings support the idea that peer social support can protect LGB young adults and buffer the adverse effects of negative attitudes, rejection, and victimization. For example, D’Augelli (2003) found that compared to LGB youth who lost friends due to coming out, LGB youth who kept their friends after coming out reported fewer symptoms of depression and suicidal thoughts and reported higher self-esteem. Carastathis et al. (2017) examined the development of resilience in relation to overcoming family rejection after sexual minority individuals shared their sexual orientation. In this study, individuals reported the use of social support, connecting with other sexual minority individuals, acceptance of themselves and others, and use of strategic concealment as factors that fostered resilience, a strong sense of self, and healthy well-being. The use of social supports, including friends, teachers, colleagues, and others within their support networks, provided these individuals with support and acceptance of their sexuality, which appeared to buffer rejection from family through challenging negative attitudes toward sexual minorities and demonstrating that they would be accepted, they belonged, and they were normal. These feelings of acceptance, normalization and belonging were also found through connecting with other sexual minority individuals. For some participants, connection with other sexual minority people was the first time they felt that they belonged, and they had a space to explore the many aspects of their identity. Connecting with other sexual minority individuals helped these individuals work toward their own self-acceptance and demonstrated that they could have a successful future as a sexual-minority-identified person. Through experiencing acceptance and support from others, as well as through therapy, individuals were able to foster self-acceptance and challenge negative self-concepts, which increased their ability to cope with rejection or negativity from others and accept others’ non-acceptance as the other person’s issue. Participants also reported strategically 120   engaging in concealment strategies such as self-monitoring and image management around family members rejecting their identity, especially just after they came out, to avoid further negative consequences. Shilo and Savaya (2011) examined the effects of social supports on mental health and the meeting of sexual orientation milestones among LGB youth. They found that acceptance of one’s own sexual orientation was significantly positively associated with family acceptance and support, and disclosure of one’s sexual orientation was significantly positively associated with support and acceptance from friends. Additionally, family and friend support had strong, positive associations with LGB youth’s well-being, whereas family and friend support had strong, negative associations with the individual’s mental health and mental distress, respectively. These findings emphasize the importance of family and friend support on LGB youth’s mental health and well-being, as well as the impact it may have on their process of identity formation, while also noting the different roles of important relationships and the impact that the source of support may have. Mustanski et al. (2011) found that family support was significantly negatively associated to psychological distress, but the effects are not as strong as the effect of peer support. In their study, peer support included the absence of social isolation, peer acceptance of sexual orientation among peers, and a sense of friendship (Mustanski et al., 2011). Regarding family support, they found that the effects reduced with age and younger individuals benefited significantly more from it than older individuals. Comparatively, there was no significant interaction between peer support and age. These results lead to the suggestion of using peer-support-focused interventions with older LGB youth and family support focused interventions with younger LGB youth. While they found that support from family and peers did relate to reduced psychological distress, they 121   did not find a significant interaction with either family or peer support and victimization, indicating that victimization still had significant negative effects and consequences on the individuals and these effects were not significantly reduced by family or peer support. Mustanski et al. (2011) concluded that more than social support is needed to improve the well-being of LGB individuals and while important, it is only part of the answer. While they recommend treatment still explores ways to increase social support, they also recommend direct community efforts to reduce victimization. An example of this kind of direct effort is programs such as safe school coalitions (Perrotti & Westheimer, 2001), which work to reduce LGB bullying and violence by putting mechanisms in place in schools. As a strategy to improve LGB youth mental health, mental health professionals can play a crucial role in advocating and supporting the implementation of such programs in their community. In relation to family and peer support, the concept of autonomy support, which relates to the support one receives in authentically expressing and being themselves in their relationships, plays a role in how safe an individual perceives a relationship or social context to be (Ryan et al., 2017). In a study examining the relationship between perceived autonomy support and outness and well-being, Ryan et al. (2017) found that LGB individuals were most out with, felt the most autonomy support with, and most well-being with friends versus family, peers, or coworkers. They also found that more outness was associated with more autonomy support and self-esteem and lower anxiety and depression. As individuals perceive more autonomy support, self-esteem increases and experiences of anxiety and depression decrease. These associations were even stronger for individuals who reported high levels of internalized homophobia, as high autonomy support reduced the differences in depression, anxiety, and self-esteem between those with high and low levels of internalized homophobia. 122   While the impact of social media on mental health presents many mixed results, Pellicane et al. (2021) found that social media use can have beneficial effects on individuals; in particular, when LGB individuals have affirming experiences of acceptance online it is related to reduced symptoms of anxiety and depression in the future. This would seem to contribute to the idea that peer support has a meaningful impact on LGB youth, even when that support is virtual and not nearby. Potoczniak et al. (2007) completed a study examining the role of social support and self-concealment in the relationship between social anxiety and ego identity development. They found that the relationship between social anxiety and ego identity was mediated by social support, suggesting that sexual minority individuals who are less socially anxious tend to have more social support, which promotes better ego identity development. They also found that social support mediated the relationship between social anxiety and self-concealment, indicating that higher levels of social anxiety were associated with less social support and more self-concealment. The authors suggested that these findings highlighted the significant role that social support plays in the lives of LGB individuals, as it can lead to decreases in self-concealment and contribute to ego identity development, emphasizing the importance of supportive social environments and accepting of LGB individuals. They also noted that perceived social support was more impactful for women in the study. Adjacently, Cox et al. (2010) found that in relation to acculturation strategies utilized by sexual minority individuals, internalized homonegativity is significantly lower among those youth who identify with the LGB community compared to those who do not identify with the community. For LGB individuals, “affiliation, connection, and participation with other ingroup members are shown to be important sources of well-being” (Cox et al., 2010, p. 1207). For 123   example, in a study by Ueno (2005), there were significant and main buffering effects by the number of sexual minority friends that LGB adolescents had. Ueno (2005) found that having more sexual minority friends significantly benefited sexual minority individuals as it was associated with reduced psychological harm related to problems at school or issues with parents, reduced effects related to victimization, and less depression over time (Ueno, 2005). Relatedly, though dating comes with barriers, as explored in Chapter III, some research has found that dating same-sex partners is related to positive outcomes for LGB youth, including improved mental health, increases in self-esteem, lower substance use, and decreases in internalized homophobia (Bauermeister et al., 2010; Russell, Watson & Muraco, 2012; Russell & Consolacion, 2003). One study found that the effects of minority stress on LGB youth’s well-being were lessened when they had a romantic partner (Baams et al., 2014). Community Support De Lira and de Morais (2018) completed a literature review exploring general resilience among the LGB population and examined factors contributing to community resilience. They found several main contributors to community resilience, which underscore the importance of collective identity and the community itself being an agent of resilience. One factor discussed by Mason et al. (2015) is the idea of collective self-esteem, which encompasses the pride of belonging to the LGB community. Another factor is the idea of cultural identity, which relates to the feeling of belongingness in being a part of the LGB community, sharing similar interests and values with others in the community, and feeling a sense of connectedness to others through an understanding of equality (DiFulvio, 2011; Zimmerman et al., 2015). An additional factor is the understanding among those within the community that there are shared challenges and a collective struggle that all are a part of an experience (DiFulvio, 2011). Kubicek et al. (2013) 124   explored social creativity, which is about seeking support as a community to work together and cope with stressful or difficult situations. Another factor contributing to resilience within the community is the development of subcultures, which serve as safe spaces for individuals to celebrate and express their sexual orientation (Kubicek et al., 2013). Community resilience is also fostered through a collective belief and expectation that challenges will be overcome (DiFulvio, 2011). Additionally, DiFulvio (2011) also discusses the idea of social activism within the community, where everyone works together to change social attitudes. De Lira and de Morais (2018) noted that much of the literature around resilience often focuses on individual and contextual aspects of an individual’s life, but it is important that resilience should not only be considered in relation to individual characteristics. They emphasized that it is important not to minimize the role of the social environment, which can promote or inhibit resilience through social, political, economic, and cultural forces. In particular, they noted that resilience can also be facilitated by environmental factors such as inclusive social and public policies that impact all, but especially for marginalized communities, such as policy around public health, education, and social services. For example, when school environments are protective, affirming, and feel safe, it benefits the mental health of LGBTQ youth by leading to reduced SOV, harassment, depressive symptoms, substance use, suicidal thoughts, attempts, and negative effects of victimization, as well as increased feelings of safety and better psychological health outcomes as young adults (Eisenberg & Resnick, 2006; Goodenow et al., 2006; Hatzenbuehler et al., 2013; Konishi & Saewyc, 2014; Kosciw et al., 2014; Poteat et al., 2013; Russell & Fish, 2016; Toomey et al., 2011). Kosciw et al. (2014) found that fewer experiences of SOV and harassment were reported 125   by students who lived in areas where sexual orientation and gender identity were included in antibullying laws compared to students who lived in areas without these laws. One way to provide support to students is through offering school-based LGBTQ support groups (Asakura, 2016; Hatzenbuehler et al., 2013; Kosciw et al., 2012), like gay-straight alliances (GSA). Research has found that LGBTQ students in schools with supportive programming and resources such as GSAs were less likely than students in schools without these resources to report depression, substance use, or suicidal ideation, and they reported feeling safer at school (Goodenow et al., 2006; Hatzenbuehler et al., 2013; Poteat et al., 2013). Furthermore, the positive effects of school-based LGBTQ support groups have been shown to continue into later developmental stages. Toomey et al. (2011) found reduced negative effects of SOV on well-being and reports of better psychological health in young adulthood among individuals who participated in the GSA at their school and felt their GSA promoted safety. Heck et al. (2011) found that individuals who attended a school with a GSA tended to demonstrate reduced levels of problematic alcohol use, fewer depressive symptoms, and lower psychological distress in young adulthood. Individuals who attended schools with GSAs also reported significantly higher ratings of school belonging and significantly lower rates of sexual-orientation-based victimization at school compared to individuals who attended schools without GSAs (Heck et al., 2011). In addition to laws and resources, LGBTQ students are more likely to experience better psychological adjustment, such as increased sense of safety, feelings of acceptance, and reduced experiences of victimization, when school policies and curricula are inclusive and LGBTQ-focused (Black et al., 2012; Kosciw et al., 2012; Kosciwet al., 2014; Toomey et al., 2012). Additional training and education for teachers, staff, and peers leads to increased understanding 126   of and empathy for LGBTQ students, which is associated with an increased likelihood of engaging in LGBTQ-affirming behaviors and intervening in discriminatory or homophobic situations (Greytak et al., 2013; Greytak & Kosciw, 2014; Kosciw et al., 2012; Poteat, 2015). Additionally, resilience and positive outcomes are fostered when students can feel a sense of school connectedness or knowing a caring teacher or other caring adult (Asakura, 2016; Eisenberg & Resnick, 2006; Konishi & Saewyc, 2014). This also applies for young adults in college, as relationships with faculty on college campuses can be supportive for LGBTQ students and have been found to be positively related to the academic progress and social integration of LGBTQ students in college (Linley et al., 2016; Woodford et al., 2015). Linley et al. (2016) found that LGBTQ students felt supported by their faculty when homophobia in the classroom was confronted, heterosexist and cisgender norms or discourse in the curriculum were challenged, inclusive language was used, diversity and multiculturalism such as LGBTQ topics and people were included in the curriculum, faculty were knowledgeable about LGBTQ issues, students’ preferred names and pronouns were used, advising was open and affirming, support and listening about non-academic areas of life were provided, LGBTQ faculty and staff are open and visible on campus, and faculty identify as allies and let students know their offices are safe spaces for LGBTQ individuals and issues. Woodford et al. (2015) found that the negative effects of campus climate relating to heterosexist harassment on depression and anxiety were moderated by physical exercise. Additionally, they observed that the negative effects of risk for alcohol abuse were moderated by self-esteem and having LGB friends (Woodford et al., 2015). Finally, they noticed that the negative effects on physical health symptoms were moderated by relationships with instructors (Woodford et al., 2015). These findings add additional support to the notion that social support 127   and positive coping skills can help change the impact of discrimination on college campuses (Woodford et al., 2015). A study by Hatzenbuehler et al. (2011) examined the protective effects of a social/contextual factor in psychiatric morbidity among LGB individuals in the United States. They utilized data from the second wave of the National Epidemiologic Survey on Alcohol and Related Conditions, which is an epidemiological survey completed through interviews with U.S. adults. The authors specifically examined the impact of same-sex couple concentration/density on the prevalence of mood and anxiety disorders among LGB individuals in states with higher and lower concentrations of same-sex couples. They also examined whether living in a state with a higher concentration of same-sex couples would buffer against the effects of economic adversity and social isolation, two risk factors associated with the development of psychopathology (Hatzenbuehler et al., 2011). The researchers found lower past-year prevalence of major depression and generalized anxiety among LGB individuals who lived in states with higher concentrations of same-sex couples than among those living in low-concentration states (Hatzenbuehler et al., 2011). They also found that LGB individuals who were exposed to economic adversity and social isolation were only at an increased risk of mood and anxiety disorders in states with a low concentration of same-sex couples. Social isolation was also specifically related to social phobia among LGB individuals in low-concentration states. The researchers did not find these interactions between risk and protective factors among heterosexual individuals, which led them to suggest that these effects may be specific to LGB individuals. They also suggested that these results support the idea that some social/contextual factors, such as concentration of same-sex couples, may have a protective effect on LGB mental health. Protective social/contextual factors are important to 128   explore as part of public health, as targeting these factors through policy or structural interventions may allow for opportunities to address population-wide mental health concerns, versus just implementing interventions at the individual level (Hatzenbuehler et al., 2011). An important part of understanding and exploring resilience is assessing factors that present risk as well as protection for a population of people. Protective factors work to mitigate the impact or outcomes of risk factors, generally leading to some positive adaptation for the individual. Protective factors come from many sources, including internal factors that can come from within the individual and external factors, which come from family, social networks, and the broader community, society, or system an individual lives within. This chapter explored these various factors and how they lend support to LGB youth and young adults. Research on internal factors has found that social support has shown a direct relationship to psychological well-being, though it also works through a stress-buffering mechanism (Kwon, 2013). Psychological health and well-being are also impacted by emotional openness, hope, and optimism through stress buffering (Kwon, 2013). Resilience is fostered through health-promoting thoughts and behaviors in addition to social supports (Harper et al., 2014). Psychological hardiness is also associated with better mental and physical health (Figueroa & Zoccola, 2015). Disclosing one’s identity is related to positive psychosocial adjustment, more family support, reduced depression, and improved well-being in adulthood, particularly when LGB youth have come out in high school (D’Augelli, 2002; Luhtanen, 2002; Morris et al., 2001; Russell et al., 2014; Russell & Fish, 2016). Outness has also been demonstrated to reduce the negative effects of victimization (Kosciw et al., 2015). For some LGB individuals, religious faith can impact resiliency, particularly with the complex relationship between faith and the Black community (Walker & Longmire-Avital, 2013). High identity integration is associated with 129   better psychological adjustment, such as less anxiety, depression, and conduct problems, as well as higher self-esteem compared with low integration (Rosario et al., 2011). Research on external factors has shown that family acceptance of an LGBTQ youth’s identity is associated with positive mental and physical health in young adulthood. Specifically, support and acceptance are associated with higher self-esteem, social support, and general health (Ryan et al., 2010). Family support, acceptance, and connectedness are protective factors against depression, substance use, self-injury, and suicidal ideation and attempts among LGBTQ youth (Eisenberg & Resnick, 2006; Reisner et al., 2014; Ryan et al., 2010). Additionally, having a supportive parent or teacher in their life significantly reduces the likelihood that sexual minority youth will experience social, emotional, or educational difficulties. Research on external factors has demonstrated that social support is related to many positive outcomes including reduced psychological distress (Mustanski et al., 2011), decreased self-concealment (Potoczniak et al., 2007), openness about one’s identity (Shilo & Savaya, 2011), facilitated ego identity development (Potoczniak et al., 2007), reduced internalized homonegativity (Bauermeister et al., 2010; Cox et al., 2010; Russell & Consolacion, 2003; Russell, Watson & Muraco, 2012), higher identity integration (Rosario et al., 2011), acceptance of one’s identity (Shilo & Savaya, 2011), improved psychological adjustment including reduced depression and anxiety and increased self-esteem (Bauermeister et al., 2010; Pellicane et al., 2021; Rosario et al., 2011; Russell & Consolacion, 2003; Russell, Watson & Muraco, 2012; Ryan et al., 2017; Ueno, 2005), and improved well-being and autonomy support (Ryan et al., 2017; Shilo & Savaya, 2011). Peer support is also a protective factor for LGB youth mental health, as it has been found to buffer adverse effects (e.g., anxiety, depression, suicidal ideation) of negative attitudes, rejection, and victimization from family, lack of family support, loss of 130   friends, and minority stress (Baams et al., 2014; Carastathis et al., 2017; D’Augelli, 2003; Parra et al., 2018). External factors of resilience for the LGB community also involve the idea of community resilience. Research indicates that community resilience is built from collective self-esteem (Mason et al., 2015), cultural identity (DiFulvio, 2011; Zimmerman et al., 2015), shared challenges and a collective struggle (DiFulvio, 2011), social creativity (Kubicek et al., 2013), subcultures (Kubicek et al., 2013), collective belief of overcoming challenges (DiFulvio, 2011), and social activism (DiFulvio, 2011). In addition to factors that impact individual and community resilience, the social environment plays a significant role in the development of resilience, as social, political, economic, and cultural forces can promote or inhibit the processes of resilience (de Lira & de Morais, 2018). Social and public policies regarding public health, education, and social services impact resilience, such that resilience can be facilitated when these policies are inclusive of all people (de Lira & de Morais, 2018). When local laws and school policies are inclusive and protective of LGBTQ individuals, the result is increased feelings of safety, reduced experiences of victimization and discrimination, and improved psychological health and well-being (Black et al., 2012; Eisenberg & Resnick, 2006; Goodenow et al., 2006; Hatzenbuehler et al., 2013; Konishi & Saewyc, 2014; Kosciw et al., 2014; Kosciw et al., 2012; Poteat et al., 2013; Russell & Fish, 2016; Toomey et al., 2012, 2011). Implementing school-based LGBTQ support groups, like GSA, has demonstrated positive effects such as reduced depression, substance use, suicidal ideation, psychological distress, and sexual-orientation-based victimization (Goodenow et al., 2006; Hatzenbuehler et al., 2013; Heck et al., 2011; Poteat et al., 2013). The reduced negative effects, improved well-being, and psychological health connected to GSAs have been found to carry into young adulthood (Toomey et al., 2011). Training and 131   education for teachers, staff and peers lead to increased understanding of and empathy for LGBTQ students, which can increase the chances of those individuals being affirming to and intervening for LGBTQ students (Greytak et al., 2013; Greytak & Kosciw, 2014; Kosciw et al., 2012; Poteat, 2015). Increases in affirming and supportive behaviors among heterosexual individuals and that teachers or adults in their lives care about them can result in LGBTQ students feeling supported, which can help with fostering resilience and positive outcomes (Asakura, 2016; Eisenberg & Resnick, 2006; Konishi & Saewyc, 2014; Linley et al., 2016). Even factors like community makeup can impact mental health and act as protective factors for LGB, such as findings of lower prevalence of depression and anxiety among LGB individuals who live in states with a greater concentration of same-sex couples (Hatzenbuehler et al., 2011). Research on resilience demonstrates that there are many avenues through which resilience is fostered on the individual, community, and societal levels, which can have a significant impact on the mental health and well-being of LGB individuals overall. There is still so much more to explore, as resilience research is still new and more limited for the LGB community in particular. However, when looking to support LGB college students, knowledge on LGB resilience and its impact on overall well-being and mental health can be a foundation for understanding the importance of fostering individual resilience and how the use of social support, connection to the broader LGBTQ community, and advocating for societal support through change of policy and law are the avenues through which individual resilience and success can be promoted. Thus far, this paper has investigated the approximate prevalence of SAD among LGB college students. It has also considered the risk factors that affect the lives of many LGB college students that could lead to the development of SAD. It explored potential internal and external 132   protective factors that might mitigate those risks for LGB college students. With a better understanding of the experience and impact of SAD on LGB college students, the next step is to determine what can be done directly and indirectly to support these students. Intervention Understanding the risk factors and impact of SAD on LGB college students can provide insight on how to approach treatment intervention and prevention strategies for LGB individuals. This section explores areas of consideration for therapy, therapy interventions, and community interventions for LGB individuals. Therapy Interventions For therapy interventions to be appropriate and effective, cultural and intersectional considerations should be made to tailor treatment to the client’s experiences and needs. Dürrbaum and Sattler (2020) suggested that interventions that support coping with minority stress, such as support groups, family interventions, or therapy to reduce minority stress, be specially targeted to LGB youth and address those difficult experiences associated with minority sexual identity, such as victimization, rejection from family and peers, and internalized homonegativity and binegativity. The role of constructs such as rumination, perceived burdensomeness, and rejection sensitivity in relation to minority stress and mental health should also be considered in the treatment of LGB individuals (Russell & Fish, 2016). Research by Hatzenbuehler et al. (2009) found an association between higher rates of stigma-related stressors and elevated levels of psychological distress among LGB individuals, with that association being the strongest among individuals who reported more experiences of rumination after facing stigma-related stress. Russell and Fish (2016) suggested that these results may demonstrate the importance of emotion regulation in the minority stress process, which may have implications for 133   treatment in relation to experienced stigma, such as utilizing interventions that focus on targeting maladaptive cognitions such as rumination. In another study, Baams et al. (2015) found that perceived burdensomeness mediated a link between minority stress and mental health in LGB youth, where feeling that they were a burden to others was elicited by minority stress and the burdensome feelings were strongly associated with experiences of depression and suicidal ideation. They also found that perceived burdensomeness accounted for the whole link between thwarted belongingness and mental health (Baams et al., 2015). These results propose that burdensome feelings, and the reduction of such, may be an important area to focus on in treatment, and that belonging may not be a critical mechanism despite being such a strong focus in general LGBTQ mental health (Russell & Fish, 2016). Pachankis et al. (2008) explored the relationship between parental rejection, gay-related rejection sensitivity, and internalized homophobia and found that the relationship between parental rejection and rejection sensitivity is mediated by internalized homophobia. They also found that unassertive interpersonal behaviors were significantly influenced by gay-related rejection sensitivity. A major takeaway from this study was finding empirical support for the common clinical presentations of the impact that past sexual-orientation-based rejection has on LGBTQ individuals’ current psychological functioning. In another study, McLaughlin et al. (2010) found a higher likelihood of psychiatric disorders among individuals who did not acknowledge or avoided discussing experiences of bias-based discrimination. Russell and Fish (2016) suggested that based on these studies, it could be helpful to use interventions that intend to understand the experiences of discrimination and stigma-related rejection, as well as the impact and meanings taken from these experiences. 134   Highlighting this research allows note of many psychological mechanisms and constructs that could be important to address with LGBTQ youth in treatment (Russell & Fish, 2016). In this small study interviewing LGB youth, Diamond et al. (2011) noted some important considerations for treatment with LGB youth, which included the youths’ own desires for their parents to be more accepting and to attend family therapy. Diamond et al. (2011) tested a treatment approach intended to address suicidality among LGB youth that was family-based and adapted from attachment-based family therapy. The treatment provided parents space to process their feelings about their child’s sexual orientation, as well as to learn about and become more aware of their reactions to their child’s orientation that could be diminishing or harmful. With this treatment approach, the LGB youth reported significant reductions in depression and suicidality. The researchers also noted success of the approach in the high levels of retention, which would be important for any treatment to be effective. The inclusion of family in therapy, as well as the provision of space for parents to process their own feelings and receive psychoeducation regarding the impact of their reactions, is an important component to address since the risks related to parental rejection can have significant implications for LGB individuals’ mental health and well-being, as discussed in Chapter III. In addition to therapy for the parents and families of LGBTQ individuals, other resources that provide information, education, resources, and support can be beneficial. The Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration provides a resource guide for practitioners to help them meet families where they are and help families learn how to support their LGBTQ children (Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, 2014). The resource guide discusses the role that families play in reducing risk and promoting well-being among LGBTQ youth, highlighting how crucial rejection and acceptance are to LGBTQ youth’s mental 135   health. The resource guide includes recommendations for educating and involving parents and families in interventions to affirm their children’s LGBTQ identities. The resource guide is research based and provides approaches to working with families, resources for increasing family support, educational resources for families including breakdowns of research findings on family support, intervention videos, assessment tools, and intervention strategies for families in supporting their children. They emphasize the importance of engaging LGBTQ youth’s families in supporting their children, in a way that is accessible and easy to utilize and engage with, which can be a great tool for many families who are unsure of where to start (Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, 2014). Often, LGBTQ individuals present for individual therapy. Therefore, it is important to research and explore treatment interventions that focus on or incorporate LGBTQ-related factors, such as community-specific issues or experiences. For example, Pachankis et al. (2015) explored the efficacy of a 10-session intervention adapted from the Unified Protocol for the Transdiagnostic Treatment of Emotional Disorders (Barlow et al., 2010). Their adaptation, the Effective Skills to Empower Effective Men project, focused on stigma-related stressors and minority stress experiences among young gay and bisexual men to reduce minority stress processes and enhance stigma coping. In the study, participants were randomly assigned to an immediate treatment group or a three-month waitlist. Self-report assessments and an interview were used to evaluate mental health, minority stress, and risk behavior at baseline, three-month, and six-month follow-ups. After treatment, they found significant reductions and clinically significant improvements in depressive symptoms, alcohol use problems, and sexual compulsivity compared to the waitlist group. They also observed significant improvement for minority stress post-treatment. The researchers noted that the overall effects of this intervention 136   were comparable to those found for other CBT interventions. They discussed that this intervention could be expanded or adapted for clinical work with women and LGBTQ youth (Pachankis et al., 2015). When considering treatment interventions for working with LGBTQ individuals and reducing minority stress, it is important to explore how to foster resilience. Kwon (2013) indicated that it is of paramount importance to understand resilience among LGB individuals and the factors that can lead to flourishment and fulfillment so that practitioners can develop interventions that are effective for the LGB community. They suggested some interventions that could support specific factors that play a role in resilience, for example, the use of behavioral activation to assist in increasing social activity and engaging with others to improve social support. Another example is facilitating emotional openness through use of emotion-focused and interpersonal approaches to treatment. Regarding hope and optimism, they considered cognitive behavioral therapy and the use of positive appraisals to improve an individual’s outlook and beliefs regarding the future. Additionally, they mentioned that primary prevention efforts have been beneficial for other stigmatized groups, so they considered the effectiveness of utilizing interventions to increase hope and optimism among LGB youth. Leleux-Labarge et al. (2015) also suggested considering the role of constructs such as psychological inflexibility, particularly as it relates to self-concealment, in an LGB client’s distress and the potential benefits of acceptance-based interventions. In a study exploring clinical intervention, Pachankis and Goldfried (2010) found improvement in psychosocial functioning and openness about sexual orientation among gay male college students who engaged in expressive writing that focused on gay-related stressors, particularly for individuals who wrote about serious subjects or indicated 137   having less social support. These different examples demonstrate that there are a variety of approaches to treatment interventions that can support resilience-promoting factors. Similar to tailoring treatment with the client’s cultural and identity factors in mind, treatment should also be specific to the presenting concerns or disorder a client is experiencing. Regarding SAD, Nordstrom et al. (2014) suggested addressing social anxiety and targeting it with CBT approaches when students arrive in college and utilizing social exposure through the built-in environment of peers and possible use of group therapy. They also suggested targeting self-esteem, as it was found to be a mediational factor partially explaining the influence of social anxiety on students’ adjustment. Ideas for intervention included increasing or strengthening self-esteem through the use of humanistic principles like strength-based approaches and CBT-based approaches such as reducing self-criticism, changing cognitive distortions, and increasing assertiveness and positive reinforcement. They suggested schools possibly using a standardized process to screen and identify students with social anxiety to engage early interventions during students’ first semester and providing support with transitional challenges. Additionally, connecting students to peer leaders as a supplement for social interactions and support could assist socially anxious students, as they indicated increased persistence, satisfaction, and feelings of belonging have been shown when relationships are built between peer leaders and first-year students. This approach incorporates many more interventions than just one-on-one individual therapy, including screening processes for early intervention and incorporating peer support into treatment (Nordstrom et al., 2014). As important as it is to find the interventions and treatment options that will be effective, it is just as important to learn what interventions are not as beneficial to treatment. For example, Sailer and Hazlett-Stevens (2011) found that the addition of interoceptive exposure exercises 138   with the intention of eliciting feared bodily sensations does not appear to have any clinical benefit and does not seem necessary when working with college students who have social anxiety, as it did not provide any more resolution than just exposure to a social situation. Knowing that interoceptive exposure exercises will not add any clinical benefit can save a clinician and client time and energy when planning treatment, which is especially important in college counseling settings where short-term and often solution-focused treatment is a primary modality of treatment. The primary purpose of this project has been to glean information on SAD among LGB college students. The next two studies discussed were the only two found in the literature search completed for this paper that explored interventions for SAD among LGBTQ individuals. Roberts et al. (2011) discussed the use of cognitive behavioral therapy to reduce symptoms of SAD and how its effectiveness with adults, adolescents, and LGBTQ adults may translate to usefulness with young LGBTQ individuals. The researchers indicated that interventions for prevention could also assist with concerns around alcohol and substance use, risky sexual behavior, lack of social support, depression, and suicidality. They highlighted that treatment should not only focus on irrational thoughts; it should acknowledge that many of the challenges in relation to negative social evaluation may stem from actual experiences of minority stress such as bullying, harassment, or isolation; therefore, building skills to manage and cope with these stressors should be emphasized as well. Roberts et al. (2011) also recommended that treatment include some focus on assisting LGBTQ youth in building supportive social networks to bolster the protective effects social support provides. The recommendations provided in this article incorporate a variety of interventions, including CBT exercises, prevention strategies for common risks, consideration for the impact of minority stress, and building social support, which 139   seems to highlight the complexity and added factors that are beneficial to explore when building a treatment plan, especially for individuals who hold any marginalized identity. Walsh and Hope (2010) presented a case study with a 23-year-old European-American male client who presented to a university training clinic with concerns about social anxiety and anxiety related to questioning their sexual identity. They discussed how research indicates the most effective treatment would be cognitive behavioral therapy while also being mindful of incorporating client characteristics and preferences as an important part of the treatment. Treatment consisted of 50 sessions over 18 months and initially focused on the client’s social anxiety using a workbook, Managing Social Anxiety: A Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy Approach—Client Workbook (Hope et al., 2000). They identified situations that made the client very anxious and developed a hierarchy of anxiety-provoking situations. The client worked on identifying their automatic thoughts in these anxious situations and eventually learned to identify thinking errors he used and challenge these thoughts. As he learned these skills, he practiced doing them as homework. He was then encouraged to challenge himself and expose himself to some of these difficult situations to practice these skills. As the client’s comfort in these anxiety-provoking situations improved, he seemed more comfortable talking about his challenges with his sexual identity, and the focus of treatment began to shift. It became more evident that his concerns related more to his sexual identity than a general fear of negative evaluation. They spent about 20 sessions exploring and considering his sexual identity, with the therapist following the guidelines of Pachankis and Goldfried (2004) regarding identity development and individuals in the questioning stage of their process. The client expressed many worries about the future and the process, as well as the ramifications, of coming out to his conservative family. Once the client began to personally identify as gay, 140   sessions focused on processing anticipated reactions from those around him if he chose to come out to them. They again began using cognitive restructuring skills for the automatic thoughts around these worries. They used another hierarchy of activities, this time related to his identity, to encourage him to actively explore his identity. They processed his experience after he completed an activity on the hierarchy. As the client became more comfortable, he began coming out to his family and friends who were, to his surprise, mostly accepting and supportive of him. After this, the remaining sessions (36 to 50), were used to explore his identity in relation to his interpersonal world, discussing romantic and sexual relationships, building a supportive social network, and preparing for termination. The client entered their first relationship, and first same-sex relationship, so related concerns and navigating conflicts were discussed in session and communication skills and coping strategies were reviewed (Walsh & Hope, 2010). Throughout treatment, the client’s social anxiety and worry symptoms declined substantially, as seen by his scores on the outcome measures employed. While his symptoms of social anxiety initially declined, they declined even further when treatment shifted to focus more on his identity in treatment. The changes in his scores across sessions 2-12, 14-50, and 2-50 were examined to assess the effectiveness of the various treatments/foci used, as well as the overall therapy process. Comparisons of his fear of negative evaluation scores indicated that the social anxiety treatment used from sessions 2-12 were not effective in reducing his fear of negative evaluation, but the significant decline over sessions 14-50 indicated that the identity-focused treatment was effective in reducing those fears. The therapist suggested that the significant reduction in scores may suggest that exploring his identity and committing to a gay identity helped reduce his fear of negative evaluation, fear of rejection, and general worries. In assessing 141   the client’s worry symptoms, both the social anxiety treatment and identity-focused treatment were effective in reducing his symptoms of worry. Overall, the treatment did appear effective in reducing the client’s social anxiety and worry symptoms. While the identity-focused therapy seemed more effective than the social anxiety treatment, the social anxiety treatment appeared more effective in reducing his worry than his social anxiety symptoms. The authors emphasized that this case highlights the important of referring to empirical literature and incorporating the client’s characteristics and preferences into the treatment plan for effective treatment. While there were limitations to generalizability of the outcomes in this study due to its nature as a case study, it presented a good example of overlapping symptomology and how important it is to be open minded and mindful in conceptualizing and working with clients from a marginalized population. It could be easy to overlook the client’s identity factors and the role they played in his experience of anxiety and worry if a clinician were only to focus on his presenting symptoms in treatment, which would miss significant factors at play that not only had an impact on the client’s mental health, but also were very important for the client to have space to explore. This case study also highlights the idea that practitioners should be careful in their clinical work not to over-pathologize symptoms that may be reasonable for the client’s context, in this case, being anxious and having worries about identifying as gay and the potential implications arising from that. The context related to the client’s identity plays a crucial role in how one conceptualizes his experiences. While this was a very thorough and lengthy course of treatment, which the authors acknowledged was due to the setting and fee structure allowing for no session limit, this would likely not be an ideal or achievable course of treatment in many college counseling centers due to the short-term nature of 142   treatment in many of these settings in relation to lack of resources and at times, session limits (Walsh & Hope, 2010). Community Interventions D’Augelli and Hershberger (1993) recommended continued establishment and use of programs in schools and the community that provide comprehensive and targeted crisis intervention, support, and socialization interventions toward LGB youth, specifically interventions to attend to issues such as self-esteem, alcohol abuse, peers, and family. Some education-specific recommendations include programs that discuss sexual orientation, such as information to dispel myths and misconceptions about sexual orientation, the impact of loss of friends and negative peer reactions from disclosure of one’s identity, and inclusive HIV educational programs that do not other or separate LGB youth. Russell and Fish (2016) discussed the importance of teachers, support, and policies in schools. Research has found that there is an association between student safety and adjustment and nondiscrimination/antibullying policies or laws that are inclusive of sexual orientation and gender identity (Hatzenbuehler & Keyes, 2013; Russell et al., 2010). These kinds of policies and laws permit teachers, administrators, and staff at schools to build an atmosphere that can then support the policies and practices that can promote a positive school environment, feelings of safety, achievement, positive mental health, and overall well-being of students (Russell & Fish, 2016; Russell & McGuire, 2008). Russell, Seif, and Truong (2001) found that establishing a positive school environment for students, especially LGBTQ students, depends significantly on the teachers, who can promote LGBTQ student well-being with the use of LGBTQ-inclusive teacher trainings and curricula that discuss the LGBTQ community and community-specific issues (Snapp et al., 2015). Research has shown that students having more affirming interactions 143   with their peers, experiencing a positive school environment, and demonstrating better adjustment is strongly associated with the presence of student-led groups or clubs, information on LGBTQ issues, and support for LGBTQ issues in schools (Poteat, 2015; Poteat et al., 2013; Toomey et al., 2011). The literature on intervention strategies for LGB individuals discussed individual treatment interventions, community interventions, and considerations for treating LGB college students. The studies examined the role of constructs related to mental health and minority stress, how they interact, and how they might impact treatment planning and focus. The importance of family support and the significant impact that familial rejection of one’s sexual minority identity were discussed, as well as the benefit of resources for LGB individuals’ families, such as education, support, and therapy of their own. Different ideas for interventions in individual therapy were explored, with common interventions including incorporating CBT techniques, minority stress-focused coping, and building of social supports. Reviewing this literature further demonstrated the gap in research concerning social anxiety among LGB college students in general, especially a lack of research addressing the treatment of this relatively common concern among the LGB college student population. Prevention of Risk for LGBTQ Individuals While intervention is necessary when risk is present and has begun to impact people, in an ideal world, preventative strategies could be employed to reduce risk and negative experiences. Understanding the risk factors that impact LGB individuals and can lead to mental health concerns like SAD can guide the development of preventative efforts to protect and support LGB individuals against that risk of negative outcomes. This section explores literature on strategies for prevention of risk among LGB individuals. 144   Roberts et al. (2011) discussed the negative experiences LGBTQ youth encounter, such as bullying, victimization, social isolation, and loss of friends and family, during their very important developmental years. As these experiences can predispose LGBTQ youth to develop SAD and other mental health issues, they indicate that it is important to reduce these negative experiences through preventative efforts, especially in schools, as youth spend a significant amount of time in school, and so much of their development occurs there. They emphasize that efforts focused on school safety and protecting LGBTQ youth, decreasing social stigma toward LGBTQ youth, and educating other students, faculty, staff and families on the importance of support for LGBTQ youth, as well as the significant impact of bullying and harassment, are critical (Eisenberg & Resnick, 2006; Garofalo et al., 1998; Roberts et al., 2011). Mustanski et al. (2011) advocated for addressing victimization directly, as support from others can only help LGBTQ individuals to some degree, but it cannot negate the negative effects of victimization. They suggested utilizing programs such as safe school coalitions (Perrotti & Westheimer, 2001), which work to reduce bullying and violence directed at LGB youth in schools, as well as provide resources and skills-based training for school staff to help them meet the needs of sexual minority youth and families. Fish and Pasley (2015) indicated that advocating for acceptance of and providing education on sexual and gender minorities through LGBTQ-inclusive curriculum, school programming, and policy could reach all students, including those who do not yet acknowledge or know their attraction or identity, which is particularly important as individuals who are questioning their sexuality or do not acknowledge their sexuality have an elevated risk for depressive symptoms, suicidality, and alcohol use. They suggested ways to foster a more inclusive and supportive environment include establishing gay/straight alliances and 145   implementing policies and providing training on sexual orientation, gender identity, and bias-based victimization. Mustanski et al. (2011) suggested creating supportive environments, such as LGBTQ youth centers, to facilitate peer support through socialization and connection to other sexual minority youth who can relate to them and their experiences. In attempting to assess when interventions could be most helpful to LGB individuals, Fish and Pasley (2015) found that there was an acceleration in level of alcohol use for LGB people during the transition to adulthood, moving from the lowest levels of use in adolescence to the highest levels of use in adulthood. Considering this information, they indicated that implementing strategies for prevention and intervention to reduce excessive alcohol use may be especially important during this transitional period for the LGB population (Fish & Pasley, 2015). Ellis (2009) suggested that embedding LGBTQ issues into curriculum content at universities is a powerful and effective strategy for increasing awareness, as the university can reliably engage a larger audience to address prejudice and discrimination and work toward fostering a more positive and inclusive campus climate. Further, they noted that establishing a campus climate of zero tolerance of prejudice, harassment, and discrimination is necessary for LGBTQ students to feel safe and for allies to be empowered to challenge homophobia. To do this, they discussed proactive actions by universities, including implementing policies, initiating sanctions for prejudice, and including LGBTQ issues in broader inclusivity efforts (Ellis, 2009). Taylor (2015) explored the steps community colleges can take to create an inclusive LGBTQ culture on campus based on research from other community colleges, four-year colleges, and large universities. They indicated that the most important action a school can take is to make an institutional commitment to support LGBTQ students, which includes strategically 146   engaging the campus and elevating LGBTQ students and LGBTQ issues to the campus level. They indicated that a commitment from institutional leadership provides a clear message to the campus community and can allow long-term support for LGBTQ students. They suggested creating a task force, which would require financial resources and a letter or statement from the president to announce the new efforts and demonstrate the commitment to supporting LGBTQ students. They recommended conducting a campus climate survey and needs assessment to assess the campus climate, experiences on the campus, and the needs of LGBTQ students. These surveys provide baseline information about LGBTQ students on campus, including the students’ needs, how they perceive campus, what their experiences are like in and outside of class, whether they feel safe, and any issues they may have. The data collected could guide the campus actions to support LGBTQ students. The next step is to provide training and professional development to school faculty and staff so they can begin to identify and mitigate heterosexism. They indicated that a common strategy is the use of ally or safe zone training, though making this training optional includes the risk that staff who could benefit from it may not be the ones who attend. Additionally, having faculty integrate LGBTQ topics and authors into their curriculum could help challenge heteronormative assumptions and biases in class topics and activities. Another step is to create space for and facilitate peer outreach and leadership, where LGBTQ students and heterosexual students directly engage in outreach programming related to LGBTQ issues. These can include delivering panel presentations, peer presentations, or other events, even integrating these kinds of presentations into regular programming or general education classes. This is important as research has suggested peer-to-peer engagement on LGBTQ issues could reduce heterosexist attitudes among heterosexual students (Taylor, 2015). 147   Finally, they recommended allocating LGBTQ-specific resources and making LGBTQ-inclusive policy changes. A significant campus resource that can support LGBTQ students is an LGBTQ resource center with professional support staff for LGBTQ students. Often, LGBTQ resource centers have a director that oversees campus-wide LGBTQ programming, advises student groups, consults other campus entities, and represents the LGBTQ community on committees. Policy changes can also be meaningful for LGBTQ students, including expanding nondiscrimination statements, creating faculty and staff training requirements, instituting policies on curriculum inclusivity, or establishing gender-neutral restrooms. This is not a comprehensive list of all the tasks a school needs to undertake to create an inclusive campus, but merely a place to start based on steps taken by other schools to improve the environment for their LGBTQ students (Taylor, 2015). Poynter and Washington (2005) discussed the idea of holding multiple identities or the vast diversity on college campuses and the intersectionality that comes with that diversity, particularly among individuals in the LGBTQ community. They explored the challenges of creating community on campus, as individuals who hold multiple identities may experience conflict between those identities or not feel that they have space within the communities they belong to because of the other identities that they hold and the biases between these communities. Some examples included being religious in the LGBTQ community and being Black within the LGBTQ community. They indicated that campus staff has a role in creating a just, civil, and open, multicultural community and emphasized creating spaces, programs, discussions, and living-learning communities for students to express themselves. They ended with suggestions to foster discussion, including allowing students to name themselves and their identities; engaging all students in discussions about race, religion, and other identities they hold; 148   working with multicultural or religious leaders on campus to discuss gender and sexual identity, inviting experts to speak on campus, and finding role models on campus who can speak to holding multiple identities (Poynter & Washington, 2005). The literature on risk prevention strategies for LGB individuals discussed efforts for creating safe environments and improving climate, reducing social stigma and victimization, providing support, and facilitating education among non-LGBTQ individuals. Much of the focus was primarily on academic settings, where LGBTQ youth and young adults often spend a significant portion of their time. Some ideas to facilitate these efforts included implementing inclusive curriculum, programming, and policies; creating safe, supportive spaces for expression and employing supportive programs such as safe school coalitions and GSA to facilitate peer support; demonstrating institutional support and commitment to the LGBTQ community; and allocating LGBTQ-specific resources. In considering how LGB college students can be supported as young adults and in an attempt to thwart the onset or worsening of mental health concerns, particularly social anxiety, several themes emerged across individual treatment interventions, community support, and considerations for the treatment of LGB college students. The first theme was an emphasis on support to cope with life stressors as well as minority stress. This includes the use of family and friend support, encouragement to include families in treatment if desired or warranted, and to provide resources and information to families, especially around the importance of their support for their LGB family member. This also included utilizing treatment interventions that are tailored to the LGBTQ population, that are mindful of their experiences with minority stress, and appropriate for the client’s stage of identity development. This entails using evidence-based practices while infusing client characteristics and preferences into treatment to ensure it best fits 149   their needs. Some effective treatment has focused on CBT skills, including identifying automatic negative thoughts, thinking errors, and thought challenges. Treatment can include creating space for and encouraging individual expression that focuses on gay-related stressors, as well as improving coping skills and emotion regulation to manage feelings and reduce minority stress. It is also important to acknowledge and validate clients’ experiences of minority stress, allow space and encourage them to talk about it, and work toward understanding their experiences of discrimination and the impact those experiences have had on them. Clinicians should try to understand LGBTQ resilience, including how they can support and facilitate it. The research also emphasized the importance of providing support, particularly supportive and safe school environments and community programs/resources (Eisenberg & Resnick, 2006; Fish & Pasley, 2015; Garofalo et al., 1998; Mustanski et al., 2011; Perrotti & Westheimer, 2001; Roberts et al., 2011). Part of this support includes education for peers, teachers, professors, parents, and families to destigmatize LGBTQ identity, teach them how to support LGB students, and to create safer, more supportive spaces for these students. There is an emphasis on making schools safe for LGBTQ youth due to the significant harm discrimination and victimization can cause. Suggestions for improving school safety and establishing a positive school environment include implementing nondiscrimination and antibullying policies and laws to reduce victimization and bullying, training for peers and school staff, including inclusive curriculum and programming, and establishing student-led groups or clubs for LGBTQ youth such as GSA. On college campuses, the climate can be improved similarly through establishing a commitment of support to LGBTQ students and centering LGBTQ issues, making inclusive policy changes, creating inclusive spaces, including LGBTQ programming, integrating inclusive 150   curriculum, creating space for expression, engaging all students on LGBTQ issues, and having difficult conversations with all students.    151   Chapter V: SUMMARY The purpose of this project was to examine the gap in the literature on social anxiety among LGB college students by investigating the prevalence of social anxiety among LGB college students, exploring general and SAD-specific risk factors for LGB college students, and reviewing protective factors and prevention strategies for risk among LGB college students. This is important to explore because there is a significant lack of research and information on the prevalence and impact of SAD among LGB college students, and as this project demonstrated, the gap is wider than anticipated, with limited literature on the prevalence of SAD among the general college and LGB populations overall. Understanding the prevalence of SAD among college-age LGB individuals, the risk factors and impact on this population, and how they can be supported through this significant transition in life may allow for the reduction in or prevent the development of SAD, which may assist these individuals in successfully managing the stressors of college and reaching their goals. This project investigated the prevalence of SAD among LGB college students by reviewing studies on the prevalence of SAD among the general college population and studies on the prevalence of SAD among the broader LGB population. Then, this project explored research on risk factors for SAD in general, risk factors for SAD among the LGB population, general risk factors among the LGB population, and the impact of SAD on college students and LGB individuals. Finally, this project reviewed the literature on protective factors and prevention strategies for risk among LGB individuals. The Prevalence of Social Anxiety Among LGB College Students The first research question examined the prevalence of social anxiety among LGB college students. As research has tended to report a higher prevalence rate of social anxiety and 152   other psychological disorders among LGB individuals, it was hypothesized that LGB college students would also report higher rates of social anxiety than their heterosexual peers. In an attempt to estimate the prevalence of SAD among LGB college students, studies assessing the prevalence of SAD among college students in general and studies assessing the prevalence of SAD among LGB individuals in general were examined. The goal was to use these data to extrapolate an estimated SAD prevalence for LGB college students, as there is a gap in the literature pertaining to this population’s experience of SAD. Caution must be exercised in comparing these populations and studies, in addition to caution around the overall prevalence of SAD in general. Overall, the research appears to be of varying moderate to good quality. There was much variation in the methods used across studies to categorize and measure social anxiety, which can create a challenge of being certain the same construct is being measured, as even small changes in the definition of SAD can significantly skew the prevalence estimates that are found. That was a significant challenge in attempting to compare the results of these studies, as well as determining which results were the most accurate. Similar to the variation in the definition of SAD, there was considerable variation in how sexual orientation was defined, operationalized, and measured across studies, which can skew the sample and impact the results as well. The reviewed research indicated that the prevalence of SAD among college students is likely between 8.5% (Bella & Omigbodun, 2009) and 80% (Ahmad et al., 2017), with the majority of studies falling between 16.4% and 32.8%. The reviewed research demonstrated that the 12-month prevalence of SAD among LGB individuals is likely between 7% (Sandfort et al., 2001) and 15.3% (Sandfort et al., 2014), and the lifetime prevalence of SAD among LGB 153   individuals is likely between 4% (Bostwick et al., 2010) and 27.1% (Meyer et al., 2008), with the majority of lifetime prevalence falling between 14.6% and 27.1%. It would appear that both of these populations demonstrated some common overlap for the majority of the studies, indicating prevalence between 14.6% and 32.8% in the middle range. It would seem likely that the prevalence of SAD for LGB college students would be comparable to this range, with some note that the actual prevalence may be a bit higher, especially for students with any sexual orientation that includes people of the same and different sex or gender from their own. It was worth noting that compared to the suggestions of the overall literature, among these studies that were examined, many of the LGB prevalence rates were slightly lower than the general college student prevalence rates. This may be due to the inconsistencies in measurements across the studies or possibly that the general college student samples were a mixture of heterosexual and sexual minority students. As none of the college population studies reported sexual orientation, it could not be explored further. One consideration was that it might be possible that the prevalence for the college population was higher than for the LGB population, which would have implications for the LGB college student population, whose prevalence of SAD could be even higher than was estimated here. Risk Factors For SAD The second research question examined the risk factors contributing to social anxiety among LGB college students. It was hypothesized that risk factors that contribute to social anxiety among LGB college students would be an intersection of those factors that contribute to social anxiety for other LGB individuals and other college students, such as identity development, social support, minority stress, and significant life transitions. 154   Based on a review of the research, there were many potential contributing risk factors for SAD among the LGB college population. These factors included general etiological factors that are common to all, such as genetic vulnerabilities, neurobiological vulnerabilities, inhibited temperament, poor attachment, negative parenting styles, negative life events, and exposure to conditioning experiences such as traumatic events, social skills deficits, or cognitive biases. Risk factors specific to the LGB population, and therefore to the LGB college student population, included social factors such as peer victimization, minority stress, lack of social or cultural support from society, developmental issues, gender role nonconformity, abusive and negative family experiences, self-concealment, and SOV. SAD’s impact on LGB college students might include difficulty building social support networks that could assist with the transition to college, reduced social support and closeness, and higher levels of homesickness. SAD may lead to academic problems such as lower grades, more absences from class, and a lower GPA. SAD may impact fears of public speaking, lower self-esteem, engagement in risky sexual behaviors, and substance abuse. SAD may contribute to greater mental health symptoms such as cognitive and affective difficulties, somatization, obsessive-compulsive processes, anxious symptoms, depressive symptoms, phobic symptoms, depression, and suicidality. These are not comprehensive lists, as they only consider the factors that have been studied until now. However, both the risks and the potential impacts demonstrate just how limited our knowledge and understanding of mental health is while at the same time highlighting just how unique each person’s experience is to themselves. While it is important to note that this research did not provide information on the directional relationship or causes of social anxiety, these findings are still valuable. Being aware of the potential risk factors and the impact that 155   SAD may have on an individual can assist future conceptualization and treatment, as well as efforts to mitigate or prevent some of these challenges on an individual and broader societal scale. Protective Factors and Prevention for SAD The third research question examined the protective factors that can facilitate resilience against social anxiety among LGB college students. The hypothesis was that the preventative or protective factors of social anxiety for LGB college students would be an intersection of factors that are preventative or protective for LGB individuals and college students overall, such as perceived social support, increased supports on college campuses, accessible resources targeted to this specific population, integrated programming in the orientation process, and reduced stigma surrounding LGB community and mental health overall. Based upon a review of the research, possible protective factors that are associated with positive outcomes for LGB college students included social support, emotional openness, hope, optimism, psychological hardiness, family support, family acceptance, family connectedness, having a supportive parent, teacher, or other adult in one’s life, high identity integration, outness, coming out in high school, disclosing one’s identity, affirming and intervening behaviors from supportive others, and community factors. Community factors included community resilience, connection to the LGBTQ community, the social environment, which included social and public policies/laws regarding public health, education, and social services, training and education on LGBTQ issues for the community, and community makeup such as concentration of LGBTQ individuals in one’s local community. This paper found that resilience is fostered through many avenues, including individual, community, and societal processes. Based upon the research reviewed, specific factors that foster 156   resilience included health-promoting thoughts and behaviors, religious faith for some, particularly for Black LGB individuals for whom religion is often intertwined in culture, and feeling that a teacher or adult in one’s life cares about them. Social support is one of the most studied and seemingly impactful protective factors for LGB individuals, as it is associated with so many positive outcomes, including many of the protective factors listed here as well as acting as a buffer to protect mental health. Social support being significantly important for college student adjustment overall and being necessary for LGB individuals’ well-being emphasizes how crucial social support must be for LGB college students’ adjustment and well-being. On the broader level, individuals can benefit from community resilience and connecting to the LGBTQ community. Community and individual resilience can be impacted by the social environment, which involves forces that can promote or inhibit resilience, including social, political, economic, and cultural forces. For example, social and public policies and laws on public health, education, and social services can impact an individual’s ability to build resilience or be resilient. Inclusive and protective local laws and school policies can facilitate resilience, increase feelings of safety, and reduce victimization and discrimination for LGBTQ individuals. The next step after exploring risk factors and protective factors that can foster resilience was to apply this information. The purpose of exploring this information was to gain an understanding of how to support LGB college students to thwart the onset or worsening of mental health concerns, specifically related to social anxiety, during the transition to adulthood and college. Several themes emerged across individual treatment interventions, community support, and considerations for the treatment of LGB college students. There was an emphasis on peer and family support to cope with life stressors, as well as including these supports in 157   treatment efforts. It is also recommended to use evidence-based practices that are inclusive and tailored to the client’s needs and experiences, especially taking into consideration the stage of development and experiences with minority stress as a sexual minority individual. Another major emphasis was on providing supportive and safe environments for LGBTQ individuals. This includes implementing community and school programs that provide resources to LGBTQ students and families, as well as providing education and training to broader peer, family, and community members so they can learn how to support these individuals and create safer, more supportive environments for them. Schools, in particular, are emphasized due to how much time LGBTQ youth spend there and how prevalent discrimination and victimization are in schools, which are major risks that cause significant negative impacts and harm to LGBTQ individuals. Suggestions for schools and college campuses include implementing nondiscrimination and antibullying policies and laws, education and training, inclusive curriculum and programming, and establishing student-led groups or clubs for LGBTQ individuals. Clinical Usefulness and Implications This project explored a gap in the literature, highlighting that this area would benefit from additional attention and research. The dearth of information around the prevalence and impact of social anxiety on the college population and the LGB population is important because social anxiety is known to be prevalent and chronic, affecting all areas of an individual’s life, but especially impacting the creation of social support networks and therefore access to social supports. Social support is one of the primary protective factors and promoters of resilience among all people, especially in marginalized communities like the LGBTQ community. Knowing that such a prevalent disorder is common among these populations and affects one of the main factors contributing to those individuals’ ability to adjust successfully and to their well-158   being comes with the responsibility of better understanding that disorder, its impact on that population, and how to intervene to assuage its negative effects. This project brings together research on the LGB population and the general college population to consider what the situation (e.g., prevalence, risk factors, protective factors) may look like at the intersection of those two groups, the LGB college student population. This is important as it contributes to the information that clinicians and researchers working with this population may benefit from exploring. This project highlights the estimated high prevalence of social anxiety among the LGB college population, which can alert clinicians that SAD is something to consider and assess in their work with students. Describing the risk and protective factors can help guide clinicians in their assessment and treatment of their clients, especially by emphasizing client strengths and building skills and supports to foster their resilience. Exploring treatment considerations and interventions informs the clinical work that clinicians do with their clients. The emphasis on utilizing evidence-based practices while also infusing minority stress-informed care can allow clinicians to consider how they bring culture and minority stress into their work. It also serves as a reminder of the importance of the use of clinical judgment and collaboration with clients to provide treatment that will be effective for them.
