Discussing prevention and larger-scale community/societal interventions that can impact the lives of LGBTQ individuals can inform clinicians and researchers, as well as the community, on what kinds of actions can have an impact and make a difference. This can help guide individuals in their practices of advocacy and how they get involved in their community. Limitations This project is a comprehensive literature review used to explore the current research pertaining to social anxiety among LGB college students and to highlight the limited amount of 159   research on this topic that constitutes a gap in the literature. Part of the limitations of this project is the nature of that gap and that there is limited research available to explore. This project attempted to estimate the prevalence of social anxiety among LGB college students, but this is just an estimation through reviewing the literature, and no statistical analysis or procedures were used. Therefore, the results are simply a broad view but not an exact measurement of the prevalence of social anxiety among LGB college students. Another limitation of this project is that the conclusions depend on the research and quality of the research that was reviewed, which impacts the accuracy of what was found. The research reviewed varied significantly regarding techniques, types of study conducted, assessments and definitions, the country completed in, and the populations. This limits the generalizability of the research and subsequently the culmination of the findings. The summary of risk factors, protective factors, and ideas for prevention and interventions are also limited to findings in the existing literature. This project is also limited by the research that could be accessed during the research procedure. Recommendations for Future Research In some of the more recent studies reviewed, the researchers have already worked toward making adjustments to their research design based on past completed analysis and recommendations, which improved the research compared to past concerns. Researchers continuing to make these adjustments based on recommendations will continue to improve the quality of the body of literature. Based on the reviews in this project, future research would benefit from using more standardized or consistent methods for study set up and completion. This standardization could include ideal procedures for collecting prevalence data, particularly among small populations that historically have been challenging to collect accurate and representative information about. Part of this standardization could also include using more clear 160   and consistent definitions and operationalizations of the variables being studied. For example, in the research reviewed in this project, a significant critique is the wide variation in how sexual orientation and social anxiety were defined and measured. The variations in these definitions can alter the data and resulting findings. With consideration of intersectionality, a significant issue in the body of literature is the need for research on the experiences of LGBTQ people of color. Not only is research on the experience of LGBTQ people of color lacking, the research that does exist has been primarily completed by White researchers. Future research should specifically explore the intersection of race/ethnicity and sexual orientation, to learn more about and understand the experience of LGBTQ people of color. This future research should center the voices of LGBTQ people of color and be conducted through an intersectional lens.  Additionally, finding one or a few valid and reliable measures or assessments to be widely used across studies could help alleviate concerns about the construct being measured and ensure that studies contribute to the knowledge of the same construct. Furthermore, the variations in these definitions and their use, particularly around identity variables like sexual orientation, can be very impactful by the language used. Use of inclusive language and being mindful of how we choose to describe groups of people is important to avoid invalidating people’s lived experiences. This also applies to language used in the measures and assessments utilized; it is important to use measures that use inclusive language for the population one is working with.  Based on the findings of this project from the research that was reviewed, the literature is missing information on the prevalence, risk factors, and protective factors for social anxiety among LGB college students. It would benefit LGB college students for social anxiety to be a 161   topic of focus to facilitate the creation of interventions and prevention strategies that will support these students and allow them to be successful. LGB college students would benefit from therapeutic interventions that integrate their identities and address experiences of minority stress, campus wide policies and actions that integrate LGBTQ issues into programming, curriculum, and socialization; and prevention programming aimed at identifying and supporting vulnerable students early in their college career. These students would also benefit from the creation and maintenance of safe, supportive LGBTQ spaces on campus where they can connect with others and build community. While these spaces do exist on many campuses, students are not always aware of them, so greater awareness and promotion of these spaces from all campus entities would help reach more students.     162   References Adewuya, A. title: Investigating the Prevalence of Social Anxiety in LGB College Students
abstract: This project examined the gap in the literature on LGB college students and social anxiety. The dearth of information around the prevalence and impact of social anxiety on the college population and the LGB population is important because social anxiety is known to be prevalent and chronic, affecting all areas of an individual’s life, but especially impacting the creation of social support networks and therefore access to social supports. Social support is one of the primary protective factors and promoters of resilience among all people, especially in marginalized communities like the LGBTQ community. Knowing that such a prevalent disorder is common among these populations and affects one of the main factors contributing to those individuals’ ability to adjust successfully and to their well-being, comes with the responsibility of better understanding that disorder, its impact on that population, and how to intervene to reduce assuage its negative effects. This project reviewed prevalence rates of social anxiety disorder (SAD) among the college student population and the LGB population to estimate the prevalence of SAD within the LGB college student population. This project also explored the risk factors of SAD for college students and LGB people to investigate the risk factors of SAD for LGB college students. Finally, this project reviewed protective factors and prevention strategies for SAD among LGB people to consider the clinical application for LGB college students, including therapeutic, social, and community interventions. Clinical implications and recommendations for future research are included
